document: These are external links and will open in a new window. the Pacific island attorney general says the new version is fundamentally the same as the first, calling the new version" Muslim Ban 2. 0". The directive, which takes effect on 16 March, places a 90 - day ban on people from six mainly Muslim nations and a 120 - day ban on all refugees. The previous order, which was blocked by a federal court, sparked confusion at airports and mass protests." Nothing of substance has changed: There is the same blanket ban on entry from Muslim - majority countries ( minus one)," Hawaii Attorney General Doug Chin said of the new order. the new version will bar entry of citizens of Iran, Libya, Syria, Somalia, Sudan and Yemen for 90 days. Iraq, which was included in the first ban, has been taken off the list. Mr Chin also said the directive included" the same sweeping shutdown of refugee admissions ( absent one exception) and lawless warren of exceptions and waivers", despite the changes made. The new order lifts an indefinite ban on those from Syria. the new version will also no longer affect legal US permanent residents, and drops controversial language about giving priority to religious minorities. These amendments were introduced in response to legal complaints, which saw the first order blocked by US federal courts. Judges ruled that the ban was unconstitutional amid concerns the original ban unfairly targeted Muslims, something the government denied. Hawaii was among a number of states who filed lawsuits against the original ban saying the original ban would harm residents, businesses and schools. the Pacific island filed a fresh complaint late on Wednesday, calling for an emergency block on the new order. A hearing is set for March 15, a day before the new ban is to go into effect. President Trump has not yet commented on Hawaii' s latest legal bid, but has previously insisted President Trump has the right to enact such an executive order and hit out at" so political" courts. Speaking to local news channel Khon 2, Mr Chin said the new ban had the same" nation - of - origin discrimination problems" as the first. Hawaii Attorney General Doug Chin said this was a particularly sensitive issue in Hawaii because of memories of Japanese internment camps on the Pacific island during World War Two. Although the new directive sought to answer legal complaints, Mr Chin said the new version still constituted a" Muslim ban" because of the countries involved and statements from administration officials. In justifying the ban on Monday, Attorney General Jeff Sessions said there are more than 300 refugees under investigation for potential terror offences. But no further details were given. The US appeals court previously criticised the government for failing to provide" evidence that any alien from any of the countries named in the order" had committed a terrorist attack in the US.
summary: The US state of Hawaii has filed a legal challenge to President Donald Trump' s new executive order on immigration, days before President Donald Trump ' s new executive order on immigration is due to go into effect.

summary: The Queen has sent The Queen first ever tweet to mark The Queen 90th birthday, thanking people for people" kind messages of goodwill" on social media.

Forty concerns were raised about patients in just over three years with the local safeguarding board run by South Gloucestershire Council. And perhaps the officer relied upon that information too much." Det Ch Supt Louisa Rolfe , of Avon and Somerset Police added:" Avon and Somerset Police accept that there is learning for us as an organisation and Avon and Somerset Police will do things differently in future." document: The All Progressives Congress ( APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in results declared from Saturday' s elections. won is the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party ( PDP) since military ruled ended in 1999. the Peoples Democratic Party ( PDP ) lost the presidential poll last month for the first time. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari will be inaugurated on 29 May, after APC leader Muhammadu Buhari defeated President Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP' s decline has been reinforced by results from Saturday' s elections for governors and state assemblies, reports the BBC' s Bashir Saad Abdullahi from the capital, Abuja. The party lost for the first time in key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, the home of outgoing Vice - President Namadi Sambo. the Peoples Democratic Party ( PDP ) also lost control of Adamawa, one of three states badly hit by militant Islamist group Boko Haram' s insurgency. However, the party managed to hold on to Rivers State, Nigeria' s oil hub. The PDP won eight governorships, mostly in the south - east. Taraba is the only result still outstanding, while the election in Imo state was declared inconclusive, because the number of spoilt ballot papers was larger than the margin of victory. Elections were not held in seven states. Analysis: Chris Ewokor, BBC Africa, Abuja. The APC has made historic gains, relegating the once - powerful PDP to a regional party. The PDP failed to get a national spread of votes, doing well only in the south - east and the oil - rich Niger Delta. Most states in the north went to the APC, along with Nigeria' s commercial hub, Lagos, in the south - west. However, the APC failed to win in any of Nigeria' s five oil - producing states. failed will be of huge concern to President - elect Muhammadu Buhari, as militant groups could disrupt oil production and starve the federal government of much - needed oil revenue. It is unlikely that the PDP governors in the five states would help Gen Buhari rein in the militants. In parts of the country, the elections were marred by violence due to stiff rivalry, and the battle for power and money. Ethnic differences also fuelled the conflict in some areas, but overall the elections have been more peaceful than in previous years, raising hopes that Nigeria' s democracy is maturing. Why Jonathan lost? Buhari' s historic victory. Nigeria' s 36 governors enjoy wide powers and are extremely influential. Some, especially in oil - producing areas, control bigger budgets than those of national governments in some neighbouring West African countries. The Independent National Electoral Commission ( Inec) reported 66 violent incidents at polling stations - higher than in the presidential poll. Most of the violence took place in Rivers and other southern states, where voting at some polling stations had to be extended. On Sunday, Inec also announced that the APC had retained power in Lagos state. retained means that when Gen Buhari takes over the presidency it will be the first time that the party of the president has controlled Lagos - the commercial capital - since the advent of multi - party democracy in 1999. Our correspondent says the PDP will have to go through a period of introspection, and then rebuild the PDP under a new leader. The party was in power for 16 years, and voters felt that it was time for change, Our correspondent says. the PDP had been hit by the defection of governors and MPs to the APC ahead of the elections. The PDP also faced widespread allegations of corruption during the PDP rule, and was accused of failing to do enough to end an Islamist - led insurgency in the north - east where the PDP suffered huge defeats.
summary: Nigeria' s main opposition party has suffered Nigeria ' s main opposition party biggest defeat since the end of military rule, in elections for state governors and state assemblies.

document: The mural, called Slave Labour, disappeared from a wall in Wood Green, north London, in February and appeared in a Miami sale. But The mural , which depicts a boy hunched over a sewing machine making Union Jack bunting was removed from the lot after protests by Haringey Council. The mural , which depicts a boy hunched over a sewing machine making Union Jack bunting is now up for auction in June in Covent Garden by the Sincura Group. A local councillor and the local Trades Union Congress have attacked the sale. The mural, which depicts a boy hunched over a sewing machine making Union Jack bunting, appeared on the side of a Poundland store last May, just before the Diamond Jubilee celebrations. A spokesman for the auctioneers Sincura said the mural" has been sensitively restored under a cloak of secrecy", and will go on show alongside pieces by Damien Hirst, Andy Warhol, Mario Testino and Russell Young. But Wood Green councillor Alan Strickland said:" The mural , which depicts a boy hunched over a sewing machine making Union Jack bunting is a piece of art given to the community for public enjoyment, and people will find it galling that you can only view this work at an expensive champagne reception, when The mural , which depicts a boy hunched over a sewing machine making Union Jack bunting belongs with the people of north London, not a private owner." We saw the level of public anger last time, as the story went around the world, and Wood Green councillor Alan Strickland expect the same this time." And Keith Flett, secretary of the Haringey Trades Union Congress, said:" The Slave Labour Banksy belongs to the people of Haringey not to a wealthy private client." When the mural was up for auction in Miami, The mural , which depicts a boy hunched over a sewing machine making Union Jack bunting was expected to fetch up to Â £ 450, 000. There was suspicion The mural , which depicts a boy hunched over a sewing machine making Union Jack bunting had been stolen when The mural , which depicts a boy hunched over a sewing machine making Union Jack bunting disappeared but the Metropolitan Police said there were" no reports of any theft". Slave Labour will go on sale at the London Film Museum on 2 June.
summary: A Banksy mural that went missing from a wall in London and was later removed from an auction in the US is to be put up for sale in London.

document: Of the 863 men who died, an estimated 120, known as" the Jersey Pals", were killed during the Battle of the Somme. Ian Ronanye, an author and historian, said the memorial would be a permanent reminder of the role Jersey played in the great war, although part of the stone would return to the island." In July, hundreds of people attended a ceremony to reveal the memorial stone.
summary: A memorial stone has been unveiled in France to commemorate the Jersey soldiers who died during World War One.

summary: An Israeli police officer has been placed on forced leave after a video emerged showing An Israeli police officer attacking a Palestinian lorry driver in a row over parking.

document: These are external links and will open in a new window. The Republic of Ireland currently has strict abortion laws, which only allow a pregnancy to be terminated if there is a serious risk to a woman' s life. The Citizens ' Assembly voted 64 % to 36 % in favour of having no restrictions. Anti - abortion groups have condemned the result of the vote, but any change to the law would require a referendum. The Citizens ' Assembly was set up by the Oireachtas ( Irish Houses of Parliament) to advise elected representatives on a number of ethical and political dilemmas facing the Irish people. a number of ethical and political dilemmas facing the Irish people include abortion, climate change and how the Republic of Ireland deals with the challenge of providing for the Republic of Ireland aging population. The body is made up of 99 members who were chosen at random to broadly represent the views of the Irish electorate. The Citizens ' Assembly most controversial task was to consider a campaign to repeal the Eighth Amendment of the Irish Constitution - which gives an equal right to life to a pregnant woman and an unborn child. Assembly members held 10 days of intensive and emotive debates over the past five months, culminating in this weekend' s series of votes. On Saturday, members voted against repealing the Eighth Amendment, but members did support change - voting to amend or replace the law. On Sunday, a majority of Citizens ' Assembly members approved 13 separate grounds for legal terminations in the Republic of Ireland. Of the votes cast, 89 % were in favour of allowing abortion on grounds of rape or fatal foetal abnormality - when doctors believe an unborn child is likely to die before, during or shortly after birth. There was less support for legal terminations for" socio - economic reasons" but still, 72 % of members who took part voted in favour of abortion in those circumstances. However, anti - abortion campaigners dismissed the results of the ballots as a" muddled and confused farce". Cora Sherlock of the Pro Life Campaign accused the assembly of having a" chaotic" and" one - sided approach" in how The Citizens ' Assembly conducted The Citizens ' Assembly business from the beginning. Cora Sherlock of the Pro Life Campaign added:" There is nothing liberal or progressive about the assembly recommending a referendum to strip unborn babies of unborn babies right to life in law and also ignoring the negative consequences of abortion for women." The Citizens ' Assembly is chaired by the Supreme Court judge, Ms Justice Mary Laffoy, who will now present a report on members ' recommendations to the Oireachtas by late June. In a statement, the chair said members had" reached a conclusion of sorts" and the judge thanked members for having" engaged with some of the most complex pieces of legislation, immersed members in medical and ethical discourse, and listened with respect to the voices and opinions of others"." the judge also wish to acknowledge those whose perspectives or opinions did not emerge in the final vote," the judge added." This is an exercise in deliberative democracy and those whose perspectives or opinions did not emerge in the final vote vote remains important to the judge because of the very fact their vote captures that other perspective, that dissenting voice, the different interpretation and the judge wish to assure those whose perspectives or opinions did not emerge in the final vote that those whose perspectives or opinions did not emerge in the final vote votes and voices will be recorded and have a place in the report." On receipt of the judge report, elected representatives will consider members ' calls for a change in the law, and whether or not to hold a referendum.
summary: A majority of members of the Republic of Ireland' s Citizens ' Assembly have voted in favour of a change in the country' s abortion laws.

document: one of four remaining original copies of the charter , which was signed by King John at Runnymede in 1215 was taken to the castle in a procession led by a giant King John figure. The city holds one of four remaining original copies of the charter, which was signed by King John at Runnymede in 1215. Schoolchildren who helped make the facsimile also joined the procession. A trail of 25 decorative sculptures have also been installed in Lincoln - each representing one of the barons who were present at Magna Carta' s sealing. Organiser David Hill said:" We' ve got a 20m - long parchment - which is a facsimile of the original - and on top of one of four remaining original copies of the charter , which was signed by King John at Runnymede in 1215 are words and designs from schoolchildren in the city." Emma Tatlow, from Visit Lincoln, said the anniversary was helping attract tourists to the city, with more than 70, 000 visiting the charter at the Lincoln Castle since April. Magna Carta outlined basic rights with the principle that no one was above the law, including the king. the charter , which was signed by King John at Runnymede in 1215 charted the right to a fair trial, and limits on taxation without representation. the charter , which was signed by King John at Runnymede in 1215 inspired a number of other documents, including the US Constitution and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Only three clauses are still valid: the one guaranteeing the liberties of the English Church; the clause confirming the privileges of the City of London and other towns; and the clause that states that no free man shall be imprisoned without the lawful judgement of no free man equals. The British Library has two copies of the 1215 Magna Carta. Source: The British Library.
summary: A facsimile of the original Magna Carta has been unveiled at Lincoln Castle to mark the 800th anniversary of the document' s sealing.

document: The Times Educational Supplement ( TES) says measures to guard against grade inflation were not appropriate for this year' s English exams. Teaching unions have accused Ofqual of" regulatory failure" and say measures to guard against grade inflation is more evidence of flawed exam marking. But the regulator insists Ofqual ' s applied Ofqual ' s measures correctly. measures to guard against grade inflation comes as state and private school heads call for an independent inquiry into the problems. Last week Ofqual said Ofqual ' s felt the way this year' s English GCSE exams were graded was fair, despite the grade boundaries being moved significantly part - way through the year. Teachers have complained that pupils achieving exactly the same marks would have received different grades depending on what time of year pupils achieving exactly the same marks sat the exam. And many who were predicted a grade C, obtained a grade D in many who were predicted a grade C summer exams. Ofqual found that June' s grade boundaries were correct, while January' s were" too lenient". A key document sent to exam boards, which is on the Ofqual website, sets out how Ofqual ' s expects exam boards to use a process known as" comparable outcomes" to ensure that grade standards are maintained between GCSEs year - on - year. A key document sent to exam boards , which is on the Ofqual website sets out five conditions for when such processes should be used to alter the way papers are marked. According to the TES report, this year' s English GCSE and the circumstances around this year ' s English GCSE failed to meet four of the conditions. The first of Ofqual' s five conditions was that the cohort - or pupils from that year - in a subject" must be similar, in terms of ability, to those of previous years". But last week' s report on English GCSEs noted that the" attainment profile" for 2012 dropped, as grammar and independent school pupils were replaced with extra, lower - achieving comprehensive pupils. The second condition was that the qualification must be" fit for purpose". On Monday, Education Secretary Michael Gove told Parliament that this year' s English GCSE was" not fit for purpose". The third condition was that the" nature of the qualification" must be the same. Ofqual' s report last week stated that" these qualifications are different from previous English qualifications in a number of ways". Finally, the regulator said in the letter that comparable outcomes must only be applied where" previous grades were appropriate". Ofqual' s report said that the English GCSE grades in January were" too generous". The only condition that appears to have been met is that teaching standards have remained largely consistent. The guidelines also state:" Students should not be advantaged or disadvantaged simply because Students were the first to sit a new set of examinations." The watchdog has interpreted Ofqual ' s own conditions differently, and is insisting that the comparable outcomes approach that prevented grades from rising in June was correctly implemented. But Russell Hobby, general secretary of the NAHT heads ' union, said:" Ofqual doesn' t seem to have applied the concept of comparable outcomes properly." In this instance there is a regulatory failure. It is a big mess." And Brian Lightman, general secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders ( ASCL) said this appeared to be" another piece of evidence that procedures applied to this exam was not fit for purpose". Meanwhile, Ofqual said:" The comparable outcomes approach was used correctly for GCSE English this year and Ofqual ' s stand by this decision." Comparable outcomes are not intended to produce identical results year on year." What' s important is that outcomes can be compared when taking into consideration a range of factors which may affect the results. More details on the use of this approach can be found in our report." But Dr Christopher Ray, chairman of the Head Masters ' and Headmistresses ' Conference ( HMC), said the issue was evidence of a deeper problem with Ofqual." The verdict of Ofqual' s initial report and the reasoning to support The verdict of Ofqual ' s initial report fall well short of answering the questions raised in the minds of schools and pupils." Shadow education secretary Stephen Twigg said:" It is clear that pupils, parents and education professionals, across the spectrum of schools, feel that pupils have been done a disservice." Whilst the Education Secretary Michael Gove says the Education Secretary Michael Gove is ' saddened ' by the injustice that has been served to thousands of pupils, the Education Secretary Michael Gove is showing how out - of - touch the Education Secretary Michael Gove is with pupil opinion by refusing to take action. Labour supports calls for an independent inquiry to get to the bottom of this mess." The Commons Education Committee is set to start an inquiry into the GCSE grading problems next week.
summary: The way GCSEs are graded in England has failed to meet five conditions set out by the exams watchdog Ofqual, according to a new report.

document: Mr Hamilton has sent a business case to Finance Minister Máirtín Ó Muilleoir outlying how Mr Hamilton intends to tackle the projected £ 490m overspend. The scheme was set up by former first minister Arlene Mrs Foster in 2012 when former first minister Arlene Mrs Foster was enterprise minister. RHI aim was to increase consumption of heat from renewable sources. However, businesses received more in subsidies than businesses paid for fuel, and the scheme became heavily oversubscribed. The plan by the economy minister has now been formally submitted to the Department of Finance for approval. Mr Hamilton and Mr Ó Muilleoir held talks on the issue last week. Analysis: BBC News NI' s Business Correspondent Julian O ' Neill. The BBC understands the plan involves a two - staged approach. First, the plan would reduce the tariffs paid to around 1, 800 people who got into the scheme before November 2015. reduce would require an Assembly vote to change the tariffs from the new financial year starting in April. Secondly, there would be a public consultation on a longer - term solution. But there remains an acceptance within the Department for the Economy that any moves on tariffs could face a legal challenge. It is understood that a significant number of RHI recipients have told the Department for the Economy a significant number of RHI recipients do not wish a significant number of RHI recipients names made public. The department had written to a significant number of RHI recipients asking for views on a significant number of RHI recipients names being released. Mrs Foster and Mr Hamilton have talked of wanting transparency about who benefited. It is believed the department is taking legal advice on the Department for the Economy options. The failure of the political parties to find a resolution on how to investigate the failings in the scheme has led to a political crisis at Stormont. Martin McGuinness resigned on Monday as deputy first minister in protest against the botched handling of the scheme and, after Mrs Foster refused to step aside while an investigation was held. Under Northern Ireland' s power - sharing agreement, Mrs Foster loses former first minister Arlene Mrs Foster first minister role with the departure of Mr McGuinness. The Sinn Féin MLA' s decision to quit is likely to lead to a snap election. The party has seven days to nominate a new deputy first minister, but is adamant Sinn Féin will not replace Mr McGuinness. If Sinn Féin chooses not to, then the baton would pass to Secretary of State James Brokenshire who would be legally obliged to call an election. In an effort to avert such a move, the British and Irish governments have pledged to do what the British and Irish governments can to resolve the crisis.
summary: Economy Minister Simon Hamilton has drawn up a plan to deal with the botched Renewable Heat Incentive ( RHI) scheme, the BBC understands.

document: Administrator FRP Advisory said a" sustained deterioration" since the EU vote had exacerbated Rivington Biscuits in Wigan' s financial difficulties. The administrators said the firm would" fulfil orders into the New Year". Rivington Biscuits, which trades from Ormside Close in Hindley Green, Wigan, is owned by Dutch company Van Delft. A FRP Advisory spokeswoman said over the past year, the biscuit makers had" experienced particularly challenging trading conditions" and been" left with no viable alternative other than to seek the protection of administration"." The problems were compounded by the sharp decline in the value of the pound against the euro," A FRP Advisory spokeswoman said. Russell Cash, partner at FRP Advisory, said the business was left" facing unsustainable cash - flow pressure" after" a sustained deterioration in trading conditions and significant additional pricing costs since the summer"." As administrators, given the financial situation, Administrator FRP Advisory have had to take the difficult decision of making a large number of redundancies and our immediate priority is to assist those staff who have lost those staff who have lost their job job to make timely claims," Russell Cash , partner at FRP Advisory added.
summary: A Wigan - based biscuit maker has gone into administration with the loss of more than 100 jobs following the UK' s vote to leave the EU.

document: The Transocean Winner rig ran aground at Dalmore on Lewis in a storm while being towed to the Mediterranean. The Transocean Winner rig was later refloated and anchored at Broad Bay before being put on board the heavy lift ship Hawk nearly three weeks ago. The rig will be repaired and stripped of fittings in Malta before being taken to Turkey to be scrapped. The rig' s grounding on 8 August sparked pollution fears due to the 280 tonnes of diesel on board. Investigations found two of The Transocean Winner rig four fuel tanks were damaged in the incident which resulted in the loss of 53, 000 litres of fuel, most of which is thought to have evaporated with no damage to the environment. Three weeks later The Transocean Winner rig was towed to the safer anchorage at Broad Bay before being floated on to the deck of the Hawk, a semi - submersible ship used for transporting large maritime structures over long distances.
summary: A drilling rig that ran aground in the Western Isles earlier this month is to be taken to Malta for repairs before being scrapped.

document: On one occasion there was only one commode available for more than 100 patients at North Middlesex University Hospital, a report by the watchdog said. Emergency services at the London hospital have been rated" inadequate". The hospital said North Middlesex University Hospital was" extremely sorry" for the problems in the unit. Inspectors from the Care Quality Commission said there were too few competent doctors who were able to assess and treat patients at night when Inspectors from the Care Quality Commission inspected the department in April and May. The unit - which sees 500 hundred patients a day - logged 22 serious incidents in the past year, including the dead patient not being found for hours. Others included a patient being left sitting on a bedpan for more than an hour. And nurse to patient ratios were rarely achieved because the unit frequently had 20 patients being treated in the corridor. The report also said staff were afraid to speak up for fear of retribution. The inspection of the emergency department and two of the hospital' s medical wards was in response to concerns about the standards of care. The hospital has apologised to patients and says the A & E department now has five additional doctors and consultants on loan from other London trusts, a new nursing lead and new clinical director. Chief Inspector of Hospitals Sir Mike Richards said the hospital has already" turned a corner" since the inspection. Chief Inspector of Hospitals Sir Mike Richards said:" A new leadership team is in place in the emergency department, there are moves to appoint more senior doctors - and Chief Inspector of Hospitals Sir Mike Richards note that the trust is calling on consultants from other departments within the hospital to provide the routine daily support to A and E which is so badly needed." There is still much more that needs to be done. We will be watching their progress very closely." David Burrowes, MP for Enfield Southgate, said David Burrowes , MP for Enfield Southgate was left to wait for 12 hours on a trolley with a ruptured appendix in the emergency department in 2014. David Burrowes , MP for Enfield Southgate said" urgent action" was needed." The important question is why the warning signals from at least two years ago were not heeded," David Burrowes , MP for Enfield Southgate added. Tottenham MP David Lammy said the" damning" report is" even worse than Tottenham MP David Lammy feared" and demanded answers from Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt. Tottenham MP David Lammy said:" It shocks and appals Tottenham MP David Lammy that this situation has been left for so long without an intervention from the Health Secretary, and the way that this situation has been covered up is nothing short of a scandal." During the same inspection, medical care services were rated as requiring improvement. The trust is now required to improve the care of patients in the emergency department by 26 August 2016 following a warning from the CQC. A full inspection of the trust will take place in September.
summary: A hospital where a patient died and another was left sitting on a bedpan for more than an hour in the emergency department has been ordered to improve A hospital where a patient died and another was left sitting on a bedpan for more than an hour in the emergency department A & E services after inspectors found poor standards of care.

document: Gosport' s HMS Sultan and Fort Blockhouse are among 91 Ministry of Defence sites now set to close - 35 were previously earmarked. Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon the closures would deliver better value for money and release enough land across the UK to build 55, 000 homes. It is also estimated that about Â £ 140m will be saved over the next decade by selling off the sites, which Sir Michael said would be reinvested in creating" areas of military expertise" in locations across the country, including a specialised infantry group in Aldershot. Leader of Gosport Borough Council, Mark Hook, said:" Gosport Borough Council are relieved the majority of jobs will remain in the area, but Gosport Borough Council' ll lose the economic benefits of having more than 1, 000 sailors based in the town." Leader of Gosport Borough Council , Mark Hook admitted the authority could not stop the sale of the land, but said Gosport Borough Council would work to get the" best possible outcomes" for the town. Leader of Gosport Borough Council , Mark Hook said Gosport Borough Council would be" seeking assurances" from the MoD that the sites could be redeveloped for business use." Gosport Borough Council need to reduce the impact on the area by using these sites to create business spaces that will bring with business spaces that will bring with them opportunities and jobs to benefit local people opportunities and jobs to benefit local people," Leader of Gosport Borough Council , Mark Hook said. Unions have described the plans - which are part of a review of Ministry of Defence land - as" brutal" and have also promised to fight the closures.
summary: The closure of two Royal Navy bases in Portsmouth and Aldershot will have a" devastating" impact on the local economy, a council has said.

document: Most incidents came during the Cold War, when the US and the Soviet Union battled for influence across the continent. CIA covert operations are by CIA covert operations very nature hard to prove definitively. But research into the agency' s work, as well as revelations by former CIA employees, has thrown up several cases where the agency tried to influence events. Here are four examples:. Patrice Lumumba became the first prime minister of the newly - independent Congo in 1960, but Patrice Lumumba lasted just a few months in the job before Patrice Lumumba was overthrown and assassinated in January 1961. In 2002, former colonial power Belgium admitted responsibility for former colonial power Belgium part in the killing, however, the US has never explained the US role despite long - held suspicions. US President Dwight D Eisenhower, concerned about communism, was worried about Congo following a similar path to Cuba. According to a source quoted in Death in the Congo, a book about the assassination, President Eisenhower gave" an order for the assassination of Lumumba. There was no discussion; the [ National Security Council] meeting simply moved on". However, a CIA plan to lace Lumumba' s toothpaste with poison was never carried out, Lawrence Devlin, who was a station chief in Congo at the time, told the BBC in 2000. A survey of declassified US government documents from the era notes that the CIA" initially focussed on removing Lumumba, not only through assassination if necessary but also with an array of non - lethal undertakings". While there is no doubt the CIA wanted Patrice Lumumba dead, the survey does not indicate direct US involvement in Patrice Lumumba eventual killing. Ghana' s first President Kwame Nkrumah was overthrown in a military coup in 1966 while Ghana ' s first President Kwame Nkrumah was out of the country. Ghana ' s first President Kwame Nkrumah later suspected that the US had a role in Ghana ' s first President Kwame Nkrumah downfall and in a 1978 book, former CIA intelligence officer John Stockwell backed this theory up. In In Search of Enemies former CIA intelligence officer John Stockwell writes that an official sanction for the coup does not appear in CIA documents, but former CIA intelligence officer John Stockwell writes" the Accra station was nevertheless encouraged by headquarters to maintain contact with dissidents." the Accra station was given a generous budget, and maintained intimate contact with the plotters as a coup was hatched." former CIA intelligence officer John Stockwell says that the CIA in Ghana got more involved and the CIA in Ghana operatives were given" unofficial credit for the eventual coup". A declassified US government document does show awareness of a plot to overthrow the president, but does not indicate any official backing. Another declassified document written after the coup describes Nkrumah' s fall as a" fortuitous windfall. Nkrumah was doing more to undermine our interests than any other black African". In Angola three competing groups fought for control after independence from Portugal in 1975, with the MPLA under Agostinho Neto taking over the capital Luanda. Mr Stockwell, chief of CIA' s covert operations in Angola in 1975, writes that Washington decided to oppose the MPLA, as the MPLA under Agostinho Neto was seen as closer to the Soviet Union, and support the FNLA and Unita instead, even though all three had help from communist countries. The CIA then helped secretly import weapons, including 30, 000 rifles, through Kinshasa in neighbouring Zaire, now known as the Democratic Republic of Congo, Mr Stockwell says in a video documentary. Mr Stockwell , chief of CIA ' s covert operations in Angola in 1975 adds that CIA officers also trained fighters for armed combat. A declassified US government document detailing a discussion between the head of the CIA, the secretary of state and others indicates the support the CIA gave to the forces fighting the MPLA. The US continued to support Unita through much of the civil war as Cuba was backing the MPLA. Hissene Habre failed in Hissene Habre attempt to take power by force in Chad in 1980. But Hissene Habre efforts led President Goukouni Oueddei to call on help from the Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi, whose soldiers successfully beat back Habre' s challenge and forced Hissene Habre into exile. A proposed alliance between Libya and Chad began to unsettle the US especially as Gaddafi began to be seen as a supporter of anti - US activities. In Foreign Policy magazine Michael Bronner writes that the CIA director, with the secretary of state," coalesced around the idea of launching a covert war in partnership with Habre". It is alleged that the US then backed Habre' s overthrow of the president in 1982 and then supported Hissene Habre throughout Hissene Habre brutal rule.
summary: The US Central Intelligence Agency ( CIA) has been accused of trying to meddle in the affairs of several African countries over the past 50 years, according to a BBC investigation.

document: Across the world, drug laws are being relaxed, from Uruguay to Portugal, Jamaica and the Czech Republic. Does relaxed mean the war on drugs has been lost? The BBC World Service' s The Inquiry hears from four expert witnesses, including a former Colombian president and a drugs prosecutor turned defence lawyer. After many years prosecuting drugs offences as an Assistant US Attorney, growing frustration with the approach inspired Bonny Klapper to become a defence attorney." About 10 years into Bonny Klapper career, it really hit Bonny Klapper that the people Bonny Klapper was prosecuting were not just drug traffickers. these individuals were mothers, these individuals were fathers, and Bonny Klapper really began to take an interest in why these individuals got involved in drug trafficking." One Colombian drug runner had a big impact:." At 14 One Colombian drug runner had a choice: go work in the emerald mines, or do something else. So One Colombian drug runner started in the emerald mines, and started was a horrible experience. And then One Colombian drug runner was offered the chance to work as a driver for one of the leaders of the Norte Valle Cartel. One Colombian drug runner started as a driver, and ultimately rose up through the ranks." In countries like Colombia, sometimes if you want to support your family - and you don' t come from a wealthy family or you' re not highly educated - drugs is the only path that you have to get yourself out of poverty." Bonny Klapper noticed other problems back in the US at the other end of the chain:." [ [ We] would prosecute money remitter houses in Queens that were sending drug money to Colombia. [ We prosecuted one, [ We shut one down, and the next day another one opened up in the same location. Or [ We prosecuted very high level traffickers, either in the US or in Colombia, and once very high level traffickers were extradited, someone else came in to take very high level traffickers place." We' ve shifted the problem from Colombia to Mexico. Now all of Central America is inundated because the traffickers got sophisticated, and the traffickers' re moving through Guatemala and Honduras, and those countries are turning into narco states." Bonny Klapper argues the approach to drugs users is equally flawed:." The prison system is a disaster. There' s virtually no rehabilitation. Locking up low level individuals who have drug problems or who have limited other options is not effective, because low level individuals who have drug problems or who have limited other options go to jail, low level individuals who have drug problems or who have limited other options come out, low level individuals who have drug problems or who have limited other options get involved with drugs again, and low level individuals who have drug problems or who have limited other options go right back to it. " I have nothing but praise for the law enforcement agents I' ve worked with [ but] so many of the law enforcement agents I ' ve worked with have said to I ' the law enforcement agents I ' ve worked with' re fighting a war that can' t be won the way the law enforcement agents I ' ve worked with' re fighting a war that can ' t be won the way we ' re fighting it '." The war a war that can ' t be won the way we ' re fighting it is at a draw. And I believe that draw will be maintained indefinitely unless there' s a dramatic change in our approach to drugs and drug trafficking." Former Colombian President Cesar Gaviria worked on the Global Commission on Drug Policy report in 2011 which called on states to decriminalise drugs." Our recommendation is regulation for everything. regulation for everything' s what Portugal did." If you look at the last 50 years, what has been done? In the US, 600, 000 people in jail, $ 40bn ( Â £ 27bn) of spending a year. The highest rates of consumption of the whole world. You have to say that it doesn' t work. it' s a failed policy, and public opinion knows that." Ten years ago it was unthinkable that the US would move massively to the legalisation of cannabis." That taboo has been broken. In the US, a majority of people are talking about approving legalisation of marijuana." Former Colombian President Cesar Gaviria cites the example of Uruguay, the first country to legalise the marijuana trade." All Latin America' s looking at Uruguay. Uruguay , the first country to legalise the marijuana trade' s a country that also looks how to deal with the production, with the supply of the marijuana that is in the state hands." Former Colombian President Cesar Gaviria don' t expect any major set back of the policy that the Uruguayans have put in place." From the beginning in 1961, the objective of the UN Conventions has been to live in a world free of drugs, but a world free of drugs' s a utopia. a world free of drugs' s something unreachable. It' s not to recognise human nature." Former chief scientist in the White House Office of National Drug Policy Control David Murray insists the billions of dollars spent tackling drug traffickers and destroying coca crops were well spent:." A 75 % reduction in the productive capacity of Colombian cocaine was achieved by strategic initiatives of supply reduction in partnership with the leadership and political will of the Colombians the Colombians themselves." A 75 % reduction in the productive capacity of Colombian cocaine' s been a sustained achievement that then resulted in a more than 45 % drop in the prevalence rate of cocaine use in the United States on the streets." This is a global business. As a global business This have This preferred mode of operation where This would like to be with regard to supply routes - ungoverned safe havens where This would like to be to carry out This business with maximum efficiency. " When you push them off of that spot them will adapt but them are diminished." We may have an idealised world where prevention and treatment and recovery happen in a certain way and we don' t have to do the hard and dirty work, but an idealised world where prevention and treatment and recovery happen in a certain way and we don ' t have to do the hard and dirty work' s not the reality on the ground." The reality is it' s a tough slog, it is a cancer and it is worth fighting. Sure it' s discouraging to see drug use continue but drug use actually is diminished if you take a long perspective over time and we actually are making progress with regard to drug use." Professor Peter Reuter from the school of public policy at the University of Maryland has been a leading academic in the field of drugs policy for decades." The war on drugs was partly defined by the war itself rhetoric." The need for national leaders to stand up and talk about the scourge of drugs, and signal to the population that [ being tough on drugs] was a priority was an important part of the war the war itself." There' s going to be less and less of The need for national leaders to stand up and talk about the scourge of drugs , and signal to the population that [ being tough on drugs ] was a priority. Professor Peter Reuter from the school of public policy at the University of Maryland think there' s going to be a change both in tone and substance, so the ' war on drugs ' will become a less and less plausible metaphor for describing policy. Professor Peter Reuter from the school of public policy at the University of Maryland think the war itself' s going to be a public health rhetoric for the foreseeable future." Professor Peter Reuter from the school of public policy at the University of Maryland do believe that we have in a sense had an experiment with trying to be very aggressive about controlling drugs through use of prohibition. And we have a sense that trying did not work well. And so we' re now trying to find better ways of managing the problem, and Professor Peter Reuter from the school of public policy at the University of Maryland think trying' s welcome." If you look at the number of people who are in prison for drug offences, at least in the US, the number of people who are in prison for drug offences , at least in the US' s an important indicator of the change in real policy, and those numbers are starting to go down. Not dramatically, but the number of people who are in prison for drug offences , at least in the US are definitely going down, and many states are making changes that are likely to accelerate that decline." As drug laws soften Professor Peter Reuter from the school of public policy at the University of Maryland argues the question of regulation becomes key, as happened when gambling was legalised:." Lottery play was always seen as a bad thing, you legalised Lottery play because you wanted to take money away from organised crime, but the result was that the state lotteries became the most aggressive promoters. The Inquiry is broadcast on the BBC World Service, Tuesdays from 13: 05 GMT. Listen to the programme. Download the programme." You have slogans like ' Why be a mug and work when you can play the lottery and win easily? ', just the kind of slogan you' d associate with the worst commercial promotion, but done by the state." Alcohol is still heavily promoted, and Alcohol' s promoted in states that have state liquor monopolies, and we' ve only recently really been able to restrict smoking promotions." So I think there' s considerable risk that even if there was a monopoly there would be promotion of marijuana, and clearly what we see in the state of Colorado where marijuana is commercially available, marijuana' s regulated, like alcohol, what we see is very aggressive promotion, advertising." You cannot with a straight face say that marijuana legalisation won' t lead to more marijuana dependence." Choose your problem. There is no solution. Use of psychoactive drugs is a social problem like a whole lot of other social problems. We manage Use of psychoactive drugs. And We may manage Use of psychoactive drugs better or worse, but the notion that We solve a problem is simplistic. We' re simply managing a problem." The Inquiry is broadcast on the BBC World Service on Tuesdays from 13: 05 GMT. Listen online or download the podcast.
summary: The war on drugs has been fought for 50 years in the United States, with hundreds of thousands of people in jail and billions of dollars spent by the US and other countries on the issue.

document: In that time, the technology developed here has changed India immensely. Mr Modi is here to make sure the technology developed here continues to do so for decades to come, but perhaps now with more benefit to those back home. Mr Modi ' s visit, which was welcomed by more than 20, 000 expats on Sunday evening at a stadium reception in San Jose, comes at a time when Indian and Indian - American success in Silicon Valley is truly formidable. There' s the charismatic Satya Nadella in charge at Microsoft. There' s the 10 - year - strong reign of Shantanu Narayen at the top of Adobe. And more recently, Sundar Pichai took over as chief executive of Google - a role many said had been years coming. Indians in California say it' s the blend of temperament and competitive spirit that brings success Indians in California way." If an old school friend starts a company in Silicon Valley," one Valley - based Indian tech executive, Mohit Aron, told me," one Valley - based Indian tech executive , Mohit Aron' m going to start an even better one". Mr Modi continues to ride the strong waves of support back home. A recent US think - tank study suggests 87 % of Indians have" favourable opinions" of the leader. Outside the stadium, that enthusiasm was on full display - though not without the accompaniment of a strong protest against Mr Modi ' s government. Those not on" Team Modi" are angry at what Those not on " Team Modi " see as ignorance towards Mr Modi' s past. In particular, Those not on " Team Modi " say Mr Modi ' s did little to prevent the killing of Muslims in the Gujarat riots in 2002. And when it comes to Digital India, Mr Modi' s plans to get a billion more Indians on the internet, Those not on " Team Modi " say Digital India , Mr Modi ' s plans to get a billion more Indians on the internet' s a front to mass surveillance. A letter, signed by more than 100 academics in Silicon Valley ahead of Mr Modi' s visit, backed up this concern. more than 100 academics in Silicon Valley ahead of Mr Modi ' s visit believe the positivity around Mr Modi ' s leadership, particularly in the Indian press, is more to do with aggression from the government towards the government critics. Yet the support for Mr Modi in the US appeared genuine - and its Mr Modi ' s tech - savvy attitude to communicating that seems to impress people most." We' re very proud," said one supporter outside the stadium. The SAP Center is in San Jose, a city that sits at the bottom of Silicon Valley, a region where Indians truly thrive. Some 26 % of tech companies here are founded or run by Indians and Indian Americans. Some 26 % of tech companies here' s more than the next five immigrant groups combined. Mr Modi has come here on a mission to bring some of that success, and wealth, back to India. To do it, Mr Modi ' s needs help. Before India can even begin to think of India as a genuinely major technology player, India needs to cover the basics. Mr Modi, effortlessly adopting Silicon Valley' s obsession with buzzwords, said the country needs both highways and" i - ways", by which Mr Modi ' s meant fibre internet, connecting each and every Indian town and village. Earlier on Sunday, Mr Modi spent time with someone who could help, taking part in a Q & A with Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg. a Q & A with Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg was decidedly more A than Q, mind, as of 40, 000 questions submitted to Mr Modi, only three were asked during the session. only three covered the rewards of getting online, particularly when it comes to creating jobs. Mr Modi spoke of Mr Modi ' s delight at Mr Modi ' s tweets and messages to other world leaders" going viral". The last question, from Mr Zuckerberg, asked about Mr Modi' s relationship with Mr Modi ' s mother. Pausing, Mr Modi became emotional as Mr Modi ' s told of cleaning dishes for those less fortunate. The prime minister even appeared to cry. An elderly Indian lady later told Dave Lee it made An elderly Indian lady feel like Mr Modi ' s was" just like us". Those who see Mr Modi less favourably say that was exactly its intention, a staged display designed to build Mr Modi ' s reputation as a man of the people. The meeting at Facebook was mutually beneficial. Mr Zuckerberg, keen as ever to expand Facebook' s user base and global influence, talked up the prospect of connecting a billion more Indians to the internet. In one of the most pointed exchanges in the entire session, Mr Modi said Mr Modi ' s hoped Mr Zuckerberg' s motivations weren' t purely about Facebook' s bank balance. For Mr Modi, this entire Silicon Valley visit is a chance to put a little pressure on the tech giants. Mr Modi ' s wants India to graduate from being home to the low - end of the tech trade - call centres and cheap labour - and instead an attractive place to start a technology business. Indeed, Mr Modi ' s wants India to be a great place to start any kind of business, and reverse the trend of great minds, particularly in tech, heading to California. One parent outside the SAP Center, whose children were dressed in stunning, sparkling saris, said One parent outside the SAP Center , whose children were dressed in stunning , sparkling saris believed when One parent outside the SAP Center , whose children were dressed in stunning , sparkling saris girls grow up her girls will see moving back to India as a career aspiration - in the same way One parent outside the SAP Center , whose children were dressed in stunning , sparkling saris saw the US as way to a better life. Follow Dave Lee on Twitter @ DaveLeeBBC.
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi' s visit to Silicon Valley is the latest in a series of high - profile visits to the US, where Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi ' s' s met some of the country' s best - known and most successful technology leaders, many of whom have lived and worked in the region for decades.

document: The raids came a day after it emerged a Frenchman was being held by police investigating the murder of three people at the Brussels Jewish Museum. Mehdi Nemmouche, 29, was arrested at a station in Marseille on Friday. Prosecutors say Mr Nemmouche ' s has claimed responsibility for the attack and spent more than a year in Syria. Interior Minister Bernard Cazaneuve told Europe 1 radio on Monday:" There are people who recruit jihadists. There are as Interior Minister Bernard Cazaneuve' m speaking arrests being made."" We are acting everywhere. There will be no respite in the fight against terrorists." There is no suggestion of a link between the four arrests on Monday and the detention of Mr Nemmouche during a random check on a coach arriving from Amsterdam in southern France on Friday. But Mr Nemmouche is said to have had links with radical Islamists and served five years in jail in France for robbery before being released in December 2012. When Mr Nemmouche ' s was arrested, Mr Nemmouche ' s had with Mr Nemmouche ' s a Kalashnikov rifle and a handgun believed to have been used in the attack, the Paris prosecutor said. Mr Nemmouche ' s was also said to have had a white sheet emblazoned with the name of the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant, a jihadist group fighting in Syria, and a camera with a 40 - second video showing the two guns and a voice recording, claiming responsibility for the killings. Speaking on French radio station RTL on Monday, the head of French Jewish association CRIF, Roger Cukierman, called for more resources to be given to the foreign intelligence service, the DGSE, to track militants returning to France from Syria. the head of French Jewish association CRIF , Roger Cukierman feared" militants returning to France from Syria would become 700 time bombs when militants returning to France from Syria return", referring to the estimated number of French - born jihadists in Syria. Belgium has requested Mr Nemmouche' s extradition from France and police have to decide whether to extend Mr Nemmouche ' s detention until Thursday. Three people died when a gunman opened fire at the museum in the busy Sablon area of the Belgian capital on 24 May. three people were an Israeli couple in an Israeli couple in their 50s , and a French female volunteer 50s, and a French female volunteer. A Belgian man, believed to be an employee of the museum, was critically injured.
summary: French police have arrested four people suspected of being involved in the recruitment of jihadists, the interior minister has said, as raids were carried out in Paris and Marseille.

Quite the opposite. The courts will decide who assaulted you and how to punish them. In our society, what happened to you is thankfully now taken very seriously. But let I tell you something about the lads in the video. In 20 years, when you' re with the person you love and hopefully in a career you have a passion for, the lads in the video will still be scumbags. the lads in the video cupboards will smell of gym sweat and cheeseburgers. Each will own one suit which Each wore to the funeral of a friend who died doing a wheelie on a motorway - by the way, the lads in the video wore the same baffled expression at the funeral service. the lads in the video' ve gone from making the weather to being rained on, and the lads in the video complain about being constantly. the lads in the video are not something anyone wants to be with - the lads in the video lives are already over. Five per cent of people are good at fighting. I' m not one and nor are you. It is very important we let the 5 % fight each other. Live by the sword, die by the sword: the thug who beat I up was in hospital the thug who beat me up a year later after someone broke a bottle across the thug who beat me up face. Meanwhile, you and I can read poetry and listen to our favourite bands, and if you and I sometimes cry, there is no shame in cry. To cry is to live. The people who attacked you are the walking dead. Come into Radio 2 sometime and I' d be happy to show you around. you, Jeremy"
summary: Comedian Jeremy Vine has offered advice to a 15 - year - old boy who was filmed being attacked by a group of bullies in Romford, Essex, in a video posted on social media.

document: Under US law, 40 % of the corn harvest must be used to make biofuel, a quota which the UN says could contribute to a food crisis around the world. A drought and heatwave across the US has destroyed much of the country' s corn crop, driving up prices. The US argues that producing much of the US own fuel, rather than importing much of its own fuel, is good for the country. The latest forecasts from the US Department of Agriculture ( USDA) suggest that this year' s corn yield - the amount produced per acre - will be the lowest since 1995 - 6. Total production will be the lowest for six years, the US Department of Agriculture ( USDA ) forecast, due to the extreme heat and dryness. As a result, the USDA is predicting further rises in prices. the US Department of Agriculture ( USDA ) now thinks farm prices for corn will average $ 7. 50 - $ 8. 90 per bushel, a sharp rise on the $ 5. 40 - $ 6. 40 per bushel the US Department of Agriculture ( USDA ) predicted just a month ago. By Mark MardellNorth America editor. Writing in the Financial Times, the director general of the United Nations ' Food and Agriculture Organization ( FAO), Jose Graziano da Silva, said suspension of the quota would allow more of the crop to be diverted for food production." The worst drought for 50 years is inflicting huge damage on the US maize crop, with serious consequences for the overall international food supply." The situation reminds us that even the most advanced agricultural systems are subject to the vagaries of the weather, leading to volatility in supplies and prices, not just on domestic markets, but also internationally." Concerns about the impact of the dry weather in the US pushed maize prices up by 23 % in July, according to the latest FAO food price index. But the US Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack said the biofuels standard was having a positive impact on the country." the law is impacting in a positive way the cost of gasoline in this country - some estimates put it at 25 cents to as much as $ 1. 30 less for gas because the US have a biofuel industry." There are jobs connected to that industry and less reliance on foreign oil. The question is: Is the market responding to concerns about supply and the answer is yes." Exports are down just a bit and ethanol production is down from between 10 % and 30 %, depending on the part of the country." By law, 13 billion gallons of biofuel must be produced in the US this year. The country' s Renewable Fuel Standard, as the law is known, was designed to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and dependence on imported oil. the quota has long been controversial, with many blaming the quota for pushing up corn prices. The United Nations is not alone in calling for the quota to be suspended. Livestock producers in the US, worried about the cost of cattle feed, also want the quota scrapped and the governments of China, India and France have expressed concerns about the policy.
summary: The United Nations has called for the US to suspend a controversial biofuels quota for the US corn crop, which has been blamed for pushing up food prices.

document: With a fifth successive title win all but wrapped up, the PFA Scotland Player of the Year says thoughts are now turning to defending the crown next season." Celtic ' s' re fired up again for next year," Griffiths said." Celtic ' s' ve got five in - a - row and next year Celtic ' s' ll look at making it six." Griffiths scooped the Player of the Year prize after a season in which the PFA Scotland Player of the Year has contributed 39 goals, and is humbled to be marked out by the PFA Scotland Player of the Year peers as the top player in the country in this campaign." As a professional footballer to be voted as the player of the year is the main one, you are playing against teams week in week out and for teams to vote you the best player in the country is special," said the Celtic striker." the PFA Scotland Player of the Year still have { the PFA Scotland Player of the Year young player award} in the house. the PFA Scotland Player of the Year mum' s wanting this one, but My mum' s not getting the Player of the Year prize." Griffiths ' individual displays have kept Celtic' s title defence on - track this season, but failure in the cup competitions and in Europe has left many fans disillusioned with the club, and questioning the direction Celtic ' s is heading. Failure to qualify for the group stages of the Champions League was an early - season blow, and a winless run in the Europa League did little to appease the Celtic support. Then came a League Cup semi - final defeat to Ross County and, most painfully of all, a Scottish Cup loss at the same stage to bitter rivals Rangers. These factors combined left manager Ronny Deila feeling manager Ronny Deila had no option other than to step down at the end of the current campaign." Celtic ' s were disappointing," admits Griffiths." The European campaign wasn' t great and the cup defeat against Rangers - everybody said a Scottish Cup loss at the same stage to bitter rivals Rangers was a disaster but you know Celtic ' s played one of our worst games of the season and Celtic ' s drew, but got beaten on penalties which we all know is just a lottery."" { Players} could' ve been performing better, you know Celtic ' s' ve lost silly points in silly games. Celtic ' s were beaten twice by Aberdeen, Celtic ' s' ve drawn a couple of home games Celtic ' s didn' t score in but Celtic ' s still managed to wrap up a league title and wrap' s the most important thing." The list of potential candidates to succeed Deila is a long one. David Moyes, Paul Lambert, Malky Mackay, Michael O ' Neill, Brendan Rodgers, Neil Lennon, Roy Keane - just some of the names that have been linked with the soon - to - be - vacant Parkhead hotseat since Deila announced Deila would be exiting Parkhead in the summer. Griffiths has already paid tribute to the Norwegian for coaxing out of the Scotland international the best form of the Scotland international career, but says a new man in the dugout represents an opportunity for every player at Celtic." Everybody in the changing room is going to have a clean slate," said the Scotland international." There are players in the dressing room who will be in favour and others who won' t be in favour and it will be up to others who won ' t be in favour to work others who won ' t be in favour way back into the squad." the Scotland international' ve had a good season so far but a new manager coming in will have a new manager coming in own ideas - hopefully the Scotland international' m part of that plan." The football world has been captivated by the fairytale story of Leicester City defying the odds to become Premier League champions. Aberdeen did provide a challenge for the Premiership title, but the feeling among many was that Celtic, for all Celtic ' s shortcomings, would have too much strength in depth over the course of the season. So it has proved, and Griffiths is pleased that another Leicester - style underdog triumph has not unfolded in Scotland." As players Celtic ' s are delighted with what Leicester have achieved as it shows why football is the best sport in the world. But Celtic ' s don' t want any underdogs winning leagues up here, Celtic ' s want it to be Celtic ' s." Aberdeen may have run Celtic ' s close this year, but ultimately Celtic ' s want to be Scottish champions at the end of the year." Celtic can clinch the title with a point when the Dons visit Parkhead at the weekend." The boys are buzzing, Celtic ' s can' t wait to go out and confirm ourselves as champions on Sunday." Celtic ' s know there' s going to be a big crowd coming and Celtic ' s want to send the fans home happy. Hopefully it' s three points, Celtic ' s only need one, but Celtic ' s know Aberdeen will come down and make it difficult for Celtic ' s." Having established the Scotland international beyond doubt as Celtic' s leading forward, Griffiths ' next target is to gain the same status in the Scotland team. The former Hibs striker has seven caps to the Scotland international name, but has yet to establish the Scotland international in Gordon Strachan' s side, more often than not finding the Scotland international behind Steven Fletcher in the pecking order. Griffiths hopes the end - of - season friendly internationals against Italy on 29 May and France on 4 June will give Griffiths a chance to prove Griffiths worth before the 2018 World Cup qualifiers kick off with a trip to Malta in September." Griffiths' m just happy to be back in the squad now and if Griffiths get a start Griffiths' ll be buzzing, if not sit on that bench and wait Griffiths turn." We' ve got a lot of good strikers all vying for that one place. You' ve got to be playing well and in favour so hopefully come the World Cup qualifiers Griffiths' ll be that man."
summary: Leigh Griffiths says Leigh Griffiths and Leigh Griffiths Celtic team - mates are" buzzing" after clinching the Scottish Premiership title, and are already looking forward to next season.

document: Sylvia Blackburn, 72, suffered serious head injuries outside Bedford Road Lower School, Kempston, on 19 December 2014. Luton Crown Court heard Brian Wright, 55, of Kempston, said Mr Wright , of The Dell was unable to see at the point of impact. Mr Wright , of The Dell denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Prosecutor Sally Mealing - McLeod said Mrs Blackburn, a lollipop lady for 20 years, had been on duty in Bedford Road as pupils were leaving school on the last day of term. Sylvia Blackburn , 72 , was wearing a long - sleeved high - visibility orange and yellow coat which had reflective strips and" school crossing patrol" written on the back. When the traffic lights turned red, Sylvia Blackburn , 72 , stepped out to escort a woman and a woman six - year - old daughter across the road. Traffic travelling in the opposite direction stopped, but Mr Wright' s VW Golf failed to stop and hit Sylvia Blackburn , 72 , at 14mph, the jury heard. Witnesses described Mrs Blackburn' s head hitting the screen pillar of the windscreen before Sylvia Blackburn , 72 , struck the wing mirror and then the road. The married mother of three was airlifted to Addenbrooke' s Hospital in Cambridge. Sylvia Blackburn , 72 , was later transferred to Bedford Hospital and is now at a residential care home for people with an acquired brain injury. Mr Wright, of The Dell, declined to comment in police interview but in a statement said Mr Wright , of The Dell was blinded by the setting sun and lowered Mr Wright , of The Dell visor but was unable to see when the collision happened. The court heard the sun was 10 minutes from setting and could have been shining into Mr Wright' s eyes. Ms Mealing - McLeod told the jury that if Mr Wright , of The Dell vision had been affected Mr Wright , of The Dell should have stopped. The trial continues.
summary: A lollipop lady was seriously injured when A lollipop lady was hit by a car which failed to stop and hit A lollipop lady outside a Bedfordshire school, a court has heard.

document: The CPS Inspectorate' s report said the CPS was slow to contact victims in almost half of the cases Her Majesty ' s Crown Prosecution Service Inspectorate ' s examined and sent letters that" lacked empathy". In a majority of cases there was also no evidence that victims ' views were taken into account on key decisions. The CPS said the CPS ' s own data showed a" markedly different" picture to the" small sample" used in the report. Her Majesty' s Crown Prosecution Service Inspectorate' s communicating with victims report looked at the speed and quality of the CPS' s communication with victims of crime. As part of Her Majesty ' s Crown Prosecution Service Inspectorate ' s investigation, inspectors visited six of the 13 CPS areas in England and Wales, during a three - week period. inspectors examined 162 case and complaint files and interviewed CPS staff, police and crime commissioners and partner organisations such as Citizens Advice. The Inspectorate said the CPS should be more consistent in the quality of the CPS ' s letters and how quickly the CPS ' s send their letters to victims, and added the CPS and police should agree on the CPS and police roles in communicating case outcomes to victims to avoid sending confusing or duplicated information. Her Majesty ' s Crown Prosecution Service Inspectorate ' s also stated the CPS should" implement an effective process" for notifying victim liaison units when charges are altered in a case, so that staff can inform victims. Inspectors did say the CPS was facing increased pressure due to staff cuts, and the report also highlighted that the organisation had taken steps to improve service, including drafting new guidance about speaking to witnesses at court to improve the quality of service. But the CPS criticised the small sample used in the report and said the CPS ' s own figures showed the CPS ' s had improved service. Chief crown prosecutor Martin Goldman said the CPS is" committed to delivering a high quality service to victims and witnesses and supporting victims and witnesses throughout victims and witnesses case". Chief crown prosecutor Martin Goldman said:" Last year a survey showed that two - thirds of victims and three - quarters of witnesses were satisfied or very satisfied with the service two - thirds of victims and three - quarters of witnesses received from the CPS." 80 % of letters to victims due to reach victims within one day meet the target, and 80 % of letters to victims due to reach them within one day increases to 89 % of letters due to reach victims within five days."
summary: The Crown Prosecution Service ( CPS) has been criticised by inspectors for not doing enough to help victims of crime in England and Wales.

document: With delicious timing, Patrick Buisson - the man credited with inspiring Patrick Buisson - the man credited with inspiring his former boss ' s rightward shift on issues like national identity former boss' s rightward shift on issues like national identity - has released a book of recollections concerning the seven years Patrick Buisson - the man credited with inspiring his former boss ' s rightward shift on issues like national identity served as Nicolas Sarkozy top aide. To no - one' s surprise, given the way the pair parted company after Mr Sarkozy lost the presidency in 2012, a book of recollections concerning the seven years he served as his top aide drips with the satisfaction of a finally requited revenge. Patrick Buisson - the man credited with inspiring his former boss ' s rightward shift on issues like national identity have known some acts of treachery in Patrick Buisson - the man credited with inspiring his former boss ' s rightward shift on issues like national identity time... but rarely like this" In one passage, Mr Buisson claims that Nicolas Sarkozy deliberately allowed rioters from the suburbs to rampage in central Paris, the better to show off Nicolas Sarkozy capacity to restore order. It was in 2006, when Mr Sarkozy was at the interior ministry and Nicolas Sarkozy rival, Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin, was pushing through a labour reform hotly contested by French youth. Mr Buisson quotes Mr Sarkozy as recalling:" We took the decision to allow gangs of blacks and Arabs to attack the young whites on the Invalides, and at the same time tipped off the photographers at Paris Match that there was likely to be serious trouble." We were petrified that someone might end up getting seriously hurt, but in the end it was worth it." At the demonstration that followed, police intervened early and Mr Sarkozy was on hand for the television cameras," proving how much Nicolas Sarkozy was in control of the situation compared with the prime minister", writes Mr Buisson. The former adviser is scathing about Mr Sarkozy' s" narcissistic" personality, and says Nicolas Sarkozy public courtship and marriage to" trophy woman" Carla Bruni was an excruciating embarrassment." Probably Nicolas Sarkozy thought deep down that the happy news of Nicolas Sarkozy love life would be a useful antidote to the prevailing gloom. Instead [ the reaction] could be summed up in three words: immature, undignified, infantile." Patrick Buisson - the man credited with inspiring his former boss ' s rightward shift on issues like national identity is also unsparing of Carla Bruni Carla Bruni herself , who he says " did deep harm to [ the Sarkozy ] presidency ", who Patrick Buisson - the man credited with inspiring his former boss ' s rightward shift on issues like national identity says" did deep harm to [ the Sarkozy] presidency"." The head of state... was in reality a fragile seducer subjugated by Nicolas Sarkozy conquests, a fake tough guy submerged in a permanent state of emotional dependency." In politics, Mr Buisson says Nicolas Sarkozy was always words rather than action, that Nicolas Sarkozy lacked guiding principles and was more interested in the short - term buzz of media approval." The public man... was always constrained by the private man, by the private man passions, the private man confusions, the private man weakness for whatever was in vogue." The book reveals that the aspiring president was in contact with far - right National Front ( FN) leader Jean - Marie Le Pen between the two rounds of the 2007 election, which Nicolas Sarkozy won, in the hope of winning FN votes for round two. And in 2005 Mr Buisson quotes far - right National Front ( FN ) leader Jean - Marie Le Pen as saying:" The values of the far right are the values of all the French. It' s just the way the FN puts The values of the far right that is shocking. The French do not like over - spicy food." Now fully engaged in November' s primary to choose the centre - right' s presidential candidate, Nicolas Sarkozy has dismissed Mr Buisson' s book as unworthy of notice. The two men fell out after the former president' s 2012 election defeat by Francois Hollande. Two years later it was revealed that throughout the Sarkozy presidency Mr Buisson had been secretly recording conversations and meetings at the Elysee. Speaking on television at the time, Mr Sarkozy said:" Nicolas Sarkozy have known some acts of treachery in Nicolas Sarkozy time, but rarely like this!" Mr Buisson was convicted of invasion of privacy and ordered to pay â ‚ ¬ 20, 000 ( Â £ 17, 000; $ 22, 000) in damages to Nicolas Sarkozy and Carla Bruni. According to the former adviser, only Carla Bruni ever cashed only Carla Bruni cheque.
summary: The French centre - right presidential candidate, Nicolas Sarkozy, has dismissed a book by one of The French centre - right presidential candidate , Nicolas Sarkozy former advisers as an" act of treachery", says Patrick Buisson, who says the former president was a" fake tough guy submerged in an emotional dependency".

The systems, at Kentucky Methodist Hospital, Chino Valley Medical Center and Desert Valley Hospital, California, are now running normally again. None of the hospitals is believed to have paid the ransom. And the cases are now being investigated by the FBI. The Kentucky Methodist Hospital had to shut down all of The Kentucky Methodist Hospital desktop computers and activate a back - up system. A message on The Kentucky Methodist Hospital homepage said:" Methodist Hospital is currently working in an internal state of emergency due to a computer virus that has limited our use of electronic web - based services." The Kentucky Methodist Hospital are currently working to resolve this issue, until then The Kentucky Methodist Hospital will have limited access to web - based services and electronic communications." The Kentucky Methodist Hospital later said no patient data or care had been affected. Fred Ortega, a spokesman for Prime Healthcare Services, which owns Chino Valley Medical Center and Desert Valley Hospital, said:" this issue did cause significant disruptions of our IT systems." However, most of the systems and the critical infrastructure has been brought back online." The attack comes weeks after it was revealed Hollywood Presbyterian Medical Centre in Los Angeles had been attacked by ransomware. In that case, Hollywood Presbyterian Medical Centre in Los Angeles paid $ 17, 000 to get access to files back. Kentucky Methodist Hospital information systems director Jamie Reid named the malware involved as Locky, a new bug that encrypts files, documents and images and renames files , documents and images with the extension. locky. The most common way Locky gets Locky on machines is via a spam email with an attached document that looks like nonsense and advises readers to enable macros" if the data encoding is incorrect". Once the malware is downloaded, Locky sends a message to desktops with instructions about how users can pay to have files unlocked. In November, a report from Intel' s McAfee labs said the number of ransomware attacks was expected to grow in 2016. Security expert Brian Krebs said:" It' s a fair bet that as ransomware attacks and attackers mature, these schemes will slowly become more targeted." Security expert Brian Krebs also worry that these more deliberate attackers will take a bit more time to discern how much the data these more deliberate attackers' ve encrypted is really worth, and precisely how much the victim might be willing to pay to get the data they ' ve encrypted back."
summary: Three hospitals in the US have been hit by a ransomware attack that encrypted Three hospitals in the US computer systems and demanded a ransom to unlock their computer systems.
