Known as the" Hi Buddy" email because of the way The final message greeted an al - Qaeda operative, The final message reads:" I met with Nadia family and we both parties have agreed to conduct the nikah after the 15th and before 20th of this month. I have confirmed the dates from Nadia family and Nadia family said you should be ready between these dates." The jury was told female names, including Nadia, represented different ingredients used to make bombs. Wedding, or ' nikah ', was a standard al - Qaeda code for a terror attack. To see each entrance of the Arndale Centre being photographed … photographed was clearly a means by which they would brief the would - be attackers as to what the would - be attackers would see as the would - be attackers made the would - be attackers approaches." Police think the first target would have been the Arndale Centre, which had been rebuilt following the IRA bomb attack on Manchester in 1996. Lord Justice Pitchford' s inquiry at the Royal Courts of Justice will look into police infiltration of political and social justice groups in England and Wales since 1968. The inquiry is expected to be split into three parts: establishing what happened, examining the procedures adopted by police to prevent wrongdoing, and recommendations for the future. Preliminary hearings are due to start in the autumn and the inquiry is set to last three years. The inquiry' s terms of reference include:. The allegations were first widely reported in 2011 when a former undercover officer, Mark Kennedy, offered to help defend, in court, six environmental campaigners whom a former undercover officer , Mark Kennedy had infiltrated. That trial collapsed - and later the same year, there were further revelations of undercover relationships, one of which led to a child. By Dominic Casciani, BBC home affairs correspondent. The allegations of wrongdoing by undercover police officers that have emerged since 2011 have been extraordinary. That steady stream of stories has led to the launch of a major public inquiry into undercover police officers activities. The breadth and nature of what is being alleged is almost too big to grasp, but it fundamentally comes down to a simple question of whether elements of the police were out of control. Seven key issues the inquiry will examine. Metropolitan Police Commissioner Sir Bernard Hogan - Howe said undercover policing was an important tactic, but had to be done legally. summary: An inquiry into claims police spied on political and social justice groups in England and Wales for more than 50 years is likely to" expose both creditable and discreditable conduct", Lord Justice Pitchford has said.

document: Mr Kasyanov, a former prime minister, is a high - profile critic of Russian President Vladimir Putin, in the opposition RPR - Parnas party. Ramzan Kadyrov : Putin ' s key Chechen ally . has close ties to Mr Putin, who encouraged Ramzan Kadyrov : Putin ' s key Chechen ally . to stamp out a separatist insurgency in Chechnya. Thousands of civilians died in the North Caucasus republic when Russian troops fought the rebels there in the 1990s. The new video is the latest in a series of threatening messages from Mr Kadyrov against Kremlin critics, whom Ramzan Kadyrov : Putin ' s key Chechen ally . accuses of working for the West. the video shows Mr Kasyanov talking to Vladimir Kara - Murza, a journalist who runs the pro - democracy opposition movement Open Russia. The movement was launched by exiled oligarch Mikhail Khodorkovsky. The video was posted late on Sunday and has more than 16, 000" likes". Mr Kasyanov says Mr Kasyanov , a former prime minister sees the video as a direct death threat and will demand a criminal investigation. Ilya Yashin, who co - chairs RPR - Parnas with Mr Kasyanov, called the video" an open threat to murder Kasyanov". Another opposition leader, anti - corruption campaigner Alexei Navalny, echoed that view. On Facebook, Mr Navalny said ( in Russian)" there is no longer any doubt that all such statements in recent weeks and specifically this one were approved by Putin and the Kremlin, and quite probably were inspired by Putin and the Kremlin too". The BBC' s Sarah Rainsford in Moscow says they key question now is whether Mr Kadyrov is acting on Ramzan Kadyrov : Putin ' s key Chechen ally . own initiative. One theory discussed on Russian social media is that Ramzan Kadyrov : Putin ' s key Chechen ally . is being used by the Kremlin to intimidate the Kremlin critics - particularly as growing economic problems raise the potential for protest. Others suggest that Mr Kadyrov is becoming a dangerous loose cannon - a regional leader who believes Ramzan Kadyrov : Putin ' s key Chechen ally . is untouchable, our correspondent reports. The phrase" Whoever doesn' t get it will get it!" is the title of a thriller that Mr Kadyrov says Kadyrov the Instagram fan has filmed, starring Kadyrov the Instagram fan as a machine gun - toting all - action hero. Kadyrov the Instagram fan - by Stephen Ennis, BBC Monitoring:. Ramzan Kadyrov is one of Russia' s most popular and controversial Instagram users. Since launching Kadyrov the Instagram fan account in 2013, Kadyrov the Instagram fan has made over 6, 000 posts and amassed 1. 6m followers. Kadyrov the Instagram fan promotes Kadyrov the Instagram fan on the site as a devout Muslim and a strong leader. One recent post featured Kadyrov the Instagram fan grappling with a crocodile. This is not the first time Kadyrov the Instagram fan has used Instagram to lash out at the Russian opposition. In May 2015, hours after the premiere of an Open Russia film about Kadyrov the Instagram fan, Kadyrov the Instagram fan posted a clip of Kadyrov the Instagram fan firing a machine gun, with the slogan" Whoever doesn' t get it will get it soon!" The following day Open Russia co - ordinator Vladimir Kara - Murza was taken seriously ill with poisoning. Instagram has rapidly grown in popularity in Russia in recent years and at the end of 2015 had more than 10m active users.
summary: Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov has posted a video on Instagram, in which Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov threatens to kill a Russian opposition leader, Andrei Kasyanov, who is due to appear in the European Parliament next week.

document: Inspector Harold Stephens said the County Plan, which will be the blueprint for development in County Durham for the next 20 years, was" unrealistic and flawed". County Durham now have no choice but to pursue this matter through the courts by way of a Judicial Review." In the plan, the county council said County Durham wants to build 31, 400 homes and create thousands of jobs over the next 20 years, in a bid to attract more businesses and people to the area. But Mr Stephens said the plan was" unsound" and assumptions about job growth were" very ambitious".
summary: A plan to build 31, 400 homes and create thousands of jobs will be challenged in court after a planning inspector said A plan to build 31 , 400 homes and create thousands of jobs was" unrealistic and flawed".

document: The University and College Union says the 1. 1 % rise offered by the universities is" an insult". But the Universities and Colleges Employers Association said the walkout was" disappointing given the very good pay offer". Unions representing university support staff are balloting on the offer, with strike action possible in the autumn. UCU says The University and College Union members have suffered a real - terms pay cut of 14. % since 2009 and complains the squeeze on staff salaries has come as university leaders enjoyed hefty increases." A 1. 1 % pay offer is an insult to hardworking staff, especially in light of the 5 % pay rise vice - chancellors have enjoyed while holding down staff pay," said general secretary Sally Hunt." Industrial action which impacts on students is never taken lightly, but members feel that members have been left with no alternative." If the employers wish to see a swift end to this dispute, and avoid further disruption, the Universities and Colleges Employers Association need to come back to the table with a much - improved offer." Summer exams are still running at some universities, though many have finished. A spokesman for the employers anticipated only" minor impact and minimal student disruption"." Even for examinations which are still taking place at some higher education institutions, more than nine out of 10 report that a no to low impact is anticipated," said the spokesman." the Universities and Colleges Employers Association would like to see the UCU consulting The University and College Union members on the final offer." The employers say the offer is" at, and, for some, beyond, a limit of affordability for higher education institutions and the very best offer that will be available this year". the Universities and Colleges Employers Association maintain the weighting of the offer means the worst paid university staff will get a rise of more than 5 %. the Universities and Colleges Employers Association say the Universities and Colleges Employers Association have also offered talks on zero - hours contracts and on improving lower pay for female academics. But UCU says The University and College Union rejected the 1. 1 % offer as the very good pay offer was only a marginal improvement on the original 1 % on which The University and College Union had balloted members. Ballots of university support staff represented by Unison and Unite are also under way on the improved offer, with both unions recommending the very good pay offer be rejected. Any action would take place during the autumn term, said a Unison spokeswoman. UCU is planning strike rallies in:. Staff are also working to contract from Wednesday - refusing to set extra work, cover for absent colleagues or work overtime.
summary: Universities in England and Wales are to stage a one - day strike on Wednesday in a dispute over pay, in a row over the size of a pay rise.

document: Judges said Mr Hart and Mr Holmstrom ' s work laid" an intellectual foundation" for policies in areas such as bankruptcy legislation and political constitutions. The pair will receive 8 million Swedish krona ( Â £ 744, 652) from the committee. Mr Hart, who was woken with the news at 4. 40am, said Mr Hart , who was woken with the news at 4 . 40am first reaction had been to hug Mr Hart , who was woken with the news at 4 . 40am wife and wake Mr Hart , who was woken with the news at 4 . 40am younger son. Mr Holmstrom said Mr Holmstrom , aged 67 , felt" very lucky" and" grateful". The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences said that Mr Hart and Mr Holmstrom' s work was" valuable to the understanding of real - life contracts and institutions". The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences also said The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences could identify" potential pitfalls in contract design." Working separately, the two created tools to help determine whether public sector workers should receive fixed salaries or performance - based pay, and whether providers of public services should be publicly or privately owned. Mr Holmstrom in particular is known for Mr Holmstrom , aged 67 , research into how contracts and incentives affect corporate behaviour. The former Nokia board member declined to say whether Mr Holmstrom , aged 67 , thought executive pay was too high these days, but commented:" Mr Holmstrom , aged 67 , personal view is that [ top executives ' contracts] are too complicated today." Mr Holmstrom, aged 67, is a professor of economics and management at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, while Mr Hart, born in 1948, is an economics professor at Harvard University in the US. The pair saw off competition from the World Bank' s new chief economist Paul Romer, who was widely tipped to win. New York University' s Stern Business School, where Prof Romer teaches, sparked controversy last Thursday when New York University ' s Stern Business School , where Prof Romer teaches , accidently published a press release naming the World Bank ' s new chief economist Paul Romer , who was widely tipped to win as the winner. New York University ' s Stern Business School , where Prof Romer teaches , quickly took down the release, saying New York University ' s Stern Business School , where Prof Romer teaches , was only preparing for a possible win. Others believed to be the running included Olivier Blanchard, a former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, and Edward Lazear, a fellow at the Hoover Institution, Stanford University. The economics prize is the only Nobel not created by Alfred Nobel, and was instead launched in 1968, long after the philanthropist' s death. To date Americans have dominated the award, with 55 of the 76 laureates holding US citizenship, including those with dual nationalities. Last year Scottish - born economist Angus Deaton won the prize for Scottish - born economist Angus Deaton use of data to investigate income inequality and inform economic policy. the prize is the fifth Nobel to be announced this year, after prizes for physiology or medicine, physics, chemistry and peace were awarded last week. The Nobel prize for literature will be awarded on Thursday.
summary: US economist Gary Hart and Swedish - born economist Carl Holmstrom have won the Nobel prize for economics for US economist Gary Hart and Swedish - born economist Carl Holmstrom work on public sector contracts.

document: The Scottish government has already drafted legislation for a referendum after Nicola Sturgeon said another ballot was highly likely in the wake of the UK voting to leave the EU. But Ms Sturgeon told STV News that any referendum would not been held in 2017. Nicola Sturgeon predecessor, Alex Salmond, has predicted a vote on independence will be held in the autumn of next year. Ms Sturgeon said:" There is not going to be an independence referendum in 2017, Nicola Sturgeon don' t think there is anybody who thinks going is the case." Nicola Sturgeon has previously said a vote on independence will be held if the Scottish government concludes a vote on independence is the only way to protect Scotland' s place in Europe. Ms Sturgeon has urged the UK government to negotiate a so - called soft Brexit and retain the UK government membership of the single market. Failing that, Nicola Sturgeon wants a special arrangement to allow Scotland to stay in the single market even if the rest of the UK leaves. The first minister' s latest comments regarding the timing of a second referendum follow Nicola Sturgeon insistence at the weekend that Nicola Sturgeon is not bluffing on calling a re - run of the 2014 ballot if Scotland' s position is ignored. But Nicola Sturgeon has also indicated that a soft Brexit could take the issue off the table in the short - term. Ms Sturgeon told BBC One' s Andrew Marr Show:" ourselves in Scotland have to ask ourselves in Scotland are ourselves in Scotland happy to have the direction of our country, the kind of country Scotland ' s want to be, determined by a right - wing Conservative government perhaps for the next 20 years, or do ourselves in Scotland want to take control of our own future?"" That' s the case that in those circumstances, Nicola Sturgeon think, it would be right for Scotland to have the opportunity to decide." Asked if Nicola Sturgeon was looking at a referendum" much quicker" than in five or 10 years ' time if there was a hard Brexit, Nicola Sturgeon said:" Nicola Sturgeon would think, yes. But let Nicola Sturgeon not get away from this point, Nicola Sturgeon' m putting to Theresa May a compromise solution." Scottish Conservative leader Ruth Davidson said ruling out an independence referendum this year was an" empty gesture" by Ms Sturgeon. Accusing the first minister of" leaving Scotland in limbo", Ms Davidson added:" If Nicola Sturgeon' s serious about allowing Scotland to move on from constitutional navel - gazing, Nicola Sturgeon should ditch Nicola Sturgeon draft referendum bill immediately." Scottish Labour deputy leader Alex Rowley said:" While it is welcome that Nicola Sturgeon has ruled out another independence referendum in 2017, ruled doesn' t come close to ending the uncertainty. " The first minister should rule out forcing another independence referendum on the people of Scotland altogether, not just for the next twelve months." But the Scottish Greens welcomed the Scottish government ' commitment to keeping a second referendum on the table. Co - convenor Patrick Harvie said:" This cannot be a quiet time ahead for supporters of independence; although the Brexit negotiations will take two years, work must begin now to build support and strengthen our case."
summary: Scotland' s first minister has ruled out an independence referendum in 2017, saying there is" no one who thinks an independence referendum in 2017 is the case".

document: The vote in the St Louis suburb is the first since the death of Michael Brown last August led to protests. A federal investigation found racial bias in the Ferguson police department was widespread. Two - thirds of Ferguson' s residents are black and now half the council. Shortly after the results came out, a video emerged showing an unarmed black man being shot dead by a police officer in South Carolina. State investigators said the officer, Michael Slager, would be charged with murder after the video showed the officer , Michael Slager firing at Walter Lamer Scott who was running away. Turnout in Ferguson increased from 12 % at the last elections, in 2013, to 29 %. Wesley Bell, who defeated another black candidate in Ferguson' s third ward, said:" This community came out in record numbers to make sure our voices were heard." When you have a community engaged, the sky is the limit." A drive by activists to register new voters and encourage previously disenfranchised residents to vote appeared to have paid off." People in general want to see change," Ferguson Mayor James Knowles told the Reuters news agency. Ella Jones defeated another black candidate and two white candidates in Ferguson' s first ward to become the first black woman on the council. Black residents in Ferguson protested for several days last August after Mr Brown was shot dead by St Louis police officer Darren Wilson. The protests spread nationwide in November when it was announced that Mr Wilson, who has since left the police, would not be charged. US police have faced severe criticism from rights groups in the wake of Mr Brown' s death, with a series of high - profile deaths of unarmed black men in police custody.
summary: Black voters in the US city of Ferguson have elected Black voters in the US city of Ferguson first black council members since a black teenager was shot dead by a white police officer last year.

document: PM Viktor Orban said Hungary would not allow migrants to leave Hungary territory without registering. PM Viktor Orban comments came as Hungarian authorities opened the main rail station in Budapest to hundreds of migrants after a two - day stand - off. One train left, but then stopped near a migrant reception centre. Migrants mostly from Syria but also from Iraq, Pakistan and Afghanistan resisted efforts by police to get Migrants mostly from Syria but also from Iraq , Pakistan and Afghanistan off the train at Bicske, about 40km ( 25 miles) west of Budapest. Some were banging on the windows and shouting" Germany, Germany." Follow our live updates. EU rules place responsibility for assessing asylum claims on the country where a migrant first arrives. Many of the migrants currently in Hungary have been refusing to register there, in order to continue Many of the migrants currently in Hungary journeys to Germany before seeking asylum. Nothing illustrates how difficult this crisis is to resolve than what has happened to these several hundred refugees who are currently on this train at Bicske. Migrants mostly from Syria but also from Iraq , Pakistan and Afghanistan jumped on the train after waiting at Budapest station for three hours. Migrants mostly from Syria but also from Iraq , Pakistan and Afghanistan were really tightly crammed in - women and babies. Migrants mostly from Syria but also from Iraq , Pakistan and Afghanistan were told no international trains would leave. but eventually Migrants mostly from Syria but also from Iraq , Pakistan and Afghanistan were told this train would leave and Migrants mostly from Syria but also from Iraq , Pakistan and Afghanistan believed and hoped this train would take Migrants mostly from Syria but also from Iraq , Pakistan and Afghanistan close enough to the Austrian border to get across. There were some police on board. We got as far as Bickse and when the train pulled in, there were loads of police waiting for Migrants mostly from Syria but also from Iraq , Pakistan and Afghanistan on the platform. The plan seemed to be to remove Migrants mostly from Syria but also from Iraq , Pakistan and Afghanistan, to take Migrants mostly from Syria but also from Iraq , Pakistan and Afghanistan to a centre where Migrants mostly from Syria but also from Iraq , Pakistan and Afghanistan would be properly identified. Some people left the first carriage, but almost immediately there was resistance, a lot of people were banging on the windows, some were shouting" Germany! Germany!" The police put on riot gear. And then there was one really distressing scene involving a woman who was carrying a baby by the railway tracks shouting" help! help!" There was a struggle involving one of her companions and riot police. This incensed some of the other refugees who had been taken off the train, some of the other refugees who had been taken off the train began pushing and jostling and there was a little bit of fighting with the riot police. And then some of the other refugees who had been taken off the train forced some of the other refugees who had been taken off the train way back on the train, which is where we are at the moment with police on the platform with several hundred refugees on the train in sweltering conditions. International services from Budapest' s Keleti station were suspended indefinitely. There have been days of tension at the station. The number of migrants entering Europe has reached record levels this year. Germany expects to take in 800, 000 asylum seekers this year - four times last year' s total. The surge in numbers has created tension and disagreement over EU migration policy. Germany has been prepared to accept large numbers of asylum seekers, but other countries have not. Mr Orban, who heads the anti - immigration Fidesz party and was in Brussels for talks, said Hungarians and other Europeans were" full of fear" because" Hungarians and other Europeans see that the European leaders, among the European leaders the prime ministers, are not able to control the situation". During a tense press conference with European Parliament President Martin Schulz, the Hungarian leader said that" nobody would like to stay in Hungary, neither in Slovakia nor Poland nor Estonia." All of them would like to go to Germany," Mr Orban , who heads the anti - immigration Fidesz party and was in Brussels for talks said." Our job is only to register All of them." Mr Schulz countered:" What we are seeing for the time being is egoism instead of common European sense." To say ' yeah, you know we have refugees all over in Europe but refugees want to go to Germany and therefore we are not concerned ' is effective, but wrong. And therefore European Parliament President Martin Schulz think we need a fair and just distribution." European Council president Donald Tusk said on Thursday that EU countries should accept at least 100, 000 asylum seekers between EU countries, a sharp increase on a previous European Commission target of 40, 000. EU states instead so far committed to sharing some 32, 000 asylum seekers from Italy and Greece. Mr Tusk also took Mr Orban to task for comments in which the Hungarian leader said Mr Orban , who heads the anti - immigration Fidesz party and was in Brussels for talks country was being" overrun" with refugees who threatened to undermine Europe' s Christian roots. European Council president Donald Tusk said:" Referring to Christianity in a public debate on migration must mean in the first place the readiness to show solidarity and sacrifice." The human cost of the crisis was also put into sharp focus on Wednesday when five children were among 12 migrants who drowned in Turkish waters while trying to reach Greece. Images of the washed - up body of a three - year - old boy, who died alongside a three - year - old boy , who died alongside his mother and five - year - old brother mother and five - year - old brother, circulated widely on social media. Czech unease at migrant numbering. Five obstacles to an EU migrants deal. Those who risk everything for a better life. The word migrant is defined in the Oxford English Dictionary as" one who moves, either temporarily or permanently, from one place, area, or country of residence to another". A refugee is, according to the 1951 Refugee Convention, any person who" owing to a well - founded fear" of persecution is outside their country of nationality and" unable" or" unwilling" to seek the protection of that country. To gain the status, one has to go through the legal process of claiming asylum. The word migrant has traditionally been considered a neutral term, but some criticise the BBC and other media for using a word some say implies something voluntary, and should not be applied to people fleeing danger. Battle over words to describe migrants.
summary: Riot police have clashed with hundreds of migrants trying to get off a train near the Hungarian capital, Budapest, after hundreds of migrants trying to get off a train near the Hungarian capital , Budapest , after they tried to enter the country without registering tried to enter the country without registering.

document: Kieran McGrath, 26, was shot after leaving the Sheldon Arms pub in Ashton - under - Lyne on 4 October 2014. Mr McGrath ' s drove to a police station but died later. The man who orchestrated Mr McGrath ' s killing, Anthony Henry, 32, was found guilty of murder on Friday. Troy Beckford, 24, and Jace Smith, 31, were convicted after a trial at Liverpool Crown Court. The jury was unable to agree in the case of two other men, Remi Adams, 34 and Scott Chapman, 27, also charged with murder. Mr Adams was found not guilty of possessing ammunition without a certificate. A woman, Bretony Gallimore, 24, was found guilty of assisting an offender. The gun used to kill Mr McGrath was the same gun used to kill Manchester shopkeeper Pragaret Singh three weeks later. Police believe the firearm was passed between criminals. Mr McGrath was shot after leaving the pub at about 22: 25 BST. Anthony Henry had tracked Mr McGrath' s Audi S3 and watched Mr McGrath ' s movements on an iPad, the trial heard. After being shot, the 26 - year - old drove away from the scene to a nearby police station but died after collapsing near the front door. Mr McGrath ' s died from a single gunshot wound, a post - mortem examination found. No witnesses to the attack have come forward.
summary: Two men have been found guilty of murdering a man who was shot dead after leaving a pub in Greater Manchester.

document: Mr Pistorius says Oscar Pistorius ' s mistakenly shot Oscar Pistorius ' s girlfriend Reeva Steenkamp through the door, believing his girlfriend Reeva Steenkamp was a burglar, then broke the door down with the bat. The prosecution says Oscar Pistorius ' s tried to beat down the door and then fired the gun. Mr Pistorius denies intentionally killing Ms Steenkamp in February 2013. Forensic expert Police Colonel Johan Vermeulen also said Colonel Johan Vermeulen , a decorated forensic expert in the South African Police Service ( SAPS ) thought Mr Pistorius had hit the door with the bat from a low angle, indicating Oscar Pistorius ' s was not wearing Oscar Pistorius ' s prosthetic legs at the time. By Pumza FihlaniBBC News, Pretoria. A big day in the Oscar Pistorius murder case. The defence worked tirelessly to disprove a finding by Colonel Johan Vermeulen, a decorated forensic expert in the South African Police Service ( SAPS). Oscar Pistorius' s toilet door stood obtrusively in the courtroom, held up by a white frame, behind Oscar Pistorius ' s toilet door a toilet cubicle. Col Vermeulen, a state witness, told the court that based on the marks on the door and the marks on the door level Mr Pistorius was on Oscar Pistorius ' s stumps when Oscar Pistorius ' s struck the door with a cricket bat. The defence strongly challenged Colonel Johan Vermeulen , a decorated forensic expert in the South African Police Service ( SAPS ) version, adding that Mr Pistorius ' defence team will present Mr Pistorius ' defence team own expert witness who will prove Mr Pistorius was in fact wearing Oscar Pistorius ' s prosthetics. Defence lawyer Barry Roux also introduced another dimension to the case, suggesting that the police recklessly handled the crime scene - Defence lawyer Barry Roux pointed to police shoe prints on the door. The forensics from the scene are a make or break for either side. Mr Roux' s plan seems to include discrediting the integrity of the evidence collection process. Defence lawyer Barry Roux has already hinted at the possible contamination of the crime scene, placing the SAPS under a rather embarrassing spotlight. This contradicts the athlete' s claim that Oscar Pistorius ' s had been wearing Oscar Pistorius ' s artificial limbs. Correspondents say whether or not the athlete was on Oscar Pistorius ' s prosthetic limbs is important because it could match parts of Oscar Pistorius ' s story that Oscar Pistorius ' s accidentally shot Ms Steenkamp, or expose inconsistencies in his story that he accidentally shot Ms Steenkamp. The damaged toilet door, with four bullet holes, was examined in the courtroom along with a replica of the toilet cubicle. Forensic evidence on the location from which shots were fired, how shots were grouped and shots trajectory were presented to the court on Wednesday. Cross - examining, Mr Pistorius ' defence team asked forensic expert Col Vermeulen to kneel and lift Colonel Johan Vermeulen , a decorated forensic expert in the South African Police Service ( SAPS ) feet, which caused Colonel Johan Vermeulen , a decorated forensic expert in the South African Police Service ( SAPS ) to wobble. The defence team claimed that Mr Pistorius therefore would not have been able to balance on Oscar Pistorius ' s stumps and break down the door using a cricket bat. Defence lawyer Barry Roux also alleged that police had contaminated the crime scene by stepping on the door. Col Vermeulen argued that if Mr Pistorius was balanced enough to fire a gun, Oscar Pistorius ' s could also break down a door with a bat. The forensics expert argued that the angle and location of the marks on the door suggested that the marks on the door had been caused by someone much shorter than Mr Pistorius '. The defence team argued that a mark on the bottom of the door showed where Mr Pistorius had tried to kick open the door using Mr Pistorius ' prosthetic legs. Col Vermeulen agreed that tried was possible." The marks on the door are actually consistent with Mr Pistorius ' not having Mr Pistorius ' legs on and Col Vermeulen suspect the marks on the door must be similar to the height that Mr Pistorius ' was when Mr Pistorius ' fired the shots," Col Vermeulen told the court. The prosecution argues that Mr Pistorius hit the door with the cricket bat before the shots were fired, but the defence claims it was the other way round. The trial is now halfway through The trial second week. Earlier on Wednesday, a friend of Mr Pistorius claimed that the star had driven at 200 km / h ( 124mph) and that a friend of Mr Pistorius had taken a picture of the speedometer to prove driven. The defence team alleged that Darren Fresco was a friend of Mr Pistorius driving at the time and had therefore fabricated evidence. On Tuesday, Mr Pistorius ' defence team questioned a pathologist' s finding that Mr Pistorius ' girlfriend had eaten less than two hours before Mr Pistorius ' killed Ms Steenkamp , a 29 - year - old model , and reality TV star. a pathologist ' s finding that his girlfriend had eaten less than two hours before he killed her contradicts the athlete' s account that the pair had been in bed for several hours before the shooting. The state is seeking to convince the court that Mr Pistorius and Ms Steenkamp, a 29 - year - old model, and reality TV star, had an argument before the athlete fired the shots that killed Ms Steenkamp , a 29 - year - old model , and reality TV star. There are no juries at trials in South Africa, and Mr Pistorius ' fate will ultimately be decided by the judge, assisted by two assessors. If found guilty, the 27 - year - old, a national sporting hero dubbed the" blade runner", could face life imprisonment.
summary: South African athlete Oscar Pistorius hit a toilet door with a cricket bat before South African athlete Oscar Pistorius fired the shots that killed South African athlete Oscar Pistorius girlfriend, a forensics expert has told South African athlete Oscar Pistorius murder trial in Pretoria.

document: These are external links and will open in a new window. The call came after" significant human remains" were found at the site of a former home in the Republic of Ireland. The home was run by the Bon Secours order of nuns in Tuam, County Galway. The bodies ranged from premature babies to three year olds. The discovery was made as part of an investigation into claims by a local historian that up to 800 babies and young children died at the home and were buried in unmarked graves. Amnesty International has said that archaeological surveys should be carried out at all former mother - and - baby homes in Northern Ireland. Archbishop Martin said many in the church and society were" ashamed" of what had emerged at the home in Tuam. Archbishop Martin added that" families are owed an apology" and that the Church had repeated an apology the Catholic Church made in 2014 when the claims" first came to light"." It makes Archbishop Martin feel awful. Archbishop Martin feel incredibly sad in recent days. We as a Church do not want to repeat the awful mistakes of the past." Archbishop Martin added:" It' s an appalling time for the Catholic Church and everyone in society." We' re opening up a whole chapter in the society in Ireland and the rest of the world where there was a terrible stigma against unwed mothers." There was a terrible time, we in society and in the Church isolated and stigmatised unwed mothers." Meanwhile, the Irish children' s minister Katherine Zappone has said that 474" unclaimed infant remains" from mother - and - baby homes were transferred to medical schools between 1940 and 1965. Irish national broadcaster RTÃ ‰ made claims about the transfer of remains in a 2011 documentary. Ms Zappone told the DÃ ¡ il ( Irish parliament) that the transfer of remains was" part of a tapestry of oppression, abuse and systematic human rights violations that took place all over this country for decades". the Irish children ' s minister Katherine Zappone also said an interim report into the home in Tuam would be published by the end of March, a move Archbishop Martin said the Catholic Church supported.
summary: The Catholic Church should apologise to the families of unwed mothers who died at mother - and - baby homes, the Archbishop of Dublin, Rowan Martin, has said.

document: Have the media lost interest? Is it a question of chronic political fatigue? Are our brains simply not wired to think long - term? The BBC World Service' s The Inquiry hears from four expert witnesses. Max Boykoff founded the Media Climate Change Observatory a decade ago." the Media Climate Change Observatory monitor 50 sources around the world across 25 countries on six continents. the Media Climate Change Observatory seek to put our fingers on the pulse of the ebbs and flows of coverage of climate change over time, month to month." the Media Climate Change Observatory' s not an exhaustive reading of all media accounts everywhere around the globe across all platforms, but rather is a way to get us talking productively." In 2004 there were relatively low levels of coverage. Around 2006, into 2007 there was an uptick. There was a high water mark in 2009 [ at the time of the UN Climate Change Conference in Copenhagen]." From that high water mark to 2014, coverage has dropped: 36 % globally; 26 % in the US; and as much as 55 % in the UK." Within the last year here in the United States, National Public Radio reduced National Public Radio environment reporting team from three to one reporter." We see examples of reduced unfolding quite regularly. There' s certainly newsroom pressures. There' s shrinking time to deadline, there' s reduced resources to cover complex issues such as climate change that require a certain level of investigation, a certain level of familiarity with the contours and the nuances of the topics." Jennifer Morgan is the Global Director of the climate change programme at the World Resources Institute." Copenhagen was supposed to be the moment when over 190 countries came together and agreed a new legally binding agreement to address climate change. It was very much a great excitement and anticipation of trying to finally get a global agreement after the Kyoto years." Jennifer Morgan remember walking in with a colleague of Jennifer Morgan, and saying ' Okay, we have to do it. we have to get it done, these moments don' t happen very often '." But it soon became clear that negotiations weren' t going to plan:." In the middle of the second week normally what happens is the options start to get narrowed down, and you can see the package emerging. That wasn' t happening, and that' s when we all started to get very concerned." China' s chief negotiator was barred by security for the first few days, sessions were routinely suspended in the name of finishing on time, developing countries said developing countries were ignored, and the EU was missing from a final meeting where a last - minute, non - binding deal was drawn up." It was terrible. [ We felt] an exhausted defeat, just a deep fatigue, particularly from the European side, of just wanting to take a break. The personal sacrifice - it sounds crazy - but believing and trying to make something happen, I think it was a trauma, just to put so much blood, sweat and tears into it." Right after Copenhagen, there was a sense that there needed to be a bit of a time out on the world leaders ' side of things. So it definitely went into a very low level of attention for a few years. The relationships of some of the Heads of State after Copenhagen were quite strained." Even months after, it was almost like [ some of the Heads of State] had been being psychologically burned by this." That' s had a real impact on the willingness of these individuals to stay engaged." Environmental psychologist Robert Gifford researches why even those who accept a link between human behaviour and climate change are reluctant to act." Our brain physically hasn' t developed much for about 30, 000 years. At that time ourselves were mostly wandering around on the Savannah, and our main concerns were very immediate: feeding ourselves right now, worrying about anybody who might try to take our territory. There was very little thinking about what might happen in five years, 10 years, or 100km away." We still have this same brain. Obviously We' re capable of planning, but the kind of default is to stick into the here and now, which is not very good for thinking about climate change, which is a problem that, for many people, is more in the future and farther away, or at least we think climate change , which is a problem that , for many people , is more in the future and farther away , or at least we think it is is." [ And] as any advertiser knows, if you don' t change your message people will just tune out. And so environmental numbness is ' yes, I' ve heard that message before '. We' re always open to new messages, and paying more attention to new messages. So if governments or policymakers repeat the same message too often, people just tune out after a while." We also tend to tune out when we feel helpless:. The Inquiry is broadcast on the BBC World Service on Tuesdays from 13: 05 GMT. Listen to the programme. Download the programme. " ' What can I do about this global problem? I' m just one person, and there' s 7 + billion people on the planet. I just don' t have much control over this global problem, so therefore I' m not going to do much about this global problem, because I contribution, even if I did everything, wouldn' t make much difference. '" Most of us who are trying to do something about this global problem have realised, for example, that the polar bear metaphor is not a great one. Yes, we have some sympathy for this poor polar bear, but it' s not close enough to our own lives." Uncertainty is a really big problem. We' ve learned in my own laboratory from experimental evidence that when people feel a bit uncertain about an environmental problem - if the future temperature might vary from a half a degree increase to a one and a half degrees increase - people will say ' well, it' s probably only going to be a half a degree increase, so people' ll keep flying to some tropical place '." It' s a natural human tendency to interpret information in a way that suits our personal interests. Joe Smith teaches geography at the Open University and argues the narrative around climate science must evolve." Joe Smith' m not sure that people need to engage with climate change at all. climate change' s more or less unreportable if you just describe climate change on the page. climate change' s complex, interdisciplinary, the findings drip out over time, and the boundary between science and policy and politics is a very messy one. climate change' s a real challenge for the media." The idea that we will mobilise any more people with fear messaging is wrong. Joe Smith think we' ve knocked at the door of everyone that might respond to such a thing, but you' ve also got to ask whether it' s an accurate way of telling the science. Joe Smith think it is more respectful to the nature of the science to say that the science' s one of humanity' s most ambitious questions." There was a tactical wrong turning in suggesting that by insisting that the debate is over, we can move onto the action. It somehow implied that the science was complete, and implied, of course, left lots of space for those people who have arguments about the actions on climate change to stand in the way of us having a proper public conversation about those actions because those people who have arguments about the actions on climate change were able to pick apart minor details in the science." It' s not just that climate science isn' t finished, the science' s actually unfinishable. " The rest of science - particle physics, cosmology - is allowed to be rather saucy. I would love to get to the point where we allow climate change science to simply be interesting, enchanting even, as fascinating as any area of science because climate change science' s a hugely ambitious and compelling mission." If you want to talk to a business person, you talk about energy security for a business person business or energy security for a business person nation. If you want to talk to a parent at the school gate, you talk to a parent at the school gate about the health of a parent at the school gate child, a parent at the school gate experience of the trip to school - wouldn' t a parent at the school gate be happier walking and cycling?" Talking about climate change doesn' t have to involve ' talking about climate change ' to lead us to some really substantial actions." We don' t need to wear a climate change t - shirt." The Inquiry is broadcast on the BBC World Service on Tuesdays from 13: 05 GMT. Listen online or download the podcast.
summary: The UN climate change conference in Copenhagen in 2009 was supposed to be the moment when world leaders came together and agreed a new legally binding agreement to address climate change, but The UN climate change conference in Copenhagen in 2009 turned out to be a failure.

We went from 30 - 40 meaderies making mead to somewhere in the vicinity of 250 in the last 10 years," Vicky Rowe , the owner of mead information website GotMead says." Vicky Rowe , the owner of mead information website GotMead like to say that everything old is new again - people come back to what was good once." Even visitors to Mr Alexander' s meadery agree. Tour participant Dirk Heseman admitted that while Maine Mead Works was the first meadery Tour participant Dirk Heseman' d actually visited, Tour participant Dirk Heseman has noticed that mead" is becoming more and more available - similar to cider". Just this year, commercial meaderies in the US have banded together to form an industry group, the American Mead Makers Association, to better share information and encourage growth in the industry. But there' s a lot of work that needs to be done to improve the image of a drink long associated with Renaissance fairs and medieval re - enactments." Mr Alexander think our number one challenge as an industry is awareness of what mead is," says Mr Alexander." You ask 10 people in a room if 10 people in a room' ve ever heard of mead, and two of 10 people in a room might say, ' yes ', and only one of 10 people in a room has had a very positive experience." The mead of the past was often sweet, and didn' t appeal to many drinkers who were just looking for something good to pair with food. But mead has since changed." People don' t realise that just because [ mead ] has honey in [ mead ], [ mead] doesn' t need to be sweet," says Ms Rowe, citing the proliferation of not only dry meads but also meads flavoured with fruits, herbs, and spicy peppers. Yet hampering efforts towards building mead awareness is also the name mead the word. Technically, mead is classified as wine by the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau, which regulates alcohol sales and labelling in the US. classified means that mead has to be labelled as" honey wine", which doesn' t help combat people' s perception of the drink as being as cloyingly sweet." How do people recognise it as mead if you can' t say the word?" says Ms Rowe. Ironically, the alcoholic beverage that most credit with the resurgence of the mead business is beer. The craft brewing movement, which was recently singled out in a report by the Atlanta Federal Reserve as a source of job growth, inspired many home brewers to expand many home brewers repertoire." Brad Dahlhofer of B Nektar meadery in Detroit , Michigan was a home brewer, and at first Brad Dahlhofer of B Nektar meadery in Detroit , Michigan liked mead because Brad Dahlhofer of B Nektar meadery in Detroit , Michigan had never had mead," says Brad Dahlhofer of B Nektar meadery in Detroit, Michigan." Every home brewer has the same dream of, ' Hey what if Every home brewer could sell this? Wouldn' t sell be great? '" Brad Dahlhofer of B Nektar meadery in Detroit , Michigan says. After Brad Dahlhofer of B Nektar meadery in Detroit , Michigan spent months making batch after batch of mead, perfecting Brad Dahlhofer of B Nektar meadery in Detroit , Michigan recipe, Brad Dahlhofer of B Nektar meadery in Detroit , Michigan realised that mead was" kind of an untouched category", and that no - one, at least back in 2008, was really doing mead commercially. So when Brad Dahlhofer of B Nektar meadery in Detroit , Michigan and Brad Dahlhofer of B Nektar meadery in Detroit , Michigan wife, Kerri, were both laid off of he and his wife , Kerri jobs in Detroit' s car industry during the recession, he and his wife , Kerri decided to take the plunge. Now, B Nektar is one of the biggest, if not the biggest, US meadery, shipping 1, 100 cases a week across the country. But for Mr Dahlhofer and Mr Dahlhofer fellow mead enthusiasts, that' s just the beginning." If you look at craft beer 25 years ago, craft beer had 1 % of the total beer market, and now craft beer have 8 %," says Maine Mead' s Mr Alexander." So we' ve got a long way to go, but Maine Mead ' s Mr Alexander feel like it' s got the opportunity because of the diversity of the beverage." You' ve got a canvas with very few limits."
summary: The mead of the past was often sweet, and didn' t appeal to many drinkers who were just looking for something good to pair with food, but the popularity of mead in the US has led to a resurgence in interest in the alcoholic beverage.

document: Assistant nurse Emilie Telander, 26, cheers as one of the day patients at Svartedalen' s elderly care home in Gothenburg manages to roll a six in a game of Ludo. But Ms Telander ' s smile fades as Ms Telander ' s describes Ms Telander ' s own luck running out at the end of the year, when after 23 months of six - hour shifts, Ms Telander ' s was told to go back to eight - hour days." Ms Telander ' s feel that Ms Telander ' s am more tired than Ms Telander ' s was before," Ms Telander ' s reflects, lamenting the fact that Ms Telander ' s now has less time at home to cook or read with Ms Telander ' s four - year - old daughter." During the trial all the staff had more energy. Ms Telander ' s could see that everybody was happy." Ms Telander is one of about 70 assistant nurses who had about 70 assistant nurses who had their days shortened for the experiment , the most widely reported of a handful of trials in Sweden involving a range of employers , from start - ups to nursing homes days shortened for the experiment, the most widely reported of a handful of trials in Sweden involving a range of employers, from start - ups to nursing homes. Designed to measure well - being in a sector that' s struggling to recruit enough staff to care for the country' s ageing population, extra nurses were brought in to cover the lost hours. The project' s independent researchers were also paid to study employees at a similar care home who continued to work regular days. The project ' s independent researchers final report is due out next month, but data released so far strongly backs Ms Telander' s arguments. During the first 18 months of the trial the nurses working shorter hours logged less sick leave, reported better perceived health and boosted the nurses working shorter hours productivity by organising 85 % more activities for the nurses working shorter hours patients, from nature walks to sing - a - longs. However, the project also faced tough criticism from those concerned that the costs outweighed the benefits. Centre - right opponents filed a motion calling on Gothenburg City Council to wrap the experiment , the most widely reported of a handful of trials in Sweden involving a range of employers , from start - ups to nursing homes up prematurely last May, arguing it was unfair to continue investing taxpayers ' money in a pilot that was not economically sustainable. Saved from the axe at the eleventh hour, the trial managed to stay within budget, but still cost the city about 12 million kronor ( Â £ 1. 1m; $ 1. 3m)." Could we do this for the entire municipality? The answer is no, this will be too expensive," says Daniel Bernmar, the Left Party councillor responsible for running Gothenburg' s elderly care. But Daniel Bernmar , the Left Party councillor responsible for running Gothenburg ' s elderly care argues the experiment still proved" successful from many points of view" by creating extra jobs for 17 nurses in the city, reducing sick pay costs and fuelling global debates about work culture." the experiment , the most widely reported of a handful of trials in Sweden involving a range of employers , from start - ups to nursing homes' s put the shortening of the work day on the agenda both for Sweden and for Europe, which is fascinating," Daniel Bernmar , the Left Party councillor responsible for running Gothenburg ' s elderly care says. " In the past 10, 15 years there' s been a lot of pressure on people working longer hours and this is sort of the contrary of been." Yet while work - life balance is already championed across the political spectrum in Sweden, the chances of the Nordic country trimming back Sweden ' s standard 40 - hour week remain slim. On a national level, the Left Party is the only parliamentary party in favour of shortening basic working hours, backed by just 6 % of voters in Sweden' s last general election. Nevertheless, a cluster of other Swedish municipalities are following in Gothenburg' s footsteps, with locally funded trials targeting other groups of employees with high levels of illness and burnout, including social workers and hospital nurses. Cleaners at Skelleftea Hospital will begin an 18 - month project next month. There' s also been an increase in pilots in the private sector, with advertising, consulting, telecoms and technology firms among those testing the concept. Yet while some have also reported that staff appear calmer or are less likely to phone in sick, others have swiftly abandoned the idea." Erik Gatenholm , chief executive of Gothenburg - based bio - ink company really don' t think that the six - hour day fits with an entrepreneurial world, or the start - up world," argues Erik Gatenholm, chief executive of Gothenburg - based bio - ink company. Erik Gatenholm , chief executive of Gothenburg - based bio - ink company is candid enough to admit Erik Gatenholm , chief executive of Gothenburg - based bio - ink company tested the method on Erik Gatenholm , chief executive of Gothenburg - based bio - ink company production staff after" reading about the trend on Facebook" and musing on whether the six - hour work day could be an innovative draw for future talent. But the firm' s experiment was ditched in less than a month, after bad feedback from employees." Gabriel Peres thought the six - hour work day would be really fun, but the six - hour work day felt kind of stressful," says Gabriel Peres, as Gabriel Peres slots a Petri dish inside one of the 3D printers Gabriel Peres' s built for the company." the six - hour work day' s a process and the six - hour work day takes time and when you don' t have all that [ much] time the six - hour work day kind of feels like skipping homework at school, things are always building up." On the other side of the country, Gabriel Peres concerns are shared by Dr Aram Seddigh, who recently completed Dr Aram Seddigh , who recently completed his doctorate at Stockholm University ' s Stress Research Institute and is among a growing body of academics focusing on the nation ' s shifting work patterns doctorate at Stockholm University' s Stress Research Institute and is among a growing body of academics focusing on the nation' s shifting work patterns." Dr Aram Seddigh , who recently completed his doctorate at Stockholm University ' s Stress Research Institute and is among a growing body of academics focusing on the nation ' s shifting work patterns think the six - hour work day would be most effective in organisations - such as hospitals - where you work for six hours and then you just leave [ the workplace] and go home." the six - hour work day might be less effective for organisations where the borders between work and private life are not so clear," Dr Aram Seddigh , who recently completed his doctorate at Stockholm University ' s Stress Research Institute and is among a growing body of academics focusing on the nation ' s shifting work patterns suggests. " This kind of solution might even increase stress levels given that employees might try to fit all the work that employees have been doing in eight hours into six - or if employees' re office workers employees might take the work home." Back in Gothenburg, Bengt Lorentzon, the lead researcher for the Svartedalen care home project, argues that the concept of six - hour days also jars with the strong culture of flexible working promoted by many Swedish businesses." A lot of offices are already working almost like consultancies. There' s no need for managers to have all managers workers in the office at the same time, managers just want to get the results and people have to deliver," Bengt Lorentzon , the lead researcher for the Svartedalen care home project says." Compare that to the assistant nurses - the assistant nurses can' t just leave work to go to the dentist or to the doctors or the hairdressers."" So Bengt Lorentzon , the lead researcher for the Svartedalen care home project don' t think people should start with the question of whether or not to have reduced hours." First, it should be: what can we do to make the working environment better? And maybe different things can be better for different groups." It could be to do with working hours and working times, but It could be a lot of other things as well." Listen to Maddy Savage' s report on Sweden' s experiment with six - hour days on The World Tonight.
summary: Sweden has become the latest country to experiment with the shortening of the work day, with a series of local and national trials targeting employees with high levels of stress and burnout.

document: Legal experts had warned that inventors and designers based in Scotland could lose out as a result of planned changes to the law. In future a unified patent court will hear patent cases. The Law Society of Scotland and the Faculty of Advocates had urged UK ministers to step in and change the law. change has now happened, with Scotland' s Court of Session being appointed as a venue for these claims, provided there is enough demand. Gill Grassie, a member of the Law Society of Scotland' s intellectual property law committee said:" the Law Society of Scotland ' s are delighted that the UK government has listened to our concerns." the change is an important and very welcome step towards the goal that the Law Society of Scotland ' s have been aiming to achieve for the benefit of Scotland' s IP rich business community." If the Law Society of Scotland ' s can secure the ultimate realisation of this goal sooner rather than later secure will give businesses in Scotland, which rely upon patents to protect valuable technologies and innovation, assurance that businesses in Scotland , which rely upon patents to protect valuable technologies and innovation will be able to enforce and defend businesses in Scotland , which rely upon patents to protect valuable technologies and innovation rights in future in a local court." Thus businesses in Scotland , which rely upon patents to protect valuable technologies and innovation will be enabled to secure the benefits this will give in terms of costs savings, convenience and certainty." The SNP' s Pete Wishart, who had campaigned for the change, said the change means inventors in Scotland will no longer have to go to a more distant court in London or Europe to enforce inventors in Scotland rights. The SNP ' s Pete Wishart , who had campaigned for the change said:" the change is a fantastic victory for the legal establishment in Scotland. The SNP ' s Pete Wishart , who had campaigned for the change raised these concerns through all stages of the intellectual Property Bill and am very pleased that in response to The SNP ' s Pete Wishart , who had campaigned for the change amendments today the UK government have said that we can secure a divisional court if we can demonstrate demand." Not only is there demand in Scotland but there is also centuries of experience, skills and expertise in dealing with patent case in Scotland." It would have been patently absurd for Scotland to be denied a divisional patent court with our tradition of invention and creativity and the change is great news for all businesses associated with developing our creative economy in Scotland." summary: The UK government has agreed to allow Scotland to have Scotland own divisional patent court to hear patent cases.

document: School staff should also watch for signs of FGM, such as frequent toilet trips and girls in pain. The Association of Teachers and Lecturers ( ATL) says teachers need more training to help teachers identity and protect girls at risk. At least 66, 000 girls and women in the UK are believed to be victims of FGM. Campaigners say girls are most at risk of undergoing the procedure during the long summer holidays. The ATL, at The Association of Teachers and Lecturers ( ATL ) annual conference in Manchester, passed a resolution to lobby politicians to eliminate the practice and to develop resources to advise teachers and support staff on how to tackle the problem. Proposing the motion, Helen Porter, from Berkshire, said school staff should openly discuss the issue with parents." Schools and education staff can help by opening discussion with parents, and scrutinising holiday requests and summer holiday plans from members of communities that practise FGM." Schools and education staff should be vigilant for the signs of FGM such as frequent toilet visits and pain whilst sitting down. Schools should publicise the NSPCC' s FGM helpline to pupils, parents and staff." We must aim to empower girls by discussion in age - appropriate PSHE [ personal, social and health education] lessons delivered by trained teachers." We must equally empower boys to challenge this practice. Do boys want the practice of FGM for boys sisters, daughters, girlfriends or wives?" Ms Porter said the practice of FGM should never be described as female circumcision, as there was no medical benefit and rarely any anaesthetic used. Helen Porter , from Berkshire said the term female circumcision was" equivalent to describing deforestation as rainforest topiary". Ms Porter said:" FGM is child abuse. the practice of FGM is a violation of a child' s human rights, and according to the United Nations is a cruel, inhumane and degrading torture that should be eliminated." Tendai Mashapure, from Cambridgeshire, said:" We need to commit ourselves to the creation of an enabling environment where individuals are empowered to make decisions based on the best interest of individuals children." FGM will not end only by targeting those who practise FGM, but rather by engaging with all families, focusing on youth who will be future parents and targeting the leaders who have influence over community members." In other words, by reducing the demand for the practice, the practice of FGM will eventually become obsolete." ATL general secretary Dr Mary Bousted said:" Teachers have been put in a position of great responsibility. What Teachers need now is clear guidance on how to fulfil those responsibilities." Teachers need a clear system for reporting Teachers concerns." Dr Bousted welcomed the letter that Education Secretary Michael Gove sent to schools last term, urging schools to protect girls at risk from what Education Secretary Michael Gove described as" this very serious form of child abuse". FGM includes procedures that remove or injure female genital organs for non - medical reasons. Dangers include severe bleeding, problems urinating, infections, infertility, mental health problems, complications in childbirth and increased risk of death for newborns. Two men were charged last month, in connection with performing FGM, under the Female Genital Mutilation Act 2003. Two men were the first people in Britain to face such charges. The NSPCC children' s charity set up a 24 - hour FGM helpline last year.
summary: Parents should scrutinise holiday requests and summer holiday plans from members of communities that practise female genital mutilation ( FGM), a teachers ' union says.

document: Gales and heavy rain swept across large parts of the UK, causing devastating flooding in Cumbria and Lancashire, as well as parts of southern Scotland. On the first anniversary of Storm Desmond, experts say November to January were the wettest three months since UK records began in 1910. Review author Terry Marsh said flooding was" extensive and repetitive". Storm Desmond began battering parts of the UK on 5 December, depositing a record month' s worth of rain on Cumbria in just one day. About 5, 200 homes were flooded in Cumbria and Lancashire, while tens of thousands more lost power after an electricity sub - station in Lancaster was flooded. The storm caused an estimated insurance bill of more than Â £ 1. 3bn. Major storms" Abigail"," Frank" and" Gertrude" also hit the UK last winter. A study by the Centre for Ecology and Hydrology ( CEH), in collaboration with the British Hydrological Society, found many rivers across northern England, Scotland and Northern Ireland saw record peak flows during the three - month period. A study by the Centre for Ecology and Hydrology ( CEH ) , in collaboration with the British Hydrological Society found the rivers Eden, Tyne and Lune in England saw record peaks of around 1, 700 cubic metres per second. Experts say such levels could fill London' s Royal Albert Hall in less than a minute. Although last winter' s floods were more extreme in scale, flooding in 1947 had a greater impact in terms of homes flooded and crops destroyed, the appraisal found. However, lead author Terry Marsh from CEH said the national scale of last winter' s floods were" the most extreme on record"." The associated flooding was both extensive and repetitive, and total river outflows from Great Britain following the passage of Storm Desmond in December exceeded the previous maximum by a substantial margin," lead author Terry Marsh from CEH said.
summary: Last winter' s floods were" the most extreme on record" and the wettest since 1947, according to a new review.

document: New research suggests the Cornish Black honey bee is better at dealing with varroa mites, which carry a strain of a disease called deformed wing virus. The virus has killed vast numbers of the world' s bees. Scientists at Paignton Zoo are researching how the breed has survived the mite. The zoo hopes Paignton Zoo findings will help protect colonies and encourage more bee keepers to take on the Cornish breed. Colonies of the bees have been moved to the zoo to monitor Colonies of the bees health over the summer. The mites act as tiny incubators of one deadly form of the disease, and inject one deadly form of the disease directly into the bees ' blood. Michael Bungard from the zoo said:" It' s important that zoos look in our own backyard." Our bee project is predominantly education, so Paignton Zoo can get the message across about the Cornish black bees and the varroa mite."
summary: Scientists at Paignton Zoo are studying a new breed of honey bee to see if a new breed of honey bee can survive a disease that has killed millions of bees around the world.

document: Mr Farage , whose party fought the last election on a policy of halting immigration for five years also suggested they should not be eligible for tax credits. It comes as a survey suggests 77 % of Britons want to see immigration cut. The coalition brought in a three month ban on EU citizens getting out - of - work benefits ahead of work restrictions being lifted for Bulgarians and Romanians on 1 January. But Mr Farage, whose party fought the last election on a policy of halting immigration for five years, said the government should go much further. Mr Farage , whose party fought the last election on a policy of halting immigration for five years said the cost of migrants claiming in - work welfare payments, such as child benefit, housing benefit and tax credits, had not been factored in to the government' s calculations." our must be completely mad, as a country, to be giving people from Eastern Europe in - work benefits," Mr Farage , whose party fought the last election on a policy of halting immigration for five years told BBC News. And Mr Farage , whose party fought the last election on a policy of halting immigration for five years said lower economic growth was a price worth paying for cutting immigration." Even if Mr Farage , whose party fought the last election on a policy of halting immigration for five years thought, which Mr Farage , whose party fought the last election on a policy of halting immigration for five years don' t, there was an economic benefit to mass immigration some things are more important than money, namely the shape of our society and giving our own youngsters a chance to work." London Mayor Boris Johnson also weighed in to the debate, suggesting the ban on EU citizens claiming benefits should be two years. Labour said Labour supported the government' s three - month ban, which Labour said was" reasonable and achievable". Downing Street said withholding benefits from migrants for longer periods may be illegal." the government ' s are doing all that the government ' s can within the law," said a No 10 spokesman. Downing Street also confirmed ministers were examining measures to curb the ability of migrants to claim child benefit for children in migrants native countries. The British Social Attitudes Survey suggests more than three - quarters of Britons want to see a cut in immigration - and 56 % want to see a major crackdown. Almost half of those surveyed, 47 %, thought immigration was bad for the economy, and among the 31 % of respondents who said immigration was good for the economy, half wanted to see immigration reduced anyway. The figures are revealed in a BBC Two documentary called The Truth About Immigration, to be broadcast later on Tuesday. Business Secretary Vince Cable tells the programme the government' s target of cutting net migration to below 100, 000 by 2015 is" not helpful" and will almost certainly not be achieved. Mr Cable, who has sought to distance Business Secretary Vince Cable from the net migration target in the past, calling the net migration target a Conservative and not a coalition policy, said politicians on all sides must be" practical" and accept that net migration cannot be controlled." net migration involves British people emigrating - you can' t control emigrating. It involves free movement within the European Union - in and out. It involves British people coming back from overseas who are not immigrants but are counted in the numbers," Mr Cable says." Setting an arbitrary cap is not helpful. Setting almost certainly won' t achieve the below - 100, 000 level the Conservatives are setting - so let' s be practical about it." Labour said the" gap between the government' s rhetoric and reality on immigration is continuing to undermine public confidence". Shadow immigration minister David Hanson said Mr Cable should toughen up enforcement of the minimum wage and prevent employment agencies recruiting solely from abroad. David Cameron promised to cut net migration - the difference between the number of people coming to live in the UK and those emigrating - from more than 250, 000 a year to less than 100, 000 by the next election in 2015. After some initial success, the latest figures show net migration is on the rise again, going up from 167, 000 to 182, 000 a year, largely because fewer Britons were emigrating to eurozone countries. Asked last month if going meant it would be impossible to meet Mr Cameron target, Mr Cameron said:" ' Mr Cameron don' t accept going."" If you take the whole three - year period [ since the election], net immigration is down by around third." Mr Cameron said some measures the government had taken, such as closing" bogus" colleges and tightening up the rules on family reunion, would take time to have an impact. In Nick Robinson' s documentary, former Foreign Secretary Jack Straw says the Labour government of which former Foreign Secretary Jack Straw was a prominent member" got it wrong" on immigration," and former Foreign Secretary Jack Straw deeply regret got". Labour MP and former Home Secretary David Blunkett adds:" Labour didn' t spell out in words of one syllable what was happening, partly because of a fear of racism." Nigel Farage tells the programme:" Labour tried to rubbish us, Labour tried to say that anybody that dared to talk about this subject was necessarily a bad person and racist, that was what Labour tried to do and actually that has been going on ever since [ Enoch] Powell' s speech." In the so - called" rivers of blood" speech, made in 1968, Mr Powell said Britain' s immigration policy was like watching a nation" heaping up a nation own funeral pyre". [ Enoch ] Powell ' s was sacked from the Conservative shadow cabinet by party leader Edward Heath, who said [ Enoch ] Powell ' s speech was" inflammatory and liable to damage race relations". Asked whether Mr Farage thought Mr Powell had been right, Mr Farage says:" Mr Powell was right for the wrong reasons. Mr Powell was wrong in the sense that Mr Powell felt that black and white would find it difficult to mix, but unfortunately Mr Powell' s been proved to be right because the sheer numbers that have come into Britain have led to segregation." BBC political editor Nick Robinson says all political parties now" promise to control" immigration because all political parties are" acutely aware of the high level of public concern" about immigration. In the programme, BBC political editor Nick Robinson looks back to a civil service paper published in 2001 which examined the economic and the social impact of immigration. The paper concluded that there was" little evidence that native workers are harmed by migration". a civil service paper published in 2001 which examined the economic and the social impact of immigration author, former Cabinet Office economist Jonathan Portes, said:" Its author , former Cabinet Office economist Jonathan Portes think politicians do have to say to individuals who are negatively affected, and let' s face it there will be some: ' Yes, politicians' re doing this for the good of our country, and yes individuals who are negatively affected , and let ' s face it there will be some may lose out, but ultimately politicians still have to do this. '" Just as our said to the coal miners 30 years ago: ' Sorry our can get our coal a lot cheaper abroad. our can' t afford to keep on propping the coal miners up. '" The Truth About Immigration is to be broadcast on BBC Two at 21: 30 GMT on Tuesday, 7 January.
summary: The government is" completely mad" to allow in - work migrants from Eastern Europe to claim benefits for longer than three months, UKIP leader Nigel Farage has said.

document: Three of those executed had been convicted of an attack in Tiananmen Square in Beijing last October, in which five people died, Xinhua said. The others were found guilty of crimes including bomb - making and arson. The government has accused separatist militants based in Xinjiang of carrying out a string of recent attacks. Xinjiang is the traditional home of Muslim Uighurs, who speak a distinct language and have different customs to the majority Han population elsewhere in China. Huseyin Guxur, Yusup Wherniyas and Yusup Ehmet were" deprived of political rights for life" because of Huseyin Guxur , Yusup Wherniyas and Yusup Ehmet role in the deadly car crash on Tiananmen Square in October 2013, Xinhua said." Huseyin Guxur , Yusup Wherniyas and Yusup Ehmet masterminded the terrorist attack," the news agency added. In the incident, a car rammed into bystanders on the politically important Beijing square before bursting into flames. Two tourists died, along with three of the attackers. Xinhua named some of the other men who were executed along with the Tiananmen attack perpetrators:. Dilxat Raxit, a spokesman for the World Uighur Congress exile group, called the executions" a typical case of the law serving political ends". Chinese officials often attribute attacks in Xinjiang to Uighur separatists, accusing Uighur separatists of seeking to establish an independent state called East Turkestan. Beijing has recently blamed Uighur separatists for an attack in May at a market in Urumqi, that left at least 31 people dead. China also accused Uighur separatists of being behind a mass knife attack in the southern province of Yunnan in March, in which 29 were killed and more than 130 injured. Uighur leaders deny Uighur leaders are co - ordinating a terrorist campaign. Uighur leaders say the government' s repressive policies in Xinjiang have provoked the unrest. Who are the Uighurs?
summary: China has executed five Uighur men in the western province of Xinjiang, state media say, as part of a crackdown on terrorism in the region.

document: The Holiday Inn Express in Picardy Place was put up for sale in November after The Holiday Inn Express in Picardy Place Aberdeen - based owners, the European Development Company ( EDC), ran into financial difficulties. The Holiday Inn Express in Picardy Place was bought by International Hotel Properties Limited ( IHL) for £ 17. 7m, plus costs. The property takes IHL' s portfolio to nine hotels. The sale was announced by administrators from FRP Advisory. The Grade B listed building consists of 161 rooms and has planning permission for a 20 - bedroom extension at the rear of the property. FRP said FRP Advisory was continuing to operate two other hotels in Aberdeen which were also placed under administration following EDC' s collapse. The Holiday Inn in Westhill and Holiday Inn Express on Chapel Street will be placed on the market" shortly", the administrators said. Joint administrator Iain Fraser added:" Trade has been firm over the festive period and the administration of EDC represents a rare opportunity to acquire quality hotels in Aberdeen in busy locations." FRP Advisory would therefore encourage interested parties to contact the Aberdeen office of FRP Advisory as soon as possible."
summary: A Holiday Inn hotel in Aberdeen has been put up for sale for £ 2. 5m, less than a year after A Holiday Inn hotel in Aberdeen was bought for £ 17. 7m.
