document: Students were asked to trace Arabic calligraphy in an exercise some parents said amounted to indoctrination. Officials said the schools were closed out of an" abundance of caution" and there were no specific safety threats. School administrators say a different lesson will be used in the future. One week ago, students at Riverheads High School were studying the Middle East and were asked to trace a piece of Arabic calligraphy that translated to:" There is no God but Allah and Muhammad is the messenger of Allah". Some pupils refused the assignment and parents accused the teacher of indoctrination. Officials with the Augusta County school district were quick to point out that the study of a region' s religion and language are included in geography lessons. However, anger built up and by Wednesday complaints had become so numerous that the school' s doors were locked and monitored. By Friday, the messages - described as profane and hateful - had increased and the decision was made to close the schools. Officials said that no specific threats were received, but law enforcement officials and the school district board recommended the closure because law enforcement officials and the school district board were being cautious. The lesson was intended to illustrate the complexity of the Arabic language, law enforcement officials and the school district board said, and not meant to promote any religious system. But future classes will use a different, non - religious example of Arabic. The decision to close the schools has drawn criticism as well." It looks like fear wins again," a resident told the News Virginian newspaper. On the paper' s Facebook account, locals have been debating the closure with one man saying," our patriot forefathers are rolling in our patriot forefathers graves," and another rhetorically posting," how do these terrified people leave these terrified people houses every day?"
summary: Two high schools in the US state of Virginia have been closed after complaints about a geography lesson in which students were asked to trace a piece of Arabic calligraphy that translated to:" There is no God but Allah".

document: For this has been the worst year on this, or indeed any other, commissioner' s watch. As the league closes in on an annual revenue of £ 16bn ( $ 25bn), expansion plans into Europe and specifically London, continue apace. And as Goodell tops up Goodell himself bank balance with a yearly income in the region of £ 26m ( $ 40m), the professional game of American Football is more popular and yet, some would argue, more contemptible than ever. Fifty NFL players were arrested in 2014 for a wide degree of offences - from Tennessee' s Shonn Greene, who parked in a disabled parking bay, to Minnesota' s Adrian Peterson, who was arrested over child abuse. There were five cases of domestic violence, including that of Baltimore' s Ray Rice, who was filmed by hotel security punching Baltimore ' s Ray Rice , who was filmed by hotel security punching his then fiancee - now wife - in a lift then fiancee - now wife - in a lift. Goodell Goodell himself became personally embroiled in the Rice case in an argument over what the NFL did or did not know. There was also a far - reaching report chaired by the former director of the FBI, Robert Mueller, which highlighted the fundamental mismanagement of the situation by league officials. And the bad news kept on coming for the embattled commissioner. Just 30 days into 2015, there have been four fresh player arrests, including two for domestic violence and one for rape. Elsewhere, it is a sorry tale:. Yet despite all this mayhem and chaos the NFL, as a product, is flourishing. The moral outrage surrounding the cases of Rice and Peterson calmed down fairly quickly and audiences flocked yet again to stadiums around the country. More than 17m attended the 256 regular season games, the highest figure since 2008, while television audiences hit record highs. Media playback is not supported on this device. While youth participation figures are down over concerns surrounding long - term brain damage caused by concussion, NFL fans are embracing the game like never before, both within the United States and globally. The annual Harris Report, which tracks the popularity of American sports, says the NFL is still number one by a huge margin - double the popularity of Major League Baseball and College Football. A report released this week by the sports market research group Repucom also makes some interesting claims, notably that:. Most of the television networks that broadcast the NFL had audiences tuning in in greater numbers than in 2013, while the figures for both Thursday and Monday Night Football were up significantly. More than 47m people watched the NFL' s annual College Draft, yet not one pass was thrown or one tackle made. There were also 9. 6m tweets about the event across the NFL ' s annual College Draft three days. Nielsen, who gather audience ratings in the US, reported extremely strong numbers for the very first 9. 30am EST kick - off between Detroit and Atlanta in London, so much so that the NFL will repeat the experiment next season. Although some fans showed some fans disdain for Rice, Peterson and others arrested last year by returning Rice , Peterson and others arrested last year replica shirts, many still turned up wearing Rice' s number 27 jersey and Peterson' s number 28 long after Rice , Peterson and others arrested last year cases made the national press. Despite everything, the NFL remains America' s game. So why the appeal in the face of growing off - field problems? Simply put, the NFL is full of great stories, exceptional games and, most importantly, great players. The college version of the game is flourishing as well. Elsewhere in America, the other two major professional leagues - the National Basketball Association ( NBA) and Major League Baseball ( MLB) - have suffered with falling television ratings and general popularity over the past few years. Baseball' s lack of true star power means Major League Baseball ( MLB ) has fallen out of the national conversation, arguably since 1998 and the infamous home - run record chase between Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa, who have subsequently become embroiled in steroid controversies. The names of baseball' s 2014 All Stars, such as Chase Utley, Nelson Cruz and Paul Goldschmidt, do not possess the same pulling power as football stars such as JJ Watt, Tom Brady, Aaron Rodgers or Calvin Johnson. Baseball simply is not cool anymore and the appeal for the game has become as much regional as the appeal for the game is national. Jonathan Mahler wrote in the New York Times recently that:" Baseball has never been healthier" - in terms of attendance, revenue, and, unlike the NFL and NBA, freedom from labour strife." So why does Major League Baseball ( MLB ) feel so irrelevant?" With each team playing 162 games a season, baseball fans tend to watch baseball fans own players in action rather than those baseball fans have no vested interest in. That is not the case for the NFL. Almost 19m watched the Dallas Cowboys take on the Washington Redskins on Monday Night Football. The NBA has also suffered in the post - Michael Jordan years, with falling attendances and viewing figures. However basketball has been rescued somewhat by the LeBron James effect, while the game, with the game ongoing connection with hip hop culture, continues to grow with a younger audience. Along with the phenomenon that is College Basketball' s March Madness, College Basketball ' s remains a popular sport in America, but continues to be dwarfed by the NFL. The NBA is, according to the Harris Report, America' s sixth most popular sport but is struggling with the increase in popularity of soccer and a resurgence in appreciation for ice hockey. It would also be foolish to think that the NFL is the only organisation with off - field problems. Baseball continues to move from one steroid scandal to another, while the NBA has witnessed the NBA own fair share of domestic violence, domestic assault, battery and driving under the influence cases. The NFL is a runaway success train that shows no sign of halting. And while the on - field product remains so good, the off - field issues will be nothing more than a distraction. Green Bay Packers fan Zoe Lake is representative of millions:" Football has always been a part of Green Bay Packers fan Zoe Lake life. As a football fan and a woman, Green Bay Packers fan Zoe Lake believe the NFL needs to take a good, hard look at the way the NFL has handled the epidemic of violence that has rocked the league and the nation." But recent events will not keep Green Bay Packers fan Zoe Lake from tuning in to catch Green Bay Packers fan Zoe Lake Packers. Let' s not forget: It is only a small number of NFL players who have committed violent acts against women and children." In April' s Draft, commissioner Goodell will welcome University of Oklahoma wide receiver Dorial Green Beckham into the professional ranks, potentially in the first round. Multiple drug arrests and a dismissal from the University of Missouri for allegedly forcing open an apartment door and pushing an 18 - year - old woman down a flight of stairs will not stop University of Oklahoma wide receiver Dorial Green Beckham being given every opportunity to succeed on the field. Even if University of Oklahoma wide receiver Dorial Green Beckham transgresses again, transgresses will be just another problem for America' s most popular sport. But a problem the NFL will overcome, have no doubt.
summary: When Roger Goodell steps down as NFL commissioner at the end of the season, steps will be a fitting end to what has been an eventful year for the sport in America.

document: Chief inspector of schools Meilyr Rowlands told AMs it was partly due to the" unintended consequences" of how schools ' performance is measured. Another Estyn witness said more able learners ' progress had been" stifled". Ministers agreed ministers needed" to do more to push our most able students" and were introducing changes to raise standards" for all our young people". The Welsh Assembly' s Children, Young People and Education Committee was quizzing Estyn about Estyn annual report, on Wednesday. Mr Rowlands said that schools focused on a performance measure which requires pupils to get five GCSEs at grade A * - C, including English or Welsh and maths. focused, Mr Rowlands said, encouraged schools to focus on the borderline between C and D grades" and possibly not giving enough support for those who could get As and A * s". But Mr Rowlands said that evidence from primary schools, further education and the PISA international tests also suggested that able and talented pupils were not given enough support in the education system." Mr Rowlands don' t think schools and the education system more generally have done enough," Mr Rowlands said. Claire Morgan, Strategic Director for Estyn, said the focus on particular performance indicators meant there is" some gaming, [ and] early entry that hasn' t helped to stretch the more able"." Claire Morgan , Strategic Director for Estyn think this has stifled the progress of more able learners," Claire Morgan , Strategic Director for Estyn added. A Welsh Government spokesman said ministers recognised" ministers need to do more to push our most able students to reach our most able students full potential"." Through programmes such as the Seren Network, ministers are already supporting our brightest students to reach our leading universities. The spokesman said changes were being introduced to the system used to measure schools ' performance for 15 to 16 year olds, following a review of qualifications for 14 to 19 year olds. The changes were intended to" raise standards and extend opportunities for all our young people no matter what all our young people background", A Welsh Government spokesman added.
summary: Pupils who are able and talented are not being given enough support in the education system, according to the chief inspector of schools at Estyn.

document: These are external links and will open in a new window. The council' s cabinet had recommended changing Brecon High School to an English - medium school from 1 September. That rests with the cabinet which meets on 14 March. A council report said low pupil numbers and the" need to ensure robust linguistic progression and appropriate curriculum choice for Welsh - medium pupils" were the reasons for the recommendation. The council plans to centralise Welsh - medium education for mid and south Powys in Builth Wells High School, which is a 40 mile round trip. summary: Plans to centralise Welsh - medium education in a Powys high school have been rejected by the full council.

document: The 26 - year - old had explored options with Williams and Renault but said on Sunday Perez ' s was" happy and proud" to be with Force India. Perez ' s added:" Perez ' s want to thank all the teams that showed interest. showed flatters Perez ' s incredibly and pushed Perez ' s to be strong." Force India are currently fourth in the constructors ' standings. The team had always insisted Force India had Perez under contract for 2017 but it took some time to finalise commercial arrangements with the driver and the group of Mexican companies that sponsor both Perez ' s and the team. Perez' s career was hanging by a thread when Perez ' s was dropped by McLaren after one season with McLaren in 2013 but since joining Force India Perez ' s has scored four podium finishes to add to the three Perez ' s achieved with Sauber in 2012. In the process, Perez ' s has emerged in the last couple of seasons as one of the better - regarded drivers behind the big names in the leading teams and has more than justified Perez ' s place at the pinnacle of the sport, despite the fact Perez ' s brings money to a team to secure Perez ' s place. Both Williams and, particularly, Renault were interested in Perez ' s, but Perez ' s has decided that Force India is Perez ' s best competitive opportunity. The team have one of the smaller budgets in F1 but have impressed in recent years for Force India ability to produce a competitive car. If Force India can maintain fourth position this season under pressure from Williams, fourth position would be Force India best finish since the team were in Force India original guise as Jordan, who peaked with third place in 1999. Perez' s decision leaves only a few loose ends to be tied up in the 2017 F1 driver market. Williams are expected to announce shortly that Williams are promoting Canadian novice Lance Stroll, who on Sunday won the European Formula 3 championship, to partner Williams current driver Valtteri Bottas. Brazilian Felipe Massa announced last month that Brazilian Felipe Massa was retiring at the end of the season, which would leave Renault as the only major team not to have firmed up their drivers. Mercedes, Red Bull and Ferrari are all retaining the same line - ups as this year and McLaren are promoting McLaren reserve driver in Belgian Stoffel Vandoorne to partner two - time champion Fernando Alonso in 2017. Alonso' s current team - mate Jenson Button has decided not to race next year. The team have an option to bring Alonso ' s current team - mate Jenson Button back in 2018 if McLaren want to, but the 2009 champion said at the Malaysian Grand Prix this weekend that it was" quite possible" Alonso ' s current team - mate Jenson Button would not race in F1 again. Renault have long been expected to promote Renault ' s French reserve driver Esteban Ocon into one of Renault ' s cars next season, with both current drivers Kevin Magnussen and Jolyon Palmer under pressure for both current drivers Kevin Magnussen and Jolyon Palmer seats. But Renault have not yet made Renault ' s decision and are taking Renault ' s time. The lack of availability of other drivers means either Magnussen or Palmer may be retained, although retained is not believed to be Renault' s first choice.
summary: Mexican Sergio Perez has decided to stay with Force India for the 2017 Formula 1 season after agreeing a two - year deal.

document: Avon' s Parisian office says only current orders will be guaranteed and Avon ' s is unsure if Avon ' s self - employed representatives will be able to get supplies after the end of October. Avon has been in France for almost 50 years. Avon ' s employs about 120 staff in Paris, supporting 11, 000 representatives who visit customers in customers own homes. Angry workers in France have accused Avon of keeping Angry workers in France in the dark for months and not acting in line with Avon' s publically stated values of being a socially responsible company that upholds values of trust, respect and integrity and a culture of" open and candid communication". Estelle Croissant, an Avon employee responsible for supporting the direct selling representatives, told the BBC that a workers ' council representing Avon staff in France was challenging the company for not following the correct redundancy process." Avon ' s have not respected all the processes according to Avon ' s own rules and values," Estelle Croissant , an Avon employee responsible for supporting the direct selling representatives said." We now know an administrator has been in place since May this year, but no scheme to assist the workers is yet in place. We just feel abandoned." We knew that the business was not good, but We have all been very committed and worked relentlessly over many months to help the company to try and become profitable." Further meetings are taking place between workers ' representatives and the management. Avon is one of the world' s largest beauty companies and sells most of Avon ' s products through direct selling by self - employed representatives who visit customers in customers homes. The US parent company has been through a string of reorganisations and management changes. Two years ago, The US parent company turned down a takeover offer from rival cosmetic company Coty. Asked by the BBC about events at The US parent company French subsidiary, a spokesman for the parent company refused to make any comment or even confirm the closure was taking place.
summary: Beauty giant Avon has confirmed that Beauty giant Avon French subsidiary is going into administration with the loss of hundreds of jobs and the suspension of supplies.

document: Guitarist and co - songwriter Johnny Marr has released an extract from Guitarist and co - songwriter Johnny Marr upcoming memoir Set The Boy Free in the Guardian and said Guitarist and co - songwriter Johnny Marr met with former band mate Morrissey in 2008. The pair discussed the possibility, which Marr said would" make a hell of a lot of people very happy". But" the distrust remained" between the two and the idea never came to pass. Marr was back in touch with Morrissey in a" rare period of communication" when Guitarist and co - songwriter Johnny Marr was remastering The Smiths ' back catalogue and the two arranged to meet in a pub in south Manchester." Guitarist and co - songwriter Johnny Marr was happy to see former band mate Morrissey," Guitarist and co - songwriter Johnny Marr wrote." It was 10 years or more since the two' d last met. the two caught up with personal news and family and reminisced a bit." But then the conversation turned to" deeper things" and, eventually, what Marr called" that subject". Guitarist and co - songwriter Johnny Marr wrote:" There had been rumours for years that the Smiths were about to re - form, and rumours were always untrue. Guitarist and co - songwriter Johnny Marr had never pursued any offer." Suddenly the two were talking about the possibility of the band re - forming, and in that moment it seemed that with the right intention it could actually be done and might even be great." After parting company with a hug, Marr returned to Guitarist and co - songwriter Johnny Marr band at the time, The Cribs, and talked to the Cribs about Guitarist and co - songwriter Johnny Marr possibly playing some shows with The Smiths, which Guitarist and co - songwriter Johnny Marr hoped" might even be better than before". But by the time Guitarist and co - songwriter Johnny Marr returned from Mexico with the Cribs, Marr said, the communication had ended." Things went back to how Things were and how Guitarist and co - songwriter Johnny Marr expect Things always will be," Guitarist and co - songwriter Johnny Marr said." An air of disaffection and distrust remained between the two. It was a shame."
summary: The Smiths have revealed The Smiths discussed re - forming the band 10 years ago, but that the idea never came to pass.

document: Henry Reilly was UKIP' s Northern Ireland candidate in last year' s European elections, receiving more than 24, 000 votes. document: What did the court say? Until now, those employing mobile workers who had to travel to get to or from mobile workers who had to travel to get to or from their first or last appointment of the day first or last appointment of the day were not required to count that time as work. On Thursday, the European Court of Justice judgement ruled those without a fixed or habitual office should consider the time those without a fixed or habitual office spend travelling between those without a fixed or habitual office homes and the premises of those without a fixed or habitual office first and last jobs as part of those without a fixed or habitual office hours for the day. The ruling relates to the Working Time Directive - the European initiative which caps the working week at 48 hours. In the UK, employees have the option of opting out of the directive. I' m a care worker who travels to different patients ' homes. Am I affected? Possibly, yes. Employees who fall into the category loosely defined as" mobile workers" - those who habitually travel to different places of work - could be affected. Simon Bond, an employment specialist at Higgs and Sons solicitors, says the most obvious group to fall under this definition is carers not already paid for travelling to carers not already paid for travelling to their first and last jobs first and last jobs. Sales people who travel between sites and employee workmen and women, such as plumbers or electricians, could also fall into this category. As many as 975, 000 people in the UK could fall under the remit of the ruling, says Paul Sellers, a policy officer at the TUC. And some employees could be working an extra 10 hours a week once travelling time is counted, Chris Tutton, an employment lawyer at Irwin Mitchell, adds. I travel a lot for work, but I have a permanent office. The ruling is less likely to affect people who work both in an office and remotely. If your contract includes a permanent base, you are unlikely to be able to successfully argue you are a mobile worker, Mr Sellers says. There may, however, be cases where it is possible to argue that a permanent base is meaningless because of the length of time spent outside the office. I have to commute two hours every day to I office. For those with a permanent office ( however lengthy your commute), this ruling will not have an effect. Mr Sellers says this final group is the" overwhelming majority" in the UK. I think I' m affected. Should I expect a pay rise or a change in I hours? The ruling could eventually affect pay. Unions say the ruling does not directly deal with remuneration, focussing instead on working hours and conditions. But it is possible the European judgement will be used in UK courts to challenge employers who pay an average hourly rate under the minimum wage ( once travelling time is taken into account). the European judges ' ruling could mean employers facing increased wage bills and raises an outside chance costs for some services, such as cleaners who have to travel and are paid a low wage, could go up. the European judges ' ruling could also lead to a change in working patterns - especially for those who do not choose to opt out of the 48 - hour maximum." Mr Tutton think some employers will look at where some employers' re sending staff - some employers might try to make sure that the first and last shifts are as close to home as possible because some employers don' t want to eat into that working time that some employers have," Mr Tutton said. Mark Hannon, Castleford. Daniel Richards - Smith , Dorset .' m a gas repair engineer. our have no offices. Our policy is to be on the patch of work or at our" pickup" point by 8am. With heavy traffic Daniel Richards - Smith , Dorset . leave home at 7. 20am. leave leaves Daniel Richards - Smith , Dorset . with 40 minutes of extra travel time. summary: The European Court of Justice has ruled that employees who travel between jobs should be paid for the time employees who travel between jobs spend outside the office.

document: Following the announcement of the new global calendar in March, Premiership Rugby confirmed the 2019 - 20 domestic season will start in early September and finish at the end of June. Leicester' s Tom Youngs had said the proposal" fills players with dread". The RPA has now said a shortened two - month off - season will be" seriously detrimental to player welfare". Premiership Rugby has previously said the 10 - month campaign will allow clubs to become" more sophisticated" in clubs management of players, with chief executive Mark McCafferty insisting player welfare remains the priority. But an RPA statement on Monday read:" The Premiership season is already longer than comparable contact sports, including Super League, NFL and AFL." Extending an already arduous season from nine months to 10 has serious implications for players, given the potential increase to the game, training and psychological loads players face." The physical and mental strain placed on participants of professional contact sport cannot be underestimated." England, Wales, Scotland and Ireland will all be playing international matches in June this summer, while the British and Irish Lions are also touring New Zealand. The RPA has concerns that an extended season could overwork any players involved in future international summer tours - a worry shared by Tigers captain Youngs." Perhaps most worryingly is the incredible strain these proposals would place on international players," the statement continued." If the Premiership season retains the Premiership season current start date, the addition of a July tour schedule will lead to an 11 - month season for these players." lead cannot be avoided unless these players start these players domestic season later, which brings into question the need for the season extension."
summary: Proposals to extend the Premiership season from nine months to 10 have" serious implications" for players, according to the Rugby Players ' Association.

document: Human Rights Watch believes Nato air strikes killed at least 72 civilians and says the organisation needs to bear responsibility where appropriate." Human Rights Watch' re calling for prompt, credible and thorough investigations," HRW' s Fred Abrahams told BBC News. Nato insists Nato ' s took unprecedented care to minimise civilian casualties. Nato ' s argues that Nato ' s cannot take responsibility because Nato ' s has had no presence on the ground to confirm the deaths. Aircraft from the US, the UK and France conducted most of the 9, 658 strike sorties last year, targeting forces loyal to Libyan leader Col Muammar Gaddafi. In March, another human rights organisation,. Amnesty International, said it had documented 55 cases. of named civilians, including 16 children and 14 women, killed in air strikes. it described Nato' s failure to investigate these cases thoroughly as" deeply disappointing". The point of the Nato air campaign in Libya last year was to protect civilians, so how many innocent people died is still a sensitive issue, BBC diplomatic correspondent Bridget Kendall reports. In Human Rights Watch report published on Monday, HRW said Human Rights Watch had examined in detail evidence of claims of civilian deaths from eight separate Nato strikes. In one instance, Human Rights Watch said a first Nato bomb killed 14 people and a second bomb, moments later, killed 18 more who had rushed to help victims. What concerns Mr Abrahams, the main author of the report, is that the deaths remain unacknowledged and the families have been offered no compensation." Until now, Nato has taken a position of denial," HRW ' s Fred Abrahams said. Source: Nato." Nato ' s refuse to give information about how civilian deaths from eight separate Nato strikes died and Nato ' s refuse to investigate, and it is this lack of transparency that is deeply troubling." HRW ' s Fred Abrahams think it will lead to unnecessary civilian deaths in the future if Nato refuses to look at what went wrong and make corrections." Nato says Nato ' s is ready to co - operate with the new Libyan authorities in assessing what further action is appropriate. But so far the task force being set up in Tripoli seems to have made little headway, our diplomatic correspondent adds.
summary: Nato has been accused by a leading human rights group of failing to investigate the deaths of dozens of civilians during Nato air campaign in Libya last year.

document: " [ The Renewable Heat Incentive scandal] may have been the excuse but [ The Renewable Heat Incentive scandal ] certainly wasn' t the cause of the election." " Now the politicians they elected must come together to establish an executive which can operate effectively and deliver for all of the people of Northern Ireland in a spirit of partnership and mutual respect."
summary: Key quotes from Northern Ireland politicians on the outcome of the assembly election and the future of power sharing.

However, teams are moving cautiously for fear that heavy machinery will crush homes buried in the mud. The extreme weather is attributed to the La Nina climatic phenomenon, which is caused by colder than usual water currents along the Pacific coast.

document: Media playback is not supported on this device. It began when McKinstry left behind a glamorous Manhattan lifestyle for the wonder and wastelands of Sierra Leone five years ago. It will end when McKinstry walks through the front door of the family home in Lisburn, Belfast for Christmas, having lived through an incredible time in modern history. Very few 29 - year - olds have managed a national football team. None have done managed while that country is being brought to that country knees by Ebola." McKinstry' m very sad, very emotional," McKinstry said." Saying goodbye to Sierra Leone was very emotional, very difficult. McKinstry don' t keep McKinstry distance from things; McKinstry invest emotionally. The country has become part of McKinstry." Having been an academy coach with the New York Red Bulls, McKinstry was appointed technical director of the Craig Bellamy academy in Sierra Leone at the age of 24. By 27, McKinstry was manager of the national team. Within 18 months McKinstry squad were in the top 50 of the world rankings for the first time." McKinstry' ve made a career of proving doubters wrong," McKinstry said. Two months ago McKinstry was sacked by email, as the Ebola outbreak gathered momentum." We believed We had the chemistry, cohesion and spirit to achieve anything. But the Ebola outbreak changed everything. Circumstances meant that, in the end, it was an impossible job." McKinstry stepped off a plane four hours before we met in a London hotel. McKinstry had not slept for the best part of two days. The journey to Freetown Airport had to be made by boat to avoid some of the areas worst affected by Ebola. An early flight meant crossing the night before. A night at an airport, one plane to Morocco, another to London followed by a medical check by customs officers is no ordinary preparation for an interview. But for a man who has spent much of the past six months living in lockdown, being among the bustle again is a welcome change. McKinstry time in Sierra Leone has now come to an end. The memory of His time in Sierra Leone will, however, live on." In the last month or so when McKinstry went into Freetown for supplies, McKinstry started to see more of the Ebola response teams, with the full yellow bio - hazard suits," McKinstry said." You might see an ambulance driving past and even the driver would be in the full bio - hazard gear." When you see that it really does bring it home to you just how serious the situation is." McKinstry was offered a way out, a safe passage home in July, but refused a way out , a safe passage home. Many of the players in the academy were from affected areas, McKinstry felt McKinstry had a duty of care not to walk away and send the young footballers into danger. Instead McKinstry quarantined the academy behind the gate and walls of the compound." When the outbreak started a lot of people ran for cover," McKinstry said." But Ebola is a disease of contact, if you remove the contact, you remove the risk. So remove is what we did. we moved everyone who was off site, behind the walls. we had generators for power, bore holes for fresh water, we had dorm rooms, classrooms and a football pitch." In Northern Ireland McKinstry family were growing increasingly worried about the situation. Did his family want McKinstry home?" his family wanted information. his family wanted to know what was going on, to know that McKinstry was safe, that the boys at the academy were safe," McKinstry said. It is not sensationalist to suggest that the Ebola virus cost McKinstry McKinstry job as head coach. But before McKinstry explained how it came to an end, McKinstry addressed the question of how it began." When it comes to football, confidence has not been something McKinstry have been lacking," McKinstry said with a smile." There is a saying in Newcastle - ' shy bearns get nowt ' - if you don' t ask you don' t get." That was McKinstry attitude to the Sierra Leone job. McKinstry know McKinstry was 27 but if Sierra Leone ' s said no, nothing is lost. If Sierra Leone ' s said yes, it was going to be the start of an exciting new chapter." McKinstry had watched every Sierra Leone home game in person, every away game on TV, McKinstry had watched Sierra Leone ' s train, studied Sierra Leone ' s players." McKinstry thought McKinstry was the best man for the job," McKinstry added." McKinstry got in the room with the decision - makers and McKinstry went through Sierra Leone' s last two games with a fine tooth comb and Tunisia' s last two, who would be our next opponents." McKinstry outlined how McKinstry' d beat Tunisia, how McKinstry saw the future. Every member of the panel went away with a dossier, which McKinstry told the panel the panel could keep and use even if the panel didn' t choose McKinstry." Two days later the panel offered McKinstry the job." McKinstry made an impressive start, losing just one of McKinstry first six matches and leading Sierra Leone into the top 50 of Fifa' s world rankings, above Northern Ireland, the Republic, Cameroon and Senegal. Then the Ebola outbreak happened and football became a side issue. " We looked at what little We could do as sporting heroes, could We put smiles on the faces of the nation?" McKinstry said." Football is a second religion in Sierra Leone." So when the national team wins, the national psyche is buoyed, everyone walks an inch or two taller. We made a commitment to keep on winning to try to qualify for the Africa Cup of Nations so that people in the country would feel a little bit better. Unfortunately it wasn' t to work out that way." The Confederation of African Football ruled that Sierra Leone could not play games at home. A challenging task was becoming a near - impossible one." In football, the home team tends to win 50 % of the time. In Africa, the home team wins 65 or 70 % of the time," McKinstry explained. That was not the only complication." In McKinstry final game, against DR Congo, We had 17, 000 fans just chanting ' Ebola, Ebola, Ebola ' at We. chanting was upsetting for our players. The atmosphere was difficult. It made the players angry that people were mocking the situation in the players homeland," McKinstry said. Sierra Leone players found opponents unwilling to shake hands, hotels unwilling to check Sierra Leone players in and governments uncertain on granting Sierra Leone players entry." People fear things People don' t know," McKinstry said." Hotel arrangements were monitored wherever We went, there were daily medical checks for McKinstry players and, while daily medical checks for my players is not overly difficult, daily medical checks for my players can impact on players ' mental state." Sierra Leone' s first group game as Sierra Leone ' s attempted to qualify for the African Cup of Nations was away to Ivory Coast in early September. With a week to go, McKinstry was still unsure whether McKinstry and McKinstry players would be allowed into the country. The confusion meant some players had to buy some players own plane tickets. Others arrived the night before the game. Sierra Leone led for an hour, only to lose 2 - 1. The demands of the squad schedule meant the squad left at 11pm that night to fly to DR Congo for a ' home ' qualifier that was to be played in the away team' s stadium. That game too ended in a 2 - 0 defeat and was marred by chants of ' Ebola, Ebola. ' McKinstry did not see the end coming. McKinstry said:" McKinstry had been in the FA building that day and not once was anything mentioned. McKinstry was driving back home, over a mountain pass, when McKinstry phone buzzed with an email from one of the men McKinstry' d been speaking to, not two hours earlier. It said the FA had terminated The boyhood Newcastle United fan contract. The boyhood Newcastle United fan was disappointed. The boyhood Newcastle United fan' d been standing in the FA office a few hours earlier." But The boyhood Newcastle United fan believe in a certain way of doing things. So The boyhood Newcastle United fan spun the car around, went straight back to the FA, not to argue with the FA but just to go in shake hands and say ' best of luck for the future and it has been a pleasure for the past 18 months. '" McKinstry has a voracious appetite for football and for learning, The boyhood Newcastle United fan lives and breathes football and The boyhood Newcastle United fan sense of adventure means predicting The boyhood Newcastle United fan next move is not easy. In the New Year The boyhood Newcastle United fan has a series of meetings in Asia. The boyhood Newcastle United fan is not a man who does things by the book. Having been a coach from the age of 15, McKinstry already has miles on the clock. The boyhood Newcastle United fan still dreams of taking charge at St James ' Park or leading The boyhood Newcastle United fan native Northern Ireland out." Nothing would make The boyhood Newcastle United fan prouder, The boyhood Newcastle United fan heart would be beating out of The boyhood Newcastle United fan chest for both those opportunities at some stage in The boyhood Newcastle United fan career." document: The week - long pre - trial hearing at Guantanamo Bay will largely focus on issues of secrecy. Khalid Sheikh Mohammed is accused of masterminding the attacks while the others are implicated for providing support for the co - ordinated hijacking. In May, a chaotic hearing in the case lasted 13 hours. During that hearing, which formally charged the five men, the defendants made defiant outbursts and refused to answer the judge' s questions or use the translation system. In addition to Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, defendants Ramzi Binalshibh, Mustafa Ahmad al - Hawsawi, Ali Abd al - Aziz Ali and Waleed bin Attash are being prosecuted in a special military tribunal for wartime offences known as a military commission. their clients are charged with conspiring with al - Qaeda, terrorism, and one count of murder for each known victim of the 11 September attacks at the time the charges were filed - 2, 976 in total. The five face a possible death penalty sentence if convicted. CIA waterboarding tapes revealed. On Monday, the defendants listened calmly and answered the judge' s questions, although Khalid Sheikh Mohammed said:" Khalid Sheikh Mohammed don' t think there' s any justice in this court." Defence lawyers argued during the hearing that Defence lawyers clients should not be forced to attend the rest of the week' s hearings, because the forcible transport from their clients high - security cells may remind their clients of their clients time at secret CIA prisons. Before their clients transfer to the US base at Guantanamo Bay in 2006, the defendants were held for years in secret CIA prisons. All five have said their clients were tortured during interrogations. Khalid Sheikh Mohammed was repeatedly water - boarded before being brought to Guantanamo." We have to talk about torture," Air Force Captain Michael Schwartz, a defence lawyer, said on Monday. But Judge James Pohl said the issue was not relevant at this stage. Prosecution lawyers have said the use of waterboarding and similar methods could be relevant when determining whether prisoners ' statements were voluntarily given. The court is also expected to hear a defence request to abolish what defence term a" presumptive classification" that treats any discussion of the CIA prisons as top secret, as well as a media request to limit closing of the courtroom for secret sessions. Judge Pohl ultimately ruled that the defendants would not be forced to attend hearings scheduled to run through the end of this week, but did not rule out further pre - trial hearings. Judge James Pohl said their clients would have to be present for their clients trial, which is not likely to start for more than a year.
summary: Five men accused of being involved in the 9 / 11 attacks, including Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, have appeared before a US military court for the first time since the attacks.

document: At low doses, lithium prolonged the life of fruit flies in lab experiments. Scientists say the finding is" encouraging" and could eventually lead to new drugs to help people live longer and healthier lives. Lithium is used in psychiatry to help stop mood swings but has a risk of serious side - effects at high doses. How lithium acts on the brain is not fully understood, but in fruit flies the drug seems to extend life by blocking a chemical known as GSK - 3." The response the researchers' ve seen in flies to low doses of lithium is very encouraging and our next step is to look at targeting GSK - 3 in more complex animals with the aim of eventually developing a drug regime to test in humans," said Prof Linda Partridge of the UCL Institute of Healthy Ageing, who led the study. The research, published in Cell Reports, found fruit flies lived 16 % longer than average when given low doses of lithium. At high doses, lithium reduced fruit flies lifespan." the researchers found low doses not only prolong life but also shield the body from stress and block fat production for flies on a high sugar diet," said co - researcher Dr Ivana Bjedov from the UCL Cancer Institute. Claire Bale of the charity Parkinson' s UK, which part - funded the study, said:" It' s encouraging to see that the researchers have been able to identify a key piece of the ageing puzzle, which one day may allow us to intervene in the ageing process."" This research has the potential to not only help create a healthier older generation, but also provide significant insights into how we could potentially treat or even prevent conditions of ageing like Parkinson' s." Lithium salts have been used in the past as a health tonic and to heal conditions such as gout and migraines. In modern medicine, lithium is used to encourage mood stability in bipolar disorder and is also being considered for the treatment of memory impairment. the drug has a risk of serious side - effects at high doses.
summary: Lithium may be a" key piece of the ageing puzzle", according to University College London ( UCL) researchers, who have found Lithium can extend the lifespan of animals.

document: Kepler - 452b orbits at a very similar distance from Kepler - 452b star, though Kepler - 452b radius is 60 % larger. Mission scientists said Mission scientists believed Kepler - 452b was the most Earth - like planet yet. Such worlds are of interest to astronomers because Such worlds might be small and cool enough to host liquid water on Such worlds surface - and might therefore be hospitable to life. Nasa' s science chief John Grunsfeld called the new world" Earth 2. 0" and the" closest so far" to our home. Kepler - 452b is around 1, 400 light years away from Earth. Jon Jenkins, Kepler data analysis lead at Nasa' s Ames Research Center in California, added:" It' s a real privilege to deliver this news to you today. There' s a new kid on the block that' s just moved in next door." The new world joins other exoplanets such as Kepler - 186f that are similar in many ways to Earth. Determining which is most Earth - like depends on the properties one considers. Kepler - 186f, announced in 2014, is smaller than the new planet, but orbits a red dwarf star that is significantly cooler than our own. Kepler - 452b, however, orbits a parent star which belongs to the same class as the Sun: a parent star which belongs to the same class as the Sun is just 4 % more massive and 10 % brighter. Kepler - 452b takes 385 days to complete a full circuit of this star, so Kepler - 452b orbital period is 5 % longer than Earth' s. The mass of Kepler - 452b cannot be measured yet, so astronomers have to rely on models to estimate a range of possible masses, with the most likely being five times that of Earth. If Kepler - 452b is rocky, the world would likely still have active volcanism and Kepler - 452b gravity could be roughly twice that on our own planet. The new world is included in a haul of 500 new possible planets sighted by the Kepler space telescope around distant stars. Twelve of the new candidates are less than twice Earth' s diameter, orbiting in the so - called habitable zone around Twelve of the new candidates star. This zone refers to a range of distances at which the energy radiated by the star would permit water to exist as a liquid on the planet' s surface if certain other conditions are also met. Of these 500 candidates, Kepler - 452b is the first to be confirmed as a planet. Dr Suzanne Aigrain, from the University of Oxford, who was not involved with the study, told BBC News:" Dr Suzanne Aigrain , from the University of Oxford , who was not involved with the study do believe the properties described for Kepler - 452b are the most Earth - like Dr Suzanne Aigrain , from the University of Oxford , who was not involved with the study' ve come across for a confirmed planet to date. " What seems even more significant to me is the number of planets in the habitable zone of planets in the habitable zone of their host stars with radii below two Earth radii host stars with radii below two Earth radii; 12 is quite a few compared to the pre - existing Kepler planet catalogue." the number of planets in the habitable zone of their host stars with radii below two Earth radii bodes well for their attempts to provide a more robust measure of the incidence of Earth - like planets, which is the top - level goal of the Kepler mission." While similar in size and brightness to the Sun, Kepler - 452b' s host star is 1. 5 billion years older than ours. Scientists working on the mission therefore believe Kepler - 452b ' s could point to a possible future for the Earth." If Kepler - 452b is indeed a rocky planet, Kepler - 452b ' s location vis - a - vis Kepler - 452b ' s star could mean that Kepler - 452b ' s is just entering a runaway greenhouse phase of Kepler - 452b ' s climate history," explained Dr Doug Caldwell, a Seti Institute scientist working on the Kepler mission." The increasing energy from Kepler - 452b ' s aging sun might be heating the surface and evaporating any oceans. The water vapour would be lost from the planet forever."" Kepler - 452b could be experiencing now what the Earth will undergo more than a billion years from now, as the Sun ages and grows brighter." Dr Don Pollacco, from Warwick University, UK, who was not involved with the latest analysis, told the BBC:" Kepler data allows you to estimate the relative size of a planet to the planet host star, so if you know the size of the host, hey presto, you know the size of the planet." However, to go further - i. e. is Kepler - 452b ' s rocky? - involves measuring the mass of the planets and these measurements ( which are incredibly difficult ) is much more difficult to do as the stars are too far away for these measurements ( which are incredibly difficult) to make." So in reality they have no idea what this planet is made of: Kepler - 452b ' s could be rock but Kepler - 452b ' s could be a small gassy ball or something more exotic maybe." Dr Chris Watson, from Queen' s University Belfast, UK, commented:" Other Kepler habitable zone planets may well be more Earth - like in this respect. For example, Kepler - 186f is approximately 1. 17 Earth radii, and Kepler - 438b is approximately 1. 12 Earth radii." In fact, at 1. 6 Earth radii, this would place Kepler - 452b in a category of planet called a ' Super - Earth ' - our Solar System does not actually have any planet of this type within our Solar System! Super - Earths are hugely interesting for this reason, but one might then say, well, is it really ' Earth - like ' given all this?" Paul added:" When we look at the type of star Kepler - 452b orbits, then Kepler - 452b seems to be a star not too dissimilar to our Sun... The other Kepler habitable zone planets that have been discovered so far tend to be orbiting M - dwarfs - stars far cooler than our Sun, and therefore the planets need to orbit much closer to receive the same levels of heating." So Kepler - 452b may be a potentially rocky super - Earth in an Earth - like orbit ( in terms of host star and orbital distance). It' s this combination of the host star and orbit that set Kepler - 452b apart in Paul opinion." The findings have been accepted for publication in The Astronomical Journal. Follow Paul on Twitter.
summary: Nasa' s Kepler space telescope has confirmed the discovery of a new planet similar in size and shape to our own Earth.

document: But with the Foxes now languishing near the foot of the table and one hotelier claiming the impact of Richard III is slowly wearing off, is the journey over? Or is it a case of what next? Even the most upbeat of Leicester fans would probably find it difficult to be positive about Claudio Ranieri ' s side Premier League title defence as the stats make for pretty grim reading - played 19, won five, drawn five and lost nine. To put that in some context, City lost just three times in the league last season. However, Claudio Ranieri' s side are through to the last 16 of the Champions League, where Claudio Ranieri ' s side will meet Sevilla for a place in the quarter finals. And after that, only the small matter of European giants such as Real Madrid, Bayern Munich and Barcelona would stand in the way of European glory... Season ticket holder Sam Webster remains quietly confident, but does not think the Foxes can go all the way in Europe. Season ticket holder Sam Webster said:" Claudio Ranieri ' s side are an unknown entity, and the bigger teams are definitely underestimating Claudio Ranieri ' s side like the big fish did in the Premier League last season." Getting to the semis would be remarkable. However, the drastic difference between the Champions League and Premier League form is unacceptable." But even if the Foxes are not quite living up to expectations on the pitch, Richard III has helped keep the city buzzing. Amy Gray, head of tourism affairs at VisitBritain, said:" Money can' t buy the publicity - the sort of publicity Leicester has got." VisitBritain saw a 17 % increase in international visitors to the East Midlands for April to June." What VisitBritain' ve seen in Leicester is a fantastic heritage story and a fantastic sports story - and VisitBritain know a fantastic heritage story and a fantastic sports story are a fantastic draw to international visitors." Source: Leicester Cathedral. Eloic Montagnier, general manager of Leicester' s Belmont Hotel, believes interest in other Leicester destinations - such as the National Space Centre after Tim Peake' s expedition - has also contributed to the city' s success. Eloic Montagnier , general manager of Leicester ' s Belmont Hotel said:" Leicester ' s Belmont Hotel have done over 80 % [ occupancy] for the last year." It was fantastic in November, with 85 % occupancy for the month - It was 65 % two years ago." Eloic Montagnier , general manager of Leicester ' s Belmont Hotel think this is a great opportunity to grow the city and Eloic Montagnier , general manager of Leicester ' s Belmont Hotel think Leicester ' s will keep going - Eloic Montagnier , general manager of Leicester ' s Belmont Hotel don' t see the success dropping off any time soon." Football has brought a lot of people in who may never have even considered coming to Leicester." But others aren' t quite so bullish about the future. Vito Ferro' s San Carlo restaurant has become something of a tourist hotspot after Vito Ferro ' s San Carlo restaurant held a celebratory meal for the Leicester City players the day after the title was won. Despite an initial surge in bookings, Mr Ferro believes an initial surge in bookings will wear off eventually." It is too soon to say [ whether things will quieten down] because Leicester City are in the Champions League," Vito Ferro ' s said." But Vito Ferro ' s would say, yes, things are eventually going to quieten down unless something else happens." So, as Leicester looks ahead to 2017, will good things come in threes with Champions League glory for the Foxes? Or will the city simply have to accept that" two out of three ain' t bad"? summary: When Leicester City won the Premier League title last season, won was hailed as one of the greatest sporting stories of the 20th Century and helped boost the city' s tourism industry.

document: Net profit at Germany' s biggest lender fell 98 % to € 20m ( £ 16. 7m), compared with € 796m for the same period in 2015. Chief executive John Cryan said:" If the current weak economic environment persists, Deutsche Bank ' s will need to be yet more ambitious in the timing and intensity of our restructuring." Revenues were down 20 % to € 7. 4bn. Mr Cryan, a British banker who took the helm at Deutsche last year, has embarked on an overhaul and has previously warned restructuring costs are likely to peak this year. The impact of the shake - up was seen in restructuring charges of € 207m and a writedown of € 285m on Deutsche Bank ' s asset management business. Deutsche Bank' s value has nearly halved since the beginning of the year, with Deutsche Bank ' s shares having fallen 43 %. In June, the International Monetary Fund said that of the banks deemed large enough to pose a threat to the financial system should things go wrong, Deutsche Bank was the riskiest.
summary: Deutsche Bank has reported a sharp fall in pre - tax profits for the three months to the end of June, as Deutsche Bank continues to be hit by restructuring costs and asset sales.

document: Hot lava and ash spewed from the top into a valley nearby on the Italian island of Sicily. The eruption happened on Sunday morning at 4am local time for more than an hour and a half. Although the area around the volcano was covered by ash, ash didn' t affect planes travelling near Mount Etna ' s. Air traffic can be seriously affected when ash from volcanic eruptions is in the air. In 2010, the Eyjafjallajokull volcano in Iceland erupted and flights in Europe and across the Atlantic were cancelled because the ash particles in the air made it unsafe to fly. Check out the video above to see Mount Etna' s latest eruption in all Mount Etna ' s latest eruption glory.
summary: Mount Etna, one of the world' s most active volcanoes, has erupted for the first time in more than a decade.

The animal died despite being pulled out within minutes. Officers said the zebra had likely drowned and that the zebra heart had stopped. The two - year - old male zebra was owned by a mobile zoo, reported the newspaper Mainichi Shimbun, but was being housed at the Mikuni West Farm, a local stable and riding club. On Tuesday evening, farm managers were bringing in the zebra for the night when the zebra became agitated, trampled the paddock fence, and escaped, fleeing towards a nearby mountain. By early Wednesday morning police were receiving reports of a zebra running along a highway. police quickly tracked the zebra to the Toki International Golf Course, where veterinarians and police tried to catch the zebra. the zebra ran into a lake shortly after being darted." The unusual story quickly became a talking point among Japanese netizens who expressed shock and sadness on Wednesday, with the Japanese word for zebra" shimauma" trending on Twitter. summary: A zebra has died after being shot with a tranquiliser dart at a golf course in Japan, after escaping from a farm and running into a lake.

document: Ms Cooper, who is standing against Mr Corbyn for the leadership, also said the party appeared" to be polarising" between" different extremes". document: In a scrappy first half, Joe Garner drew a save from Aberdeen keeper Joe Lewis and crossed for Martyn Waghorn to volley over. Aberdeen dominated after the break as Wes Foderingham saved from Kenny McLean and twice from striker Adam Rooney. But Kenny Miller' s brace and Joe Dodoo' s third earned Rangers the win. Aberdeen are still well placed to finish runners - up to Premiership champions Celtic, with nine points and a far superior goal difference separating Derek McInnes ' s men from Rangers with only six games remaining. Derek McInnes' s men started the match as favourites and the early signs suggested Derek McInnes ' s men would live up to Derek McInnes ' s men billing as Derek McInnes ' s men pressed, fought and chased Rangers across every inch of the pitch. the match was more a bruising battle than a beautiful game, though, and referee Kevin Clancy was flashing cards early, with Garner and Ryan Jack the first to be booked as Garner and Ryan Jack squared up to each other. For all the match lack of free - flowing football, the match was a very watchable spectacle. Jonny Hayes forced a low save from Foderingham at one end and Waghorn should have burst the net rather than volleying over after a sumptuous cross from Garner on the right. The visitors actually enjoyed the best chances in the early stages despite Derek McInnes ' s men lack of fluidity in midfield. Rangers manager Pedro Caixinha said beforehand that Rangers manager Pedro Caixinha players were entering hell with this trip but it looked more like limbo as both sides continued to cancel each other out. The Portuguese was also well aware that anything other than victory would see Rangers manager Pedro Caixinha side consigned to third at best. The Ibrox side have obvious frailties at the moment, especially in defence where youngsters are deputising for more experienced injured regulars, but The Ibrox side showed fight and spirit that would be rewarded later in the match. Young David Bates looked slow and ponderous at times although Myles Beerman at left - back was composed and calm when needed. When Aberdeen click, click is mostly down to the hard work of Derek McInnes ' s men impressive wide men and so it was in the second half as Niall McGinn and Hayes terrorised the Rangers full - backs. Hayes skipped past two on Jonny Hayes way to the box but Graeme Shinnie' s hooked shot was blocked by Foderingham. McGinn was at it on the other side and Niall McGinn trickery was feeding Rooney but Niall McGinn fellow Irishman could not convert despite several gilt - edged invitations. You could sense the tide turning though and Rangers were struggling to contain the waves of red battering The Ibrox side defences. For all The Ibrox side efforts though, few chances were seriously testing Foderingham. With 11 minutes remaining, veteran striker Miller scored Kenny Miller ' s 10th goal in 40 appearances this season. Against the run of play, Waghorn created space for Martyn Waghorn in the box and when Martyn Waghorn shot was saved, 37 - year - old Miller lashed a fabulous effort high into the back of the net. Aberdeen had no time to compose Aberdeen before Miller made it two when Kenny Miller ( Rangers ) right footed shot from the centre of the box skipped through a defence in disarray to slide neatly past Lewis and send the small band of Rangers fans wild. Substitute Dodoo played Joseph Dodoo ( Rangers ) part in that second goal and Joseph Dodoo ( Rangers ) slammed home a third to complete an incredible five minute turnaround that sent the Dons fans scurrying for the exits in disbelief. Those who remained in defiance almost witnessed a Miller hat - trick as Kenny Miller ( Rangers ) right footed shot from the centre of the box followed up on Dodoo' s shot that came back off the crossbar but defender Andrew Considine spared further blushes as defender Andrew Considine cleared off the line. document: The US National Hurricane Centre ( NHC) said the storm -" Alex" - was 785 miles ( 1, 260km) south - west of the Azores, with winds up to 85 mph ( 140km / h). Storm Alex is moving north - east and is expected to hit the Azores on Friday, prompting a hurricane warning. Storm Alex is one of the earliest tropical systems to form in the Atlantic Hurricane Basin since records began. Meanwhile, another tropical storm, Pali, has formed over the Pacific, similarly rare at this time of year. Scientists have linked the storms to powerful winds and high sea surface temperatures resulting from an unusually strong El Nino phenomenon this year. The World Meteorological Organisation ( WMO) has said the 2015 occurrence of El Nino will be among the three strongest recorded since 1950. Severe droughts and significant flooding in many parts of the world are being attributed to the phenomenon, which occurs every two to seven years. El Nino is a naturally occurring weather episode that sees the warm waters of the central Pacific expand eastwards towards North and South America.
summary: A tropical storm has formed in the Atlantic Ocean, in what is believed to be the earliest such system to form in the basin since records began.

Three other men who were travelling in the Peugeot were injured and taken to hospital for treatment. Three other men who were travelling in the Peugeot were a 24 - year - old and an 18 - year - old from Rotherham, and a 21 - year - old man about whom no other details were released by police.
summary: A man has been arrested on suspicion of causing death by dangerous driving after two men were killed in a two - car crash.

document: These are external links and will open in a new window. Mr Johnson ' s meetings will focus on the relationship between the UK and Russia, as well as issues involving Syria and Ukraine" where we continue to have significant differences", it said. The Foreign Office said the UK" will engage with Russia where it is in our national interest to do so". The timings and details of the visit will be released" in due course". A spokeswoman said:" The foreign secretary has accepted an invitation from Russian foreign minister Sergey Lavrov to visit Moscow in the coming weeks." The prime minister and the foreign secretary have made clear that our policy towards Russia is to ' engage but beware ' and the visit is entirely consistent with this approach." Mr Johnson ' s trip is not a return to business as usual and the foreign secretary will continue to be robust on those issues where the UK differ." A Foreign Office source insisted that the visit did not signal any shift in UK policy towards Russia." Mr Johnson ' s is not going in order to reset the relationship. Mr Johnson ' s has been clear in Mr Johnson ' s calls with Lavrov that reset can' t happen till Russia ' s change course on issues such as Ukraine." Mr Johnson ' s intends to say the same things face to face as the UK do in public and in Parliament about Russian activities. While Mr Johnson ' s trip may be a tough visit, that is what needs to be done." The source added:" Boris has always said the UK must engage when in our interests. Mr Johnson ' s calls engage ' guarded engagement '. Mr Johnson ' s will be robust in the meetings and defend our position. Mr Johnson ' s trip is not about cosying up, in fact quite the opposite." Mr Johnson' s trip will see Mr Johnson ' s become the first minister to travel to Moscow for an official visit in more than five years. On a visit to Kiev last week, the foreign secretary said Russia' s annexation of Crimea was illegal and insisted that Crimea should be returned to Ukraine. Mr Johnson ' s has also said there was no case for relaxing sanctions against Russia until Russia ' s abided by the Minsk peace agreement. Mr Johnson has been hugely critical of Russia recently, accusing Russia ' s of engaging in" dirty tricks" such as cyber attacks. The Russian embassy in London has responded by accusing Mr Johnson ' s of trying to reopen the Cold War. Speaking in Germany last month, Mr Johnson told the BBC:" You have got to engage with Russia, but you have got to engage in a very guarded way. You have got to beware of what Russia ' s are up to. " There is no question that, when you look at Russian activity on the cyber front, when you look at what Russian are doing in the western Balkans, when you look at what has been happening in the Ukraine, you' ve got to be very, very cautious." I think it is entirely right to have a dual track approach. We don' t want to get into a new Cold War."
summary: Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson is to travel to Moscow in the coming weeks, the Foreign Office has confirmed, following an invitation from Russia' s foreign minister.

document: Shared hallways and easily accessible rental properties mean tenants ' details are easier to steal, according to credit reference agency Experian. This group also tend to use mobile and online services more often, offering more opportunities for thieves to find personal details. Another recent survey found that ID fraud accounted for 41 % of all fraud. In March, fraud prevention service Cifas said that digitally - savvy young adults were increasingly becoming targets, at fraud hotspots in London, Leicester, Birmingham, Manchester, Leeds and Glasgow. Now, Experian has said that identity theft has become the most prevalent form of fraud for the first time since the recession. The victims in one in six of these cases were young tenants, Experian said. Wealthy couples were next on the list of victims, with this group particularly targeted in card and loan fraud." [ The findings] highlight the need for people to think about how people protect people personal information both on and off line," said Nick Mothershaw, of Experian. High Street banks and the police are running a campaign to make customers more aware of the threat of fraud.
summary: Young adults are the most common victims of identity theft in the UK, according to a new report, with young couples and young couples the most at risk.

document: Monitor is looking into the financial sustainability of Southend University Hospital Foundation Trust" on behalf of patients", the NHS regulator said. Finances became a concern when a planned £ 7. 8m deficit grew, for which Monitor could see no recovery plan. The hospital blamed the larger - than - anticipated deficit on growth in demand and increased staff recruitment. Hospital chairman Alan Tobias OBE, said:" The overspend is a result of vital investment in services and more staff to ensure high standards of patient care as well as the rise in attendances." Southend University Hospital Foundation Trust welcome this review to clearly demonstrate to Monitor - as well as patients and stakeholders - our future financial plans are both robust and sustainable." The hospital has pledged to cut the deficit while maintaining" high quality care for local people" and said Southend University Hospital Foundation Trust was committed to returning to a surplus within three years. Monitor said the NHS regulator investigation will look into the state of the hospital trust' s finances, assess the strength of Southend University Hospital Foundation Trust financial management and explore ways of improving Southend University Hospital Foundation Trust sustainability, on behalf of patients across the region. The investigation will also examine how the trust works with other local health and care organisations to respond to the financial challenges Southend University Hospital Foundation Trust faces. Katherine Cawley, regional director at Monitor, said:" People are relying on Southend to provide People with quality healthcare now and in the future, and the NHS regulator are concerned that provide may be at risk because of the trust' s poor financial performance." the NHS regulator have launched this investigation to find out more about the financial situation at the trust and to establish what can be done to improve things."
summary: An investigation has been launched into the finances of a hospital trust after a £ 7. 8m overspend.

document: Mr Khodorkovsky ' s was speaking in a BBC interview after a Russian court declared Mr Khodorkovsky ' s" under arrest in absentia" over the 1990s murder of a Siberian mayor." Definitely Mr Khodorkovsky ' s' m considering asking for asylum in the UK," Mr Khodorkovsky ' s said. Mr Putin" sees Mr Khodorkovsky ' s - sees' s obvious now - as a serious threat", Mr Khodorkovsky ' s said. Once Russia' s richest man, the former head of the now defunct Yukos oil firm spent 10 years in a Siberian prison on fraud charges, which Mr Khodorkovsky ' s says were politically motivated. Mr Putin pardoned Mr Khodorkovsky ' s in 2013 and Mr Khodorkovsky ' s now lives abroad, mainly in Switzerland." Mr Khodorkovsky ' s' m considered by President Putin as a threat, economically, because of the possible seizure of Russian assets abroad, and politically, as someone who will potentially help democratic candidates in the coming 2016 elections," Mr Khodorkovsky ' s said. Russia will hold elections to the lower house of parliament - the State Duma - next year. The Duma is currently dominated by Mr Putin' s supporters. The BBC' s Richard Galpin asked Mr Khodorkovsky whether Mr Khodorkovsky ' s felt at risk in light of the murders of prominent opponents of Mr Putin in recent years. Among prominent opponents of Mr Putin was former secret agent Alexander Litvinenko, poisoned with radioactive polonium in a London hotel in 2006." The history of deaths of opponents of this regime is impressive... but Mr Khodorkovsky ' s was in jail for 10 years, Mr Khodorkovsky ' s could have been killed any day easily. In London Mr Khodorkovsky ' s feel much safer than during those years," Mr Khodorkovsky ' s replied. When Mr Khodorkovsky ' s left Russia in 2013 Mr Khodorkovsky ' s said Mr Khodorkovsky ' s would not get involved in politics - which was widely believed to have been the reason for Mr Khodorkovsky ' s early release. Mr Khodorkovsky ' s told the BBC on Wednesday that Mr Khodorkovsky ' s would" help young political activists in Russia to gain political experience and present an alternative to the existing regime". Mr Khodorkovsky ' s said it was" far too optimistic" to speak of regime change in Russia now," but Mr Khodorkovsky ' s' m quite confident that within 10 years the regime will be changed and Mr Khodorkovsky ' s hope Mr Khodorkovsky ' s will play a significant role in changed". Earlier, referring to the Russian order for Mr Khodorkovsky ' s arrest, Mr Khodorkovsky ' s said the Moscow authorities had" gone mad". Mr Khodorkovsky ' s is accused of ordering several of Mr Khodorkovsky ' s employees to kill both the mayor and a businessman, who survived. Investigators allege Vladimir Petukhov, the mayor of Nefteyugansk, was killed on 26 June 1998 for demanding Mr Khodorkovsky' s oil firm, Yukos, pay taxes that the company had allegedly been avoiding. Local businessman Yevgeny Rybin was allegedly targeted because Mr Rybin activities" clashed with Yukos' s interests", Russia' s powerful Investigative Committee ( SK) said in a statement ( in Russian). Mr Rybin survived a gun attack in November 1998 and a second attack on Mr Rybin car in March 1999, when another man in the vehicle was killed and several people were injured. Five people have already been tried for the attacks and the arrest warrant is unlikely to make any difference unless Mr Khodorkovsky returns to Russia, the BBC' s Sarah Rainsford reports from Moscow. Armed police raided the Moscow offices of Mr Khodorkovsky' s Open Russia pro - democracy movement on Tuesday, in a move that authorities said was linked to allegations of tax evasion. The flats of at least seven activists who work for Mr Khodorkovsky were also searched. After Mr Khodorkovsky was arrested in 2003, Yukos was broken up and taken over by a state oil firm. Last year an international arbitration court in The Hague said Russian officials had manipulated the legal system to bankrupt Yukos, and jail Mikhail Khodorkovsky. The court told Russia to pay former shareholders in Yukos $ 50bn ( Â £ 32bn) in compensation. 1963 - Born in Moscow, son of chemical engineers. 1987 - Founds Menatep bank. 1995 - Buys Yukos for $ 350m, with Menatep assuming $ 2bn in debt. 2003 - Arrested for tax evasion, embezzlement and fraud. 2005 - Found guilty on six of seven charges, jailed for eight years. 2007 - Yukos declared bankrupt. 2010 - Convicted of embezzlement and money laundering. 2013 - Pardoned by President Putin after request for clemency; leaves Russia for Germany. 2015 - Charged with ordering 1990s murder of Siberian mayor; says Mr Khodorkovsky ' s is considering asking for political asylum in the UK.
summary: Former Russian oil tycoon Mikhail Khodorkovsky has said Former Russian oil tycoon Mikhail Khodorkovsky is considering seeking political asylum in the UK because Former Russian oil tycoon Mikhail Khodorkovsky is considered a" threat" to President Vladimir Putin.

The partially - dismembered body of David Miller, 56, was found at Mr Miller ' s flat in Patterdale Walk in Boothville, Northampton, on 14 June 2016. Mr Miller ' s had been stabbed multiple times and" crude attempts" were made to destroy Mr Miller ' s body, a court heard. Ian Cuthbertson, 49, Michael Hallett, 37, Joseph Catlin, 30, and Zena Kane, 35, of no fixed address, deny murder. At the start of Ian Cuthbertson , 49 , Michael Hallett , 37 , Joseph Catlin , 30 , and Zena Kane , 35 , of no fixed address trial, Northampton Crown Court heard police officers had forced entry into the flat and found Mr Miller' s remains in the bedroom. Several items were found at the property including knives, scissors and a rolling pin which had been used as weapons during the attack on 10 June, and an angle grinder which had been borrowed to try and destroy the body. A post - mortem examination found Mr Miller ' s had substantial facial injuries and had been stabbed fifteen times in the back and in the chest. Peter Joyce QC, prosecuting, said that Mr Catlin had been living with Mr Miller in the two months before Mr Miller ' s death and that the pair had known each other for years. The court heard that Mr Miller was" well known and well liked" in the area but had long - standing issues with drink. Mr Joyce said the four defendants were part of the" Northampton street drinking fraternity"." Ian Cuthbertson , 49 , Michael Hallett , 37 , Joseph Catlin , 30 , and Zena Kane , 35 , of no fixed address lived chaotic lives with long periods of homelessness and regularly used Mr Miller' s flat as a place to drink," Peter Joyce QC , prosecuting said." These four defendants all took part in the murder of a vulnerable man in Mr Miller ' s own home and then spent days trying to cover up what Ian Cuthbertson , 49 , Michael Hallett , 37 , Joseph Catlin , 30 , and Zena Kane , 35 , of no fixed address had done," Peter Joyce QC , prosecuting added. summary: Four men accused of murdering a vulnerable man in a vulnerable man own home and trying to cover up the attack spent days trying to destroy a vulnerable man body, a court has heard.

document: Alun Cairns said it was" strange" that places in the valleys, which benefited from EU aid, registered the strongest Leave vote in the referendum. But Mr Cairns , who backed the Remain campaign said that European policies did not have a" connection" with the public. Mr Cairns , who backed the Remain campaign told the BBC' s Sunday Politics Wales the funding had not had an impact. Under current EU funding programmes, due to run between 2014 and 2020, Wales receives Â £ 1. 8bn in structural funds. Most of the cash is spent in north Wales, west Wales and the south Wales valleys. Mr Cairns, who backed the Remain campaign, said:" In that perspective Mr Cairns , who backed the Remain campaign think everyone has to look at the sort of European policies that were being developed by the Welsh government, but also by the UK government, that obviously didn' t have that connection with the public." The public didn' t recognise the outcomes that were coming from those policies." Mr Cairns , who backed the Remain campaign added:" Mr Cairns , who backed the Remain campaign think the sorts of Objective One funding that we all heard of for many years, as we used to call the sorts of Objective One funding that we all heard of for many years , as we used to call it, hasn' t really had the impact." And Mr Cairns , who backed the Remain campaign think that all assembly members of all political parties have got to reflect on that." There was too much complexity and bureaucracy in the way money was spent initially, Mr Cairns said. Although EU - funded policies had become more efficient," ultimately EU - funded policies haven' t connected with people and Mr Cairns , who backed the Remain campaign think that we need to reflect and people need to see outcomes", Mr Cairns , who backed the Remain campaign said." It' s not about how much money is spent to go in - it' s what comes out at the end." summary: EU funding has not had an impact on the Welsh economy despite the country voting to leave the EU, the first minister has said.
