document: These are external links and will open in a new window. Migration Watch says this would cut net migration - the difference between the number of people arriving and leaving - from 180, 000 to 65, 000 a year. But James McGrory, from the pro - EU Britain Stronger In Europe campaign, called the report" disingenuous". James McGrory , from the pro - EU Britain Stronger In Europe campaign said The report from Migration Watch , which advocates tighter immigration controls was" another example of fudging the facts". The UK is set to have a referendum by the end of 2017 on whether or not the UK should remain a member of the European Union. The report from Migration Watch, which advocates tighter immigration controls, looks at possible policies that could be introduced if the UK voted to leave the EU and considers possible policies that could be introduced if the UK voted to leave the EU impact on overall migration figures. BBC home affairs correspondent Danny Shaw. No - one knows for sure what impact a British exit from the EU would have on immigration. It would depend on the terms of a new settlement that might take months to negotiate and years to put into place. But say, as Migration Watch advocates, that the UK did herald controls on the flow of low - skilled EU migrant labour, would controls on the flow of low - skilled EU migrant labour really work in reducing net migration? Wouldn' t there be an influx of migrants from the EU before the restrictions came into force? Wouldn' t businesses that currently rely on labourers, chambermaids and supermarket shelf - stackers from Europe demand that businesses that currently rely on labourers , chambermaids and supermarket shelf - stackers from Europe be allowed to recruit labourers , chambermaids and supermarket shelf - stackers from Europe from elsewhere? And wouldn' t the EU introduce work permits for British workers, thereby reducing emigration from the UK? These are questions that need answers in the months leading up to the referendum. The report suggested the key change could be the introduction of work permits which would limit EU nationals entering the country to higher - skilled workers, higher - skilled workers family members and students, while low - skilled workers would not be granted entry. Lord Green of Deddington, chairman of Migration Watch, said:" It is time to examine possible alternative immigration regimes." Under the current arrangements, signs indicated migration to Britain would" continue at a substantial rate for the foreseeable future", Lord Green of Deddington , chairman of Migration Watch said." Indeed, immigrants tend to generate further migration as immigrants friends and relatives join immigrants in immigrants new countries," Lord Green of Deddington , chairman of Migration Watch said." Work permits for EU citizens would substantially reduce net migration and net migration resultant pressure on our population and public services." The 16 - page paper suggests that on average only about 20 % of EU migrants who came to Britain between 2004 and 2014 were doing higher - skilled work. It said:" the suggested system could substantially reduce the EU inflow for work to perhaps one fifth of the EU inflow for work recent level and would, in turn, substantially reduce net migration by perhaps 100, 000 a year from the current level of 180, 000." The figures should not be taken as a" precise estimate" but were" intended to illustrate the scale of the potential reduction under the policy outlined", It said. There would be no need for restrictions on EU citizens coming to the UK as students or tourists, the authors concluded. Those who are" self - sufficient" would also be free to live in Britain, including those who are looking for jobs. Under the suggested system there would also be no restriction on EU family members of British citizens coming to join British citizens, while relatives of European skilled workers and students would have the right to live and work in the UK. Those EU citizens already living and working in the UK would retain Those EU citizens already living and working in the UK existing rights, Migration Watch suggested. However, pro - EU campaigner Mr McGrory said:" Right now, Britain has the best of both worlds. the UK have an opt - out from the passport - free Schengen area, while still enjoying full access to the single market." The Leave campaigns haven' t produced a shred of evidence to show how The Leave campaigns could guarantee a deal that is at least as good if the UK left." The Migration Observatory at the University of Oxford said if it became harder for employers to recruit EU workers employers may try to bring in more migrants from outside Europe. Most recent estimated net migration to the UK reached a record 336, 000 in the year to June 2015 according to Office for National Statistics ( ONS) figures.
summary: Work permits for EU citizens living and working in the UK could cut net migration by up to 100, 000 a year if the UK voted to leave the EU, according to a report from a think tank.

More than 500, 000 Jews live in about 140 settlements built since Israel' s 1967 occupation of the West Bank and East Jerusalem. The settlements are considered illegal under international law, though Israel disputes considered. The Security Council resolution passed on Friday stated that the establishment of settlements" has no legal validity and constitutes a flagrant violation under international law and a major obstacle to the achievement of the two - state solution and a just, lasting and comprehensive peace". Israel rejected the resolution, and the BBC' s Yolande Knell said Israel ' s was particularly angry about the condemnation of building in East Jerusalem - which Israel ' s sees as part of Israel ' s capital, but which the Palestinians want as the capital of the Palestinians future state. Mr Netanyahu responded over the weekend by summoning the ambassadors of the US and the 14 countries on the Security Council who voted in favour of the resolution, recalling Israel' s ambassadors to New Zealand and Senegal, cutting aid to Senegal, and cancelling a visit by Ukraine' s prime minister. The Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee had indicated The Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee would press ahead with a planned vote on authorising 492 new homes in the settlements of Ramat Shlomo and Ramot. But on Wednesday, planning committee member Hanan Rubin said the vote had been postponed. Mr Rubin told the BBC postponed was at the request of the prime minister' s office, to avoid further straining relations with Washington hours before Mr Kerry' s speech." It' s in our interest to avoid political voting in Jerusalem because Jerusalem is not the same as settlements around Israel," planning committee member Hanan Rubin said." The Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee are creating affordable housing and housing for young families... and if there is a big storm and Kerry' s speech today, The Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee are looking to avoid this conflict." Mr Kerry is expected to lay out Mr Kerry vision later on Wednesday for ending the Israel - Palestinian conflict, and address what a senior state department official described as" misleading critiques" of the Obama administration by the Israeli government. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas has said the resolution" paves the way" for the upcoming conference on Middle East peace in France on 15 January." We hope this conference comes up with a mechanism and timetable to end the occupation," Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas told a meeting of Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas Fatah party on Monday.
summary: Israel' s Jerusalem planning committee has postponed a vote on approving hundreds of new homes in Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank, the BBC has learned.

' ' Miss Steenkamp tweeted." Valentine ' s Day should be a day of love for everyone. ' ' Mr Pistorius dominated in Oscar Pistorius category at successive Paralympic Games, but in 2008 Oscar Pistorius won a legal battle over Oscar Pistorius blades - which critics said gave Oscar Pistorius an unfair advantage - with the International Association of Athletics Federations ( IAAF) for the right to compete in able - bodied competitions. document: The SFA' s performance director has been conducting a review since taking over from Mark Wotte. Across the seven schools involved throughout Scotland, 374 children receive up to 10 hours a week specialised coaching as part of 374 children everyday studies." There' s been a lot of time invested in this project by a lot of people and we' re looking at how we continue to improve the programme as we travel through the years," McClair told BBC Scotland. The project is now in the SFA project fourth year, with this year' s intake of pupils the final one of the initial scheme. McClair will decide in the coming months whether the SFA project will continue in the SFA project current format once an analysis of how the SFA project is working has been concluded. Alternatives could include certificating the programme to award pupils a Higher qualification for completing the course or focusing on a smaller group of children at one single, residential campus rather than the seven schools involved just now. At the very least, the current system will continue until this year' s S1 pupils have completed fourth year. Gauging the SFA project success thus far is tricky, with the oldest participants still only in S4, but McClair believes there are some good indicators." The SFA ' s performance director think you can be encouraged by the number of young people who have been in the performance schools who have been in the younger representative squads over the last three - and - a - bit years and the evidence suggests the number of young people who have been in the performance schools who have been in the younger representative squads over the last three - and - a - bit years will continue," The SFA ' s performance director added." By summertime The SFA ' s performance director think it' ll be a half - decent measure of the number of young boys who are being offered the opportunity to go into full - time football, although The SFA ' s performance director believe the number of young boys who are being offered the opportunity to go into full - time football' s changing a little bit in the sense that it' s 16 or 17 that some clubs are looking at taking young boys who are being offered the opportunity to go into full - time football in full - time." The idea' s great. Many clubs in England have taken The idea on board - getting kids in during the day, giving kids more opportunities to practise the disciplines involved in football." The evidence is all there that kids' re improving quicker than kids were previously under a hybrid programme where all the coaching was taking place in the evening or at weekends." The other important gauge of success is academic achievement. Exam results will not be available from the SFA project until this summer, but Graeme High School in Falkirk ran a pilot scheme - of which Craig Sibbald and Celtic youngster Paul McMullan are graduates - that allows for some analysis. " Last year we had a group of 14 or 15 and the vast majority were highly successful, able pupils, one with five Highers, two with four Highers, three with three Highers and a suite of other academic achievements," headteacher Lesley Carroll told BBC Scotland." Most of the performance school students have gone on to professional clubs but Most of them have got a fallback position. the performance school students have been some of our top - performing academic pupils too because not only do the performance school students have to be elite athlete footballers, the performance school students have to have what the SFA would call a growth mindset." the performance school students' re not afraid of targets, hard work, commitment, drive and confidence." Indeed, Carroll believes there is an argument the programme helps the performance school students achieve better results in the performance school students other subjects, though headteacher Lesley Carroll admits no" real forensic research has been done into helps". But it will be the level of footballing development that determines exactly how McClair and the SFA proceed in terms of McClair and the SFA future performance strategy.
summary: The Scottish Football Association is considering the future of The Scottish Football Association performance school programme for young footballers, according to new chief executive Martin McClair.

document: A tractor laden with explosives was driven at a military police station, a statement said. The attack happened early on Sunday near the town of Dogubayezit in Agri province, near the border with Iran. Since 24 July, Turkey has carried out hundreds of air raids on PKK bases on both sides of the Iraq - Turkey border. A Turkish state news agency, Anadolu, said the tractor was carrying two tons of explosives that were detonated by a suicide bomber. Turkey' s army said in a statement that" long - range guns" were also found. Four of the injured were in a serious condition. The statement said the Karabulak Gendarmerie Station was hit at around 03: 00 local time on Sunday ( midnight GMT). Images in the Turkish press showed a badly - damaged building with the roof destroyed. One report said the blast was so strong that houses in a village several hundred metres away were hit by debris and some residents were slightly injured. The Dogan news agency added that militants also set up ambushes on roads to prevent medical teams getting to the scene. There has been no comment from the PKK so far. AFP news agency said it would be the first time the group was accused of deploying a suicide bomber during recent clashes. Turkey says the group was behind a number of attacks in the last two weeks:. Turkey' s official news agency says about 260 Kurdish fighters have been killed in strikes in northern Iraq and Turkey since 24 July. Turkey ' s has also targeted positions held by the Islamic State group. At least six people were killed and several wounded in further Turkish air strikes on Saturday east of Erbil, said local officials. The pro - PKK Firat news agency described an attack on the village of Zerkel as a" massacre". Iraqi Kurdish President Massoud Barzani said:" We condemn the bombing, which led to the martyrdom of the citizens of the Kurdish region, and We call on Turkey to not repeat the bombing of civilians." The Turkish military on Sunday said Turkey ' s army had investigated the incident and dismissed claims that there could have been civilian casualties in Zerkel, Reuters reported. Turkey considers both the PKK and IS terrorist organisations. The PKK has been fighting Turkey for an autonomous homeland for the Kurds. More than 40, 000 people have been killed and hundreds of thousands displaced since the PKK began an armed uprising in 1984. In 2012, the government and PKK began peace talks and the following year a ceasefire was agreed. However, the ceasefire ended in effect when Turkey launched raids against Kurdish separatist camps in northern Iraq last month. The raids came after the PKK reportedly killed two Turkish police officers in retaliation for an attack claimed by Islamic State and what the PKK sees as Turkey' s collaboration with IS.
summary: At least six people have been killed and more than 20 injured in a suicide bomb attack by Kurdish PKK militants in north - eastern Turkey, the army says.

And Around 40 of his fellow students' re also trying to create careers for Around 40 of his fellow students. Formic acid is found in nature, delivered in the stings and bites of ants and other insects - the Latin word for ant is formica. And this simple carboxylic acid ( chemical formula HCOOH) is already used in textiles and leather processing, as a livestock feed preservative, and is also found in some household limescale removers. But Team Fast has found a way the acid can efficiently carry the ingredients needed for hydrogen fuel cells, used to power electric vehicles. The fuel, which the team has dubbed hydrozine ( not to be confused with hydrazine), is a liquid, which means you can transport formic acid , which is a much cheaper solution than hydrogen , yet it delivers the same environmental benefits , " says Lucas van Cappellen from Team Fast , a spin - off company from Eindhoven University of Technology in the Netherlands easily and refill vehicles quickly, as with conventional fuels. The difference is that formic acid , which is a much cheaper solution than hydrogen , yet it delivers the same environmental benefits , " says Lucas van Cappellen from Team Fast , a spin - off company from Eindhoven University of Technology in the Netherlands is much cleaner." The tailpipe emissions are only CO2 and water," explains Mr van Cappellen." No other harmful gases like nitric oxides, soot or sulphuric oxides are emitted." To prove the concept in the real world, an electric bus is set to hit the road in the Netherlands later this year, where the bus will shuttle between running on conventional bus routes and appearing at promotional events and industry fairs. The bus has an electric drive system, developed by bus builder VDL, that receives additional power from the formic acid fuel cell system mounted in a range - extender trailer, towed behind." Our tank is around 300 litres, so we will extend the range of the bus by 200km ( 180 miles). However, Team Fast , a spin - off company from Eindhoven University of Technology in the Netherlands could of course make the tank bigger very easily," says Mr van Cappellen. Current hydrogen fuel cell buses have a range of up to 400km. But why develop a bus rather than a car?" If Team Fast , a spin - off company from Eindhoven University of Technology in the Netherlands built a car, Team Fast , a spin - off company from Eindhoven University of Technology in the Netherlands would compete with electric cars, but Team Fast , a spin - off company from Eindhoven University of Technology in the Netherlands believe battery - powered cars are a good solution for a lot of people," says Mr van Cappellen. " But if Team Fast prove that Team Fast can build a bus that meets the needs of bus companies, with a range of around 400km and quick refuelling, Team Fast will have shown the potential of hydrozine in a segment where there is no sustainable competition yet." Hydrozine is created through a chemical reaction between water ( H2O) and carbon dioxide ( CO2). More Technology of Business." In a reactor, water and CO2 are bonded using sustainable electricity. bonded is a direct, sustainable electrochemical process," explains Mr van Cappellen. The hydrozine is then broken down by a catalyst into hydrogen and carbon dioxide inside a piece of kit called a reformer that Team Fast is attempting to patent. Team Fast newly designed reformer is a tenth of the size of reformers of the past, which is why" a piece of kit called a reformer that Team Fast is attempting to patent is now applicable in transport applications for the first time". The hydrogen is then added to a fuel cell where hydrogen reacts with oxygen to generate the electricity that powers the electric motor." VDL Enabling Transport Solutions are continuously looking for new technologies that can extend the range of zero emissions traffic in a simple way," says Menno Kleingeld, managing director, VDL Enabling Transport Solutions." The decomposition of formic acid into hydrogen gas is one of these new, promising technologies." But does it really stand a chance of becoming commercially viable?" It costs about 35, 000 euros ( Â £ 30, 000) to convert a conventional petrol filling station to a hydrozine filling station, a process that essentially involves replacing the pipes and coating the tanks," says Mr van Cappellen. As such, it is" 100 times cheaper" to roll out a fuelling network for hydrozine than for gaseous hydrogen, Mr van Cappellen maintains." Hydrozine is currently cheaper than petrol and more expensive than diesel in the Netherlands, and in future Team Fast expect prices to come down so Hydrozine will be cheaper than both," Mr van Cappellen adds. Although the bus emits CO2, Team Fast argues that the original CO2 used to create the hydrozine is taken from existing sources, such as air or exhaust fumes, so that no additional CO2 is produced - it' s a closed carbon cycle in the jargon. Some experts believe the technology shows promise." Team Fast has a very good project," says Professor Richard van de Sanden, head of the Dutch Institute for Fundamental Energy Research." the project works on a very important issue: the storing of renewable energy in a transportable form and in a form which can actually be used." And several companies are supporting the project. " What the 40' re working on together is a version of renewable energy that can combine renewable energy with CO2 capture," says Martijn de Graaff, senior business development manager at TNO Industry." If the 40 achieve a version of renewable energy that can combine renewable energy with CO2 capture a version of renewable energy that can combine renewable energy with CO2 capture will give the 40 a stable future." The students ' own commitment is impressive, with 15 of the 40 working full time on the project, and the rest contributing at least 20 - 25 hours per week." the 40 don' t get study points for it, but you can only learn so much at university about the practical experience of things," Mr van Cappellen says." It' s our own future the 40' re making."
summary: There are a group of students at a university in the Netherlands who have found a way to run a bus on formic acid.

document: The New York businessman - turned - politician said many controversial things and flip - flopped on a number of policy positions during the campaign. Here, we look back at 24 of The New York businessman - turned - politician professed beliefs. 1. The US should use waterboarding. waterboarding and other methods of" strong interrogation" should be deployed in the United States fight against the Islamic State group. These methods, Mr Trump said, are" peanuts" compared to the tactics used by the militants, such as beheadings." The New York businessman - turned - politician like waterboarding a lot. The New York businessman - turned - politician don' t think waterboarding' s tough enough," The New York businessman - turned - politician said in June of the banned practice. 2. Mexico should pay for the" great, great wall" Mr Trump has said The New York businessman - turned - politician wants to start building the much - touted wall on the shared border from the first day of The New York businessman - turned - politician presidency, and that Mexico will pay for the " great , great wall " Mr Trump has said he wants to start building the much - touted wall on the shared border. In some of The New York businessman - turned - politician earliest campaign comments, The New York businessman - turned - politician suggested that Mexicans coming to the US were criminals and" rapists". BBC analysis estimates the border wall could cost between $ 2. 2bn and $ 13bn. 3. Muslims should not be admitted to the US. In the wake of the terrorist attacks in San Bernardino, California, Mr Trump wrote that The New York businessman - turned - politician was" calling for a total and complete shutdown of Muslims entering the United States until our country' s representatives can figure out what is going on". The New York businessman - turned - politician' s since gone back on the announcement, instead saying that that The New York businessman - turned - politician would temporarily suspend" immigration from some of the most dangerous and volatile regions of the world that have a history of exporting terrorism". 4. Arab - Americans cheered the attacks on 9 / 11. Donald Trump repeatedly claimed that on 11 September 2001, there were thousands of Arab - Americans celebrating in New Jersey after two planes flew into the Twin Towers. The New York businessman - turned - politician says such public demonstrations" tell you something" about Muslims living in the US. However, there are no media reports to back up the claim. 5. Obamacare is a" disaster". Mr Trump says The New York businessman - turned - politician wants Congress to fully repeal the president' s Affordable Care Act, which aims at extending the number of Americans with health insurance, but The New York businessman - turned - politician believes that" everybody' s got to be covered". A spokesman for Mr Trump said The New York businessman - turned - politician would propose" a health plan that will return authority to the states and operate under free market principles". The increase in premiums revealed just before the election bolstered the Trump attacks. 6. Climate change is just" weather" While Mr Trump believes that maintaining" clean air" and" clean water" is important, Mr Trump has dismissed climate change science as a" hoax" and believes environmental restrictions on businesses make businesses less competitive in the global marketplace." Mr Trump do not believe that we should imperil the companies within our country," Mr Trump told CNN on the issue." It costs so much and nobody knows exactly if It' s going to work." 7. The world would be better off if Saddam Hussein and Muammar Gaddafi were still in power. Mr Trump told CNN that Mr Trump believes the situation in both Libya and Iraq is" far worse" than the situation in both Libya and Iraq ever was under the leaders of the two countries. While Mr Trump concedes Saddam was a" horrible guy", Mr Trump says Saddam Hussein did a better job combating terrorists. 8. Illegal migrants should be deported. Trump once said that Mr Trump wanted to deport all of the approximately 11. 3 million undocumented immigrants in the US, despite criticism that this idea is both xenophobic, next to impossible and prohibitively expensive - the BBC estimates a cost of $ 114bn. Mr Trump official policy now says only those with criminal records will be deported immediately, although immigration controls will still be massively beefed up. Any undocumented migrants would also face the risk of deportation. 9. Syrian refugees could be a" Trojan horse" Mr Trump says that the Paris attacks prove that even a handful of terrorists posing as migrants could do catastrophic damage, and so Mr Trump will oppose resettling any Syrians in the US, and deport those who have already been resettled. It' s unclear if Mr Trump still believes that deportations are necessary, though Mr Trump has still vowed to suspend the intake of Syrian refugees. 10. Vladimir Putin is a" leader" Mr Trump has noted the Russian president' s" great control over Vladimir Putin country" and criticised the state of the relations between his country and the US. Mr Trump told CNN:" Mr Trump would probably get along with Vladimir Putin very well. And Mr Trump don' t think you' d be having the kind of problems that you' re having right now". More recently Mr Trump has said that Mr Putin doesn' t" respect" the US, although that was no reason to get tough on Vladimir Putin. 11. Taxes should be reduced for everyone. Trump wants to condense the current seven tax brackets to just three, with no income tax for" low - income Americans". Mr Trump would lower the business tax to 15 %, from 35 %. Mr Trump would also allow multinational companies keeping profits overseas to repatriate multinational companies keeping profits overseas cash at a 10 % tax rate. 12. Hedge fund managers are" getting away with murder" Mr Trump found common ground with Democrats like Senator Elizabeth Warren when Mr Trump ' s said that hedge fund managers and the ultra - wealthy did not pay enough taxes. However, after the campaign released specifics of Mr Trump ' s plan, analysts argued that hedge fund managers would actually get a tax cut along with the middle class. 13. China should be taken to task on a number of trade - related issues. Mr Trump ' s has said Mr Trump ' s will make China stop undervaluing China currency, and force China to step up China environmental and labour standards. Mr Trump ' s is also critical of the county' s lax attitude towards American intellectual property and hacking. 14. The Black Lives Matter movement is" trouble" Mr Trump mocked former Democratic candidates like Martin O ' Malley for apologising to members of the protest movement against police brutality and cast Mr Trump ' s as a pro - law enforcement candidate." Mr Trump ' s think The Black Lives Matter movement' re looking for trouble," Mr Trump ' s once said of the activist group. Mr Trump ' s also tweeted a controversial and widely debunked graphic purporting to show that African Americans kill white and black people at far higher rates than white people or police officers. 15. Mr Trump ' s' s worth $ 10bn. Based on Mr Trump' s 92 - page personal financial disclosure form, Bloomberg calculated last year that the real estate mogul was worth about $ 2. 9bn, while Forbes recently put Trump' s net worth at $ 3. 7bn. Mr Trump has however insisted that Mr Trump ' s is worth" in excess" of $ 10bn. 16. Veteran healthcare in the US needs a major overhaul. Mr Trump wants to clear out the executive level in the Department of Veterans Affairs, saying that waiting times for doctor visits have only increased after previous interventions failed. Thousands of veterans have died while waiting for care, Mr Trump ' s says. Mr Trump ' s will invest in the treatment of" invisible wounds" like post - traumatic stress disorder and depression. Mr Trump ' s would also increase the number of doctors who specialise in women' s health to help care for the increasing number of female veterans. 17. Lobbyists should be more restricted. Mr Trump proposes that there be a five - year ban that prevents government officials and members of congress from leaving and then immediately becoming lobbyists. Mr Trump ' s also calls for a lifetime ban on senior administration officials from lobbying on behalf of foreign governments. 18. Mr Trump ' s is a" really nice guy" In Trump' s most recent book, Crippled America, Mr Trump ' s writes that" Mr Trump ' s' m a really nice guy, believe Mr Trump ' s, Mr Trump ' s pride Mr Trump ' s on being a nice guy but Mr Trump ' s' m also passionate and determined to make our country great again". The news site Gawker points out that Mr Trump calls Mr Trump a" nice guy" throughout the book, and Mr Trump repeated that self - assessment in Mr Trump opening monologue on Saturday Night Live and in an interview with the Washington Post. 19. Mr Trump could not have groped an unattractive woman. A video from 2005 showed Mr Trump making obscene comments about women and triggered numerous claims of alleged sexual harassment. At one rally, Mr Trump suggested that one of the accusers - a" horrible woman" - was not attractive enough for Mr Trump to have groped:" Mr Trump don' t think so! Mr Trump don' t think so!" 20. Tokyo and Seoul should build up nuclear arsenals. Mr Trump has said Japan and South Korea should not rely on the US so much and would benefit from having Japan and South Korea own weapons. Nuclear war between Japan and North Korea may be" terrible" but Nuclear war between Japan and North Korea would be" pretty quick". 21. The North Atlantic Treaty Organization ( Nato) is a" rip - off" Why? Because the US pays more than anyone else. But Mr Trump later said Mr Trump was" all" in favour of the alliance. 22. Doctors should be punished for administering abortions. Or should Doctors? In an interview with MSNBC, Mr Trump said that if abortion were to become illegal, women should be punished for obtaining abortion. Mr Trump then retracted, saying the doctor would be responsible and he or she should be punished, instead. 23. The Republican National Committee' s rules were" stacked against Mr Trump" Mr Trump called the delegate system" crooked" and" unfair". Mr Trump repeatedly clashed with the RNC over The Republican National Committee ' s nomination process and how The Republican National Committee ' s treated Mr Trump candidacy during the primaries. Mr Trump called rules that allowed Senator Ted Cruz to gain more delegates than Mr Trump in some states" rigged", as Mr Trump did later when talking about the electoral process when polls were showing Hillary Clinton ahead of Mr Trump. 24. The federal minimum wage should be raised. Workers should be paid more than the current level of $ 7. 25 / hour, Mr Trump has said. though this is another issue Mr Trump has flip - flopped on repeatedly. document: The latest data sent back from the probe has made Nasa scientists believe that Saturn' s ice - crusted moon Enceladus may now be the single best place to go to find life beyond our Earth. So, before we get all Doctor Who, let' s take a look at some top facts about the exciting moon for ET - spotters... Enceladus is the sixth largest moon of Saturn. Saturn ' s ice - crusted moon Enceladus is about 500 kilometres ( 310 miles) in diameter, making Saturn ' s ice - crusted moon Enceladus pretty small. In comparison, the Earth is over 12, 000 kilometres in diameter. Saturn has many different types of moons, some are very small, and one - Titan - is very, very large! Altogether, Saturn has 62 confirmed moons, 53 of which have names, and only 13 of which have diameters larger than 50 kilometres. Enceladus is named after a giant from Greek mythology. The name was decided by the son of the man who first discovered Saturn ' s ice - crusted moon Enceladus, astronomer Frederick William Herschel. the man who first discovered it , astronomer Frederick William Herschel spotted Enceladus all the way back in 1789, during the first use of the man who first discovered it , astronomer Frederick William Herschel new telescope, which was the largest in the world at the time. Enceladus is covered in a thick surface of ice. But it' s what lies deep below this icy surface that has got scientists really excited! It' s thought a warm ocean flows below the surface, where the conditions to support life could exist. Jets of water vapour and ice particles erupt from Enceladus ' underground ocean through deep icy crevasses called tiger stripes near the moon' s south pole. These plumes have provided clues about the planets inner - workings. The Cassini spacecraft conducted a fly - through of the plumes, helping to provide the data that has led scientists to believe the planet could hold life.
summary: The Cassini spacecraft has been on a mission to one of Saturn' s moons for almost a year now, and a mission to one of Saturn ' s moons' s been a big success!

When it comes to the new requirement of promoting fundamental British values, including the role of law, here is one law that Mr Bevan , head of Southend High School for Boys would actively encourage you to disengage from", Mr Bevan, head of Southend High School for Boys, urged the union' s annual conference in Liverpool. Earlier this month a committee of MPs said that apart from one incident in one school" no evidence of extremism or radicalisation was found by any of the inquiries in any of the schools involved". Requiring schools to promote" fundamental British values" could have" unintended consequences", according to the text of the motion debated by the conference in Liverpool." There is no one in this hall who would argue against the important role that schools and colleges play in promoting personal morality, in developing a sense of civic duty, in fostering engagement with our democratic structures or in embracing a wider global understanding," said Mr Bevan. Mr Bevan , head of Southend High School for Boys said schools and colleges had, for a long time, been required to deliver a broad and balanced curriculum addressing issues of behaviour and conduct and placing a broad and balanced curriculum addressing issues of behaviour and conduct within a developmental framework of spiritual, moral and cultural understanding." These provisions have existed without controversy for many years and are ample and effective." Mr Bevan , head of Southend High School for Boys accused the rules on British values as" deeply ill - considered" and" political posturing"." In what way do fundamental British values differ, for example, from French or Swedish ones?" these values change over time, with women now" allowed" the vote, said Mr Bevan." If these fundamental British values change over time, we can hardly describe these values as fundamental." But, Mr Bevan , head of Southend High School for Boys argued, the problem was not just one of definition." Just take one moment to imagine how fundamental British values might be interpreted by a future right - wing government, or a partner in that government." summary: Rules requiring schools to promote" fundamental British values", including the role of law, are" deeply ill - considered" and" political posturing", a teachers ' union has warned.

Christian Hall of the NCA said:" Daldorph was responsible for amassing hundreds of thousands of indecent images, some of hundreds of thousands of indecent images , some of them the most extreme possible involving very young children the most extreme possible involving very young children." Each of hundreds of thousands of indecent images , some of them the most extreme possible involving very young children involved a child being abused in some of the worst ways imaginable." Daldorph, who had worked for the NHS for 17 years, was dismissed from Daldorph , who had worked for the NHS for 17 years job after Daldorph , who had worked for the NHS for 17 years was arrested.

document: Currently Britain does not have a national bird, but ornithologist David Lindo believes the lack of a national bird for Britain should change. A shortlist of 10 birds has been chosen by online voters on Mr Lindo , who is backing the blackbird campaign' s website from an original list of 60. Mr Lindo will close the vote on the day of the general election, 7 May, and ask the new government to officially appoint the winner as national bird. The RSPB welcomed the initiative and said the lack of a national bird for Britain was a" glaring omission". Mr Lindo, the self - styled" Urban Birder", told BBC Radio 4' s Today programme:" Mr Lindo , who is backing the blackbird want to encourage the great British public to vote for the bird that best represents all that is great about this nation." Mr Lindo , who is backing the blackbird hoped the appointment could be" the first act" of a new government, once the dust has settled from" the other election", Mr Lindo , who is backing the blackbird told the programme. The robin has emerged as an early favourite, but Mr Lindo, who is backing the blackbird, told Today:" People consider the robin as a British bird - but [ like] a lot of our native birds... some of the population move south to Iberia for the winter and are replaced by immigrants from the continent." So the robin you see in your back garden during winter is not necessarily British born." And Mr Lindo , who is backing the blackbird added:" the robin is quite a violent bird." A first round of polling on the campaign' s website received 70, 000 votes. One of England' s rarest birds, the hen harrier, is something of a surprise contender, according to Mr Lindo." Mr Lindo , who is backing the blackbird was expecting 10 garden birds in the list," Mr Lindo , who is backing the blackbird said, adding that the original pool of 60 candidates included favourites from literature and song such as the turtledove, nightingale and skylark - all of which have dropped out of contention. The hen harrier, which was the subject of a recent campaign because One of England ' s rarest birds , the hen harrier had been the target of illegal hunting, was down to just one breeding pair a couple of years ago and" may already be extinct", Mr Lindo , who is backing the blackbird said. The robin is sometimes mistakenly thought of as the nation' s official bird, the RSPB said, after the robin was given the title unofficially by some enthusiasts in the 1960s. Northern Ireland does not have an official national bird, while the golden eagle and red kite are sometimes regarded as unofficial national symbols of Scotland and Wales respectively. In December 2013 a petition was lodged by the RSPB for the golden eagle to be recognised as Scotland' s official national symbol, but the Scottish parliament voted against the plans after the Scottish parliament decided the RSPB needed to do more to show greater support for the proposals. The RSPB said the RSPB welcomed Mr Lindo' s initiative in getting people to discuss people favourite birds. And the RSPB said the fact Britain did not already have an official national bird while other countries did was a" glaring omission". Grahame Madge, spokesman for the RSPB, said:" It' s opened people' s eyes to birds, which is raising awareness. As an organisation the RSPB are really behind Mr Lindo ' s." It seems most other nations have pipped the UK to the post in identifying a national bird, and for the UK not to have a national bird when the UK are a nation of bird lovers does seem to be a glaring omission." The shortlist, in pictures:. 1. Mute swan. 2. Red kite. 3. Hen harrier. 4. Puffin. 5. Barn owl. 6. Kingfisher. 7. Wren. 8. Robin. 9. Blackbird. 10. Blue tit.
summary: The public has been asked to vote for The public favourite bird to be named as the UK' s national bird ahead of the general election.

document: Lufthansa lost an appeal to a Frankfurt labour court, but is making a further legal challenge that could go late into Tuesday evening. The pilots ' strike, called over a pay dispute, will affect around 100, 000 passengers, Lufthansa said. The industrial action is part of a long - running pay dispute at Lufthansa. The pilots ' union Vereinigung Cockpit ( VC) has organised 14 strikes since April 2014. Short and medium - haul flights from Germany will be affected from 00: 01 to 23: 59 local time ( 23: 01 - 22: 59 GMT). Flights by Lufthansa' s other airlines including Eurowings, Swiss, Austrian Airlines, Air Dolomiti and Brussels Airlines are not affected by the strike, the airline said. Pay talks between the Vereinigung union and the German airline broke down earlier this month, and Lufthansa said the union had" consistently rejected the offer" of mediation. The union is calling for a 3. 7 % pay rise for 5, 400 pilots dating back to 2012. Lufthansa, which is facing increasing competition from budget rivals, offered a 2. 5 % increase over the six years until 2019. Meanwhile, a separate dispute with cabin crew at Lufthansa' s low - cost subsidiary, Eurowings, led Lufthansa , which is facing increasing competition from budget rivals to cancel more than 60 flights on Tuesday.
summary: German airline Lufthansa has launched a fresh legal challenge against a strike by German airline Lufthansa pilots, which could lead to the cancellation of more than 1, 000 flights.

document: While ministers claim ministers Psychoactive Substances Bill reflects the findings of the experts, I am told that the hand - picked committee was divided on whether low - harm substances like amyl nitrate ( poppers) and nitrous oxide ( laughing gas) should be included. The final report was drafted by Home Office officials but some members of the panel, which included three people who also sit on the ACMD, insisted on writing in what became known as the" safety - valve" clause. The recommendation for" general prohibition" was amended to say that there should be exemptions for substances" where the risks of health and social harms can be adequately assessed". The line was included specifically to ensure that some low risk products could be excluded from the ban. The coalition government response last October went along with the safety - valve clause saying The coalition government response last October would" explore how to put in place a schedule of exemptions and make provision to add to a schedule of exemptions where the risks of health and social harms can be adequately assessed". But when the new Conservative government published the Psychoactive Substances Bill last month, any mention of assessing social harms or health risks had gone. The safety - valve clause insisted upon by the expert panel had been removed. The Home Office has made it clear that" there is no provision in the Bill to enable the licensing of so - called low - harm substances" arguing that there are difficulties in defining low risk and that the licensing of so - called low - harm substances might" send out confusing messages about the safety of new psychoactive substances". It is likely that this is going to be a major battleground as the controversial bill reaches committee stage in Parliament. The LibDem Home Affairs spokesman Lord Paddick has made it clear The LibDem Home Affairs spokesman Lord Paddick party will oppose the legislation in their Psychoactive Substances Bill current form." As drafted, the Bill is far too broad and indiscriminate, further undermining credibility and efficacy in reducing harm," The LibDem Home Affairs spokesman Lord Paddick told the House of Lords. The Bill would ban any substance that affects a consumer' s" mental functioning or emotional state", unless specifically exempted by the Home Secretary. This definition goes further than the Irish legislation on which the approach is modelled. In Ireland, a psychoactive substance is defined as one that results in" a significant disturbance in, or significant change to, motor function, thinking, behaviour, perception, awareness or mood". The word" significant" is, of course, significant. The word " significant " provides the safety valve that excludes low - risk and low - harm products. Whether UK ministers will relent on this issue of a" safety - valve clause" is perhaps the biggest question as the Psychoactive Substances Bill makes their Psychoactive Substances Bill progress through Parliament.
summary: The UK government' s approach to banning so - called" legal highs" is at odds with the recommendations of an expert panel set up by the Advisory Council on the Misuse of Drugs ( ACMD).

document: Councils in England are facing a £ 1. 1bn shortfall this year, on top of" almost unendurable" cuts since 2010, the Association of Directors of Adult Social Services has warned. Freezing care provider fees to save money was no long sustainable, the Association of Directors of Adult Social Services said. Ministers say extra money will help NHS and social care services work together. The survey, which was completed by 147 directors of adult social services for councils in England, suggests that funding reductions to social care budgets have totalled £ 4. 6bn since 2010 - a 31 % overall reduction. Budgets for adult social care - which provides practical support to people due to illness, disability, old age or a low income - will reduce by a further £ 500m in cash terms this year, The survey , which was completed by 147 directors of adult social services for councils in England said." Taking the growth in numbers of older and disabled people into account, reduce means that an additional £ 1. 1bn would be needed to provide the same level of service as last year," the report warned. The survey , which was completed by 147 directors of adult social services for councils in England said some councils had made savings in the past by freezing fees paid to providers, but care providers were now also facing financial problems. Some companies - particularly those in southern England - are struggling to attract staff, amid increasing concern about the quality of care, The survey , which was completed by 147 directors of adult social services for councils in England said." What is at stake is the continuing capacity of adult social care to sustain services to those in greatest need," ADASS president Ray James said." In virtually all our authorities, the number in need is growing, while the complexity of their needs is increasing." ADASS called for the government to" protect essential care and support services to the most vulnerable members of our community". But a government spokesman said the survey" ignores" a commitment to invest £ 10bn in health services that are being" joined up" with social care, by 2020. The BBC has launched an online guide to the care system for the over - 65s. The" care calculator" covers residential care and the support provided in people' s own homes, for tasks such as washing and dressing. Users can submit Users postcode and find out how much each service costs where Users live in the UK. There is also a dedicated BBC Cost of Care website, with news stories, analysis and video. The spokesman said:" Increasing budgets isn' t the only solution. By working innovatively and joining up health and social care we can improve care and also save money." However, Councillor Izzi Seccombe, from the Local Government Association ( LGA), said adult social care services were facing" enormous pressures" due to" insufficient funding, growing demand and escalating costs". " We have long warned that investing in the NHS whilst social care budgets are under continual pressure is simply a false economy." It is social care services that support elderly and vulnerable people to maintain elderly and vulnerable people independence, live in elderly and vulnerable people own community and stay out of hospital longer," she added. Caroline Abrahams, charity director at Age UK, said the idea of a further £ 1bn coming out of social care budgets was" chilling". Sue Brown, vice chairman of the Care and Support Alliance - which represents 80 leading charities - said the figures" confirm what we already know - that the care system is in worsening crisis". Sue Brown , vice chairman of the Care and Support Alliance - which represents 80 leading charities - said" chronic underfunding" of adult social care had seen" dramatic year - on - year rationing of support, excluding hundreds of thousands of older and disabled people from the care hundreds of thousands of older and disabled people desperately need". Janet Morrison, chief executive of the charity Independent Age, said:" This worrying survey shows how the frail and elderly in our society are being hit by year on year cutbacks to council services."" It' s vital now more than ever that we have an honest debate about the true costs of providing social care, not just health care," Janet Morrison , chief executive of the charity Independent Age added.
summary: An extra £ 1. 1bn will be needed to provide the same level of care for older and disabled people in England this year, a survey of adult social care bosses suggests.

document: For the next three weeks the city will host the International Festival, the Fringe and the Military Tattoo. The Fringe remains the world' s largest arts festival with 3, 269 shows at 294 venues. Meanwhile, the International Festival will host some of the finest performers from the worlds of theatre, music, opera and dance. Online highlights at bbc. co. uk / edinburghfestivals. Follow @ BBCEdFest on Twitter, facebook. com / BBCEdFest and Instagram. com / bbcedfest for updates. BBC Arts Online at bbc. co. uk / arts. The Royal Edinburgh Military Tattoo will pay tribute to the Queen, who celebrated the Queen , who celebrated her 90th birthday this year 90th birthday this year. The Royal Edinburgh Military Tattoo ' s will include a cast of more than 1, 200 performers and over 250 pipers and drummers from around the world. Twenty - five performances will take place across August, with a combined live audience of 220, 000 people. The Royal Air Force will open the show with a flypast on selected evenings, including a planned flypast by the world - famous Red Arrows on Saturday at 19. 30. The Royal Edinburgh Military Tattoo ' s will commemorate the centenary of the Great Arab Revolt - the British - backed uprising against the German - allied Ottoman Turks depicted in the film Lawrence Of Arabia. The anniversary of The Battle of Jutland will also be marked during the event. Brigadier David Allfrey, The Royal Edinburgh Military Tattoo' s chief executive and producer, said:" The Royal Edinburgh Military Tattoo ' s are particularly proud to add our celebration to Her Majesty the Queen' s special year while marking other important anniversaries: Jutland and the Great Arab Revolt." Above all though, the music is the star. This year The Royal Edinburgh Military Tattoo ' s have developed a fabulous score bursting with incredible tunes." The International Festival will stage a huge opening event on Sunday. a huge opening event is a free event called Deep Time, which will see artwork projected onto the western faÃ § ade of Edinburgh Castle and Castle Rock. The digitally - animated projections will be inspired by the city' s past, set to a special soundtrack by Scottish rock band Mogwai. projected will chart 350 million years of Edinburgh' s history, looking at how volcanic activity formed the landscape and exploring the intellectual legacy of the city. In particular, projected will celebrate the work of renowned Edinburgh scientist and thinker James Hutton. The Edinburgh Festival Fringe also gets under way. The Edinburgh Festival Fringe new chief executive Shona McCarthy promised" unparalleled" breadth and diversity of talent. The festival will be made up of:. The Edinburgh Festival Fringe remains the largest arts festival in the world despite a small fall in the number of shows - down 1. 3 % from 3, 314 last year.
summary: Edinburgh is gearing up for Edinburgh annual three - week arts festival, which begins on Sunday with the opening of the International Festival.

document: The materials, which can sense pressure as sensitively and quickly as human skin, have been outlined by two groups reporting in Nature Materials. The skins are arrays of small pressure sensors that convert tiny changes in pressure into electrical signals. The arrays are built into or under flexible rubber sheets that could be stretched into a variety of shapes. The materials could be used to sheath artificial limbs or to create robots that can pick up and hold fragile objects. their skins could also be used to improve tools for minimally - invasive surgery. In one approach, Ali Javey at the University of California, Berkeley, and Javey ' s colleagues built up layers of criss - crossed nanometre - scale wires topped with a thin rubber sheet. Together, the stack acts as what is known as a thin - film transistor, or TFT, with a pressure - sensitive layer on top. The amount of electrical current running through the device is dependent upon how much pressure is exerted on the rubber sheet; more pressure allows more current to flow. The team demonstrated the flexibility of Ali Javey at the University of California , Berkeley , and his colleagues TFT stacks by bending their TFT stacks to a radius smaller than that of a pencil without changing the skin' s performance." Javey' s work is a nice demonstration of Ali Javey at the University of California , Berkeley , and his colleagues capability in making a large array of nanowire TFTs," said Zhenan Bao of Stanford University, whose group demonstrated the second approach. The heart of Professor Bao' s devices is micro - structured rubber sheet in the middle of the TFT - effectively re - creating the functionality of the Berkeley group' s skins with less layers." Instead of laminating a pressure - sensitive resistor array on top of a nanowire TFT array, the Stanford group ' s made our transistors to be pressure sensitive," Professor Bao explained to BBC News." Our microstructured rubber can bounce back to Our microstructured rubber original shape much faster and enable higher sensitivity," Zhenan Bao of Stanford University , whose group demonstrated the second approach added. The overall flexibility of the Stanford group' s skins appears to be lower, and Professor Bao concedes that to develop Zhenan Bao of Stanford University , whose group demonstrated the second approach group' s approach further, better conductive rubber will be needed. Nevertheless, both groups demonstrate that two groups reporting in Nature Materials skins can register a pressure in a tenth of a second, over a large range - from five grams per square centimetre to 40 times that high. Those numbers rival the response of human skin, made with relatively inexpensive manufacturing techniques. John Boland, a nanotechnologist from Trinity College Dublin, praised the two approaches in a critique for Nature Materials." Perhaps the most remarkable aspect of these studies is how these studies elegantly demonstrate that it is possible to exploit well - established processing technologies to engineer low - cost innovative solutions to important technical problems," John Boland , a nanotechnologist from Trinity College Dublin wrote. However, he notes that there are still" significant opportunities for further innovation", such as reducing the distance between the sensors in the arrays to maximise the detail the sensors in the arrays could" feel", as well as improvements that could make large - area arrays possible and affordable.
summary: Flexible rubber skins that can detect pressure have been developed by scientists in the US.

It was late October 2014, and on paper the young banker had lived what could only be described as a privileged and successful life. But over the space of a few drug - and alcohol - fuelled days, the young banker tortured and killed Sumarti Ningsih, 23, and Seneng Mujiasih, 26, before calling the police to let the police know what the young banker had done. In court, lawyers described a much darker side to the young banker apparently gilded existence, one involving drugs, sexual sadism, and an extreme personality disorder. Jutting had tortured Ms Ningsih for three days, before the young banker killed Sumarti Ningsih , 23 by slashing Sumarti Ningsih , 23 throat over a prolonged period, nearly decapitating Sumarti Ningsih , 23. the young banker then hid Sumarti Ningsih , 23 body in a suitcase. A few days later, Jutting brought the young banker second victim, Ms Mujiasih, to the young banker flat. his second victim , Ms Mujiasih was a woman the young banker would go on to describe simply as" the prey" the young banker had been hunting." Sumarti was generous. was is clear from the evidence in the house. Sumarti Ningsih , 23 driving force was to improve life for Sumarti Ningsih , 23 family, to make her family richer. Life may be peaceful in the village but Sumarti Ningsih , 23 would have been all too aware of the possibilities of a life with more material comforts." The story of Sumarti: Born in Indonesia, murdered in Hong Kong. Experts for the defence say Jutting' s IQ score is 137 - putting the young banker in the top 1 % of the population. But Experts for the defence also diagnosed the young banker with four disorders, which Experts for the defence said combined to lead to the killings:. • Narcissistic personality disorder. • Sexual sadism disorder. • Cocaine use disorder. • Alcohol use disorder. Prosecution witnesses argued that such conditions should not" substantially" diminish the young banker ability to control the young banker actions. But according to the defence, when it came to the young banker narcissism, the signs were there from an early age. Jutting was born in London in 1985. the young banker first name Rurik was chosen by the young banker mother, and literally translated as" great one" - it was an imperial dynasty in Russia. the young banker described the young banker as an ambitious boy who had a happy childhood. But even from a young age, Jutting displayed feelings of superiority and entitlement, the young banker defence argued. the young banker was admitted to the prestigious private school Winchester College in the young banker early teens but was disappointed that the young banker ranked sixth in the scholarship selection, rather than first. When the young banker mother expressed delight at the young banker entrance exam results, Jutting commented that the young banker found his mother reaction" almost insulting", because her reaction implied that his mother was surprised the young banker had got in. There were other troubling episodes. When Mr Jutting was 16, Mr Jutting father tried to take his father own life by slashing his father wrists while his father was in the house. Jutting had to help provide the initial care and go to hospital with his father. Jutting also said Mr Jutting had been sexually assaulted by another student while studying at Winchester. In 2003, Mr Jutting was seen by a psychiatrist, who said Mr Jutting experienced suicidal thoughts and that Mr Jutting was affected by knowledge of Mr Jutting parents ' marital problems and concerns about Mr Jutting mother' s health. Nonetheless, Jutting excelled academically, being admitted to Cambridge University to study history and law at Peterhouse college. A fellow of the college, who asked to remain anonymous, told the BBC Mr Jutting was ambitious, a keen athlete, committed to Mr Jutting studies and from a stable Catholic background. British banker guilty of murders. Killed by Jutting and forgotten by Indonesia. ' We were lucky it wasn' t We ' ( video) Jutting gained first class honours in Mr Jutting history degree but was disappointed to receive a 2: 1 in law, and challenged the examiner' s approach. The inability to accept criticism, psychiatrists said, was another sign of Mr Jutting narcissistic personality traits. On graduation, Jutting worked at Barclays bank, before being head - hunted by Bank of America Merrill Lynch. Mr Jutting role involved developing complex tax products and, within a few years, Mr Jutting salary had risen to £ 270, 000 ( $ 334, 705) per year. But then, things began to go wrong. In 2012, while trying to market a tax product in Luxembourg, auditors began investigating Mr Jutting team for possible violation of regulations, flagging up Jutting in particular as a serious risk to the organisation. Jutting described this as a" negative turning point" in Mr Jutting career and felt Mr Jutting move to Hong Kong the subsequent year had been arranged by bosses to get Mr Jutting out of the way. At one point, Mr Jutting manager told Jutting Mr Jutting was one of the most unpredictable people his manager had ever worked with. Jutting' s alcohol use was also uncontrollable around this time, as Mr Jutting needed to drink excessive amounts in order to get to sleep. Mr Jutting then - girlfriend was so worried about Mr Jutting reliance on alcohol His then - girlfriend banned Mr Jutting from drinking at home. Mr Jutting briefly saw a psychiatrist at this point, and said Mr Jutting often felt down and tearful at work. By the time Mr Jutting had moved to Hong Kong in October 2013, Mr Jutting was consuming three quarters of a bottle of vodka to sleep and using cocaine. Mr Jutting said Mr Jutting smuggled cocaine up Mr Jutting rectum on Mr Jutting flight to Hong Kong. Once in Hong Kong, Jutting rented a flat in The J Residence, a luxury development in Wanchai popular with expatriate workers. Although located in a busy street in the heart of the city, the development gives off a sense of exclusivity. Keycards are needed to access individual floors, while the sheer height of the building, at over 41 floors, means that residents can enjoy views of Hong Kong' s skyline - from the bar, garden, and even swimming pool on the roof. But Jutting described Jutting as feeling increasingly despondent and nihilistic in the city. Jutting did not have much of a social life and spent long periods drinking at home while playing computer games. Jutting also had extreme sexual interests, and an obsession with sadistic pornography, experts said. Jutting began using sex workers in 2009 and as time went on Jutting behaviour became increasingly forceful. On a number of occasions, Jutting removed condoms during sex without their consent, despite knowing removed would constitute rape in the UK. Jutting continued to fantasise about rape and kidnap even while Jutting was remanded in a psychiatric centre after Jutting arrest, prosecution expert Dr Kavin Chow said. By 2014, Jutting was" spiralling out of control". Jutting would go on cocaine binges that lasted for days. At one point, Jutting missed a scheduled meeting in London and, as an excuse, Jutting told Jutting boss Jutting had HIV. Jutting developed a round - the - clock craving for the drug, Jutting weight ballooned and in the weeks before the killings took place Jutting stopped going to work. Instead, Jutting spent hours watching and reading violent pornography. Jutting attempted to find men on Grindr to have sex with, later telling a psychologist Jutting had been" trying to do everything Jutting could to get new experiences", but described everything as" disappointing". On 25 October 2014 Jutting took Ms Ningsih to Jutting flat, after offering to pay Ms Ningsih for sex. They had had sex on one occasion before, in a hotel, but things had got so violent that Ms Ningsih asked to end the session early, and refunded half Jutting money. On this second occasion, the sex also switched from consensual to non - consensual, as Jutting began to beat Ms Ningsih. Jutting then held Ms Ningsih captive, and tortured Ms Ningsih using pliers, Jutting belt, sex toys and Jutting hands. Jutting filmed some of the torture on Jutting phone, in footage that was shown to the jury. The details that follow are distressing and brutal. Jutting claims Jutting drifted in and out of the influence of cocaine:" When Jutting became relatively less under the influence of cocaine Jutting became quite apologetic - Jutting told Ms Ningsih repeatedly Jutting loved Ms Ningsih," Jutting said in one police interview. Yet, in another interview, Jutting said that Jutting hadn' t tortured Ms Ningsih as much as Jutting would have liked, before killing Ms Ningsih. Jutting killed Ms Ningsih on the third day, after Jutting made Ms Ningsih kneel in front of the toilet bowl, with Ms Ningsih hands tied behind Ms Ningsih back, and lick the bowl. Jutting then cut Ms Ningsih throat with a knife but Ms Ningsih did not die immediately, so Jutting dragged Ms Ningsih into the shower and continued. Jutting recorded several videos describing the aftermath of the killing on Jutting phone. Eventually, Jutting wrapped up the body and placed the body into a suitcase, which Jutting left on the balcony. Jutting began planning to torture a second victim on 31 October. Jutting bought tools, including sandpaper, nails and a blow torch, filming tools , including sandpaper , nails and a blow torch on Jutting iPhone, describing how Jutting might use tools , including sandpaper , nails and a blow torch to torture a victim. That night, Jutting went out and met Ms Mujiasih, inviting Ms Mujiasih back to Jutting flat for sex. They began kissing and cuddling on the sofa but Ms Mujiasih began shouting when Ms Mujiasih saw a gag by the sofa. Jutting held a knife against Ms Mujiasih throat, telling Ms Mujiasih Jutting would kill Ms Mujiasih if Ms Mujiasih continued to struggle. Ms Mujiasih continued struggling, and Jutting killed Ms Mujiasih by slashing at Ms Mujiasih neck. Jutting later told police:" Ms Mujiasih was simply, the word Jutting' d use is prey. Jutting was hunting for prey and Ms Mujiasih was unfortunately the person who was hunted". After taking more cocaine, Jutting says Jutting contemplated taking Jutting own life. Jutting eventually called 999. Jutting also called Jutting boss, saying:" Jutting' m in a lot of trouble, his boss need to do something about the reputation of the bank." Even though Jutting had not been to work in the two weeks leading up to the killings, the office was still on Jutting mind. After Jutting killed Ms Ningsih, Jutting changed the out - of - office message from Jutting work email to:" Jutting am out of the office. Indefinitely. For urgent enquiries, or indeed any enquiries, please contact someone who is not an insane psychopath. For escalation please contact God, though suspect the devil will have custody. [ Last line only really worked if Jutting had followed through..]" On one occasion, according to an expert witness, Jutting likened Jutting life to The Truman Show, a movie starring Jim Carrey about a man who' s entire life, unbeknownst to a man who ' s entire life , unbeknownst to him , is a TV show, is a TV show. likened too may reflect Jutting narcissism because Jutting wanted to believe that" Jutting life was so significant that … millions of people would be interested in watching his life". Jutting is now likely to spend much if not all of his life in jail.
summary: Rurik Jutting, who has been found guilty of the murders of two women in Hong Kong, has been sentenced to life in prison with a minimum of 25 years.

document: Six documents taken from an old account belonging to Mr Brennan were published by the anti - secrecy group WikiLeaks. The CIA said there was" no indication" that anything classified was released. But the documents do include a draft security clearance application containing personal information. Six documents taken from an old account belonging to Mr Brennan appear to all date to 2009, when Mr Brennan was seeking security clearance while applying for a job as a White House counterterrorism adviser. Mr Brennan was working in the private sector at the time, having already spent 25 years working for the CIA between 1980 and 2005. A high - school student claimed The boy ' s was responsible for hacking the AOL account, telling Nthe New York Post The boy ' s was protesting against US foreign policy. The boy' s Twitter account, which says The boy ' s is 13, has published redacted images of what appears to be government information. The documents published by Wikileaks include a draft on national security challenges said to have been created in 2007. The final, unfinished paragraph is headed" Damaging Leaks of Classified Information". A 2008 letter about interrogation methods is also included, appearing to be from the vice - chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence to the vice - chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence fellow board members. Wikileaks said the anti - secrecy group WikiLeaks would release more documents" over the coming days". The FBI and the Secret Service are investigating the hacking. The CIA stressed that none of the documents released so far were classified." In fact, the documents released so far appear to be documents that a private citizen with national security interests and expertise would be expected to possess," a statement said. High - profile leaks including a wealth of diplomatic cables from Wikileaks have dogged the US government in recent years. The use of private email has become a major issue in recent months for White House hopeful Hillary Clinton, since it emerged that White House hopeful Hillary Clinton had operated a private account while secretary of state. Mr Brennan became director of the CIA in 2013, having spent four years as assistant to the president for homeland security and counterterrorism.
summary: The CIA director John Brennan' s personal email account has been hacked by a hacker, according to documents published by a whistle - blowing website.

document: Dead Men Risen, written by Toby Harnden and published by Quercus, took the prize at a ceremony in Westminster and was the judges ' unanimous choice. Dead Men Risen , written by Toby Harnden and published by Quercus focuses on the death of Lt Colonel Rupert Thorneloe in 2009. Dead Men Risen , written by Toby Harnden and published by Quercus challenges every citizen of this country to examine exactly what we' re asking soldiers to do in Afghanistan," the panel continued." Rather than offering easy answers Dead Men Risen , written by Toby Harnden and published by Quercus lets the soldiers speak for the soldiers." Other awards presented included a posthumous honour for Christopher Hitchens, whose final book, Arguably, was included on the long list for the top prize. Hitchens ' widow Carol Blue accepted the award on behalf of the Vanity Fair writer. The journalism prize was awarded to Amelia Gentleman for Amelia Gentleman work in The Guardian, while the blog award went to Rangers Tax Case - an online commentary on the ongoing financial problems at the historic Scottish football club. The writers of the blog said The writers of the blog aimed to" provide the details of what Rangers FC have done, why it was illegal and what the implications are for one of the largest football clubs in Britain". The winners were chosen from shortlists of six books, six journalists and seven bloggers, whittled down from longlists of 17 books, 12 journalists and 18 bloggers. Each of the winners received a Â £ 3, 000 prize.
summary: A book about the life and death of a Welsh Guardsman killed in Afghanistan has won the prestigious Man Booker Prize for Fiction.

Tian Tian the giant panda was artificially inseminated earlier this year after attempts to bring Tian Tian the giant panda together with male partner, Yang Guang, failed. The zoo said new scientific tests had given a" strong indication" of pregnancy, but were" too new to be definitive". Tian Tian also conceived last year, but the pregnancy failed. Iain Valentine, director of Giant Pandas for the Royal Zoological Society of Scotland, said:" The latest scientific data suggests Tian Tian the giant panda is now pregnant and that implantation has taken place, therefore Tian Tian the giant panda may give birth at the end of the month." This is all very new and complex science and we still have a bit of time to go yet." As like last year, the late loss of a cub remains entirely possible." The zoo said the Royal Zoological Society of Scotland had been able to confirm that Tian Tian did become pregnant last year. However, the Royal Zoological Society of Scotland said it was most likely that Tian Tian the giant panda had reabsorbed the foetus late term. The two pandas arrived in Scotland from China in 2011. Tian Tian has had cubs in the past in China, before Tian Tian the giant panda came on loan to Edinburgh. If Tian Tian the giant panda does have a successful delivery, it will be the first time a giant panda has been born in Britain. summary: Edinburgh Zoo' s giant panda Tian Tian is expected to give birth at the end of the month, the zoo has said.

document: These are external links and will open in a new window. The move, if enacted, would make Natwest and RBS the first UK banks to introduce negative interest rates, in effect, charging to deposit money." Global interest rates remain at very low levels... remain could result in Natwest charging interest on credit balances," Natwest wrote in a letter to customers. Personal customers are not affected. However, charities and community groups are counted as business clients and so would be affected by the changes, the banks said. A spokesperson for Royal Bank of Scotland, which owns NatWest, told the BBC the letter was sent to just under 1. 3 million of the combined business and commercial customers of the two banks." Royal Bank of Scotland , which owns NatWest will consider any necessary action in the event of the Bank of England base rate falling below zero, but will do our utmost to protect our customers from any impacts," Royal Bank of Scotland , which owns NatWest said. Jack: The weird world of negative interest rates. The Federation of Small Businesses, which has 170, 000 members, called on other banks to update customers of any changes to customers Business Current Account ( BCA)" during this uncertain economic period". Mike Cherry, National Chairman at the Federation of Small Businesses ( FSB), said the warning from Natwest and RBS" will be deeply concerning to small firms". The FSB also urged the Bank of England to consider the impact on smaller firms of cutting interest rates. Mike Amey, a managing director at investment firm Pimco, said the two banks were" giving Natwest and RBS wiggle room in the very unlikely event" that the Bank turns the official interest rate negative." The Bank of England sets the interest rate next week, so the fact the Bank of England put this out this week... is possibly a bit of a reminder to the Bank of England there are negative consequences," Mike Amey , a managing director at investment firm Pimco told the BBC. UK interest rates have been unchanged since the Bank of England cut UK interest rates to a record low of 0. 5 % in March 2009 at the height of the financial crisis. The Bank kept UK interest rates on hold earlier this month, despite speculation the Bank of England would cut rates further. But Bank governor Mark Carney has said it is likely" some monetary policy easing" will be required to boost the UK economy in response to the Brexit vote. However, Bank governor Mark Carney has said Bank governor Mark Carney does not favour rates falling any lower than 0. 25 %. Nevertheless, some economists believe that rates could still be cut to zero or lower later this year. When the rate goes below zero, the normal relationship between banks and customers is reversed. Instead of the lender getting paid interest by the bank for allowing the bank to use the lender money, the lender has to pay the bank for holding the lender money. The underlying idea is much the same as cutting interest rates in more normal times. The aim is to encourage more borrowing and spending by firms and less saving. In 2014, the European Central Bank was the first major central bank to introduce negative interest rates, with the aim of encouraging banks to lend to businesses rather than hold on to money.
summary: NatWest and RBS have warned NatWest and RBS business customers that NatWest and RBS could start charging interest on their business customers money in the event of the Bank of England cutting interest rates below 0. 25 %.
